questions.text: Which muscle type is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Multipennate The image shows the pectoralis major muscle. The pectoralis major muscle is classified as multipennate, not unipennate. Multipennate muscles have multiple tendons with muscle fibers that branch out diagonally in a feather-like pattern from the central tendon. The pectoralis major has several tendons with muscle fibers extending in different directions, giving it a multipennate arrangement.
 

Other options: -

Option 1: Cruciate: Muscle fibres are arranged in X shape. Ex:- Sternocleidomastoid

Option 3: Parallel: Muscle fibres in these muscle run parallel to the length of muscle. Ex:- Biceps brachi

Option 4: Unipennate: Muscle fibres are arranged on one side of tendon. Ex:- Extensor digitorum

Reference : Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition - page no.112

questions.text: What are the following structures in the given image of axilla?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 1-Medial cord of brachial plexus, 2-long thoracic nerve, 3-subscapularis

Structure 1: Medial cord of brachial plexus
  • It is a part of the brachial plexus, a network of nerves that supplies the upper limb.
  • The medial cord gives rise to multiple nerves responsible for innervating various muscles and structures in the upper limb.

Structure 2: Long thoracic nerve
  • It originates from the roots of the brachial plexus.
  • The long thoracic nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle.
  • It plays a crucial role in stabilizing the scapula during movements of the upper limb.

Structure 3: Subscapularis
  • The subscapularis is one of the four muscles that form the rotator cuff in the shoulder region.
  • It is located on the anterior surface of the scapula (shoulder blade) and aids in the internal rotation of the arm.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42nd Page no 927.

questions.text: A patient who was unable to move his fourth and fifth fingers, hold a pen, or hold a piece of paper between his fingers was presented. Which of the sites listed below is most likely to have caused the nerve injury
questions.solution:
Correct answer, Option 4: D, which shows the medial epicondyle of humerus behind which the ulnar nerve passes. Ulnar nerve supplies the medial half of Flexor Digitorum Profundus which causes flexion of fourth and fifth fingers and palmar interossei which causes adduction of fingers. Thus in ulnar nerve injury the patient as mentioned in the question, fails to move his 4th and 5th fingers and card test is positive( Inability to hold paper/card in between fingers).



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 984,984.e1

questions.text: Which nerve may be involved in the malformation seen below?
questions.solution:
This image is showing partial Claw hand sign which is seen in Ulnar nerve damage.

Ulnar nerve supplies
1. 3rd and 4th Lumbricals 
2. Palmar and Dorsal interossei

3/4th lumbrical are required for PIP and DIP extension at 4th/5th digits, and 4th/5th digit flexion at MCP joint.
Hence, ulnar nerve damage will lead to flexion at 4th/5th digit PIP and DIP joints, and extension at  4th/ 5th digit MCP joints leading to partial ulnar claw hand.




Note: The image given is not of Benediction(Pope) sign. In Benedict sign (which occurs due to median nerve damage) - there is loss of 1st and 2nd lumbricals (which helps in 2/3rd digits MCP Flexion) - leading to extension at index/middle finger MCP joint. But since 3/4th lumbrical are spared - there is flexion at 4/5th digit MCP joint. 
The main difference is at 4/5th digit MCP joint - In ulnar claw hand - 4/5th digit MCP joint would be extended; while 4th/5th digit MCP in benedict sign(median nerve injury) would be flexed. 




Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 984,984.e1

questions.text: Identify the function of the muscle at Metacarpophalangeal joint shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Flexion The muscles shown in the image are the lumbricals muscles. The lumbricals are a group of four small muscles located in the hand. They originate from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus and insert onto the extensor expansion of the fingers. The primary function of the lumbricals is to flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints of the fingers. This action allows for finger flexion and helps with gripping and holding objects.




Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 883,885

questions.text: Injury to the marked structure in the given cadaveric image will result in
questions.solution:
Specimen shown in the given image is of cubital fossa. Marked structure is of radial nerve (lateral most) which supplies the extensors of wrist. A fracture of the midshaft of humerus results in damage to the radial nerve. Extensor muscles in the forearm, hand, metacarpals, and phalanges lose their ability to extend the joint. Additionally, it causes wrist drop due to a loss of wrist extension and weakens the hand's ability to adduct and abduct.

questions.text: Name the nerve that is indicated by arrow D.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Genitofemoral nerve 

Anatomy:

  1. Origin: The genitofemoral nerve arises from the anterior divisions of the L1 and L2 spinal nerves within the lumbar plexus.

  2. Course: After its origin, the nerve descends through the psoas major muscle and emerges from its lateral border.

  3. Branches:

    • Genital Branch (or Genital Component)
    • Femoral Branch (or Femoral Component)

Function:

  • The Genitofemoral nerve is a mixed nerve.
  • Sensory Innervation: The sensory branch of the Genitofemoral nerve supplies the skin of the upper anterior thigh (femoral branch) and the skin over the scrotum or labia majora (genital branch).
  • Motor Innervation :The motor branch of the Genitofemoral nerve innervates the cremaster muscle in males and the round ligament of the uterus in females.



 


 

Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 1464e.40,1140

questions.text: The relationships of the epiploic foramen are displayed in the abdomen's subsequent coronal section. According to the illustration below, which of the following structures constitutes its superior boundary?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Caudate lobe of the liver
 
  • The epiploic foramen, also known as the foramen of Winslow, is a small opening in the peritoneum that connects the lesser sac to the greater sac.
  • The superior boundary of the epiploic foramen is formed by the caudate lobe of the liver.
  • The caudate lobe is one of the lobes of the liver and lies posteriorly, adjacent to the inferior vena cava.

   Boundaries of epiploic foramen :

questions.text: Identify the nerve highlighted by the red box in the given image
questions.solution:
The structure highlighted by the red box is ischial spine and it is related to the internal pudendal nerve. 

It is a branch of sacral plexus-S2S3S4 and it exits from the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen. Thereafter, it enters the perineum below the pelvic floor by passing around ischial spine through the lesser sciatic foramen. 

The ischial spine serves as an important landmark for pudendal nerve block. 

Note- The structures passing the lesser sciatic foramen can be remembered by the mnemonic PINT

P- Pudendal nerve
I- Internal pudendal vessels
N-Nerve to obturator internus
T-Tendon of obturator internus


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1147,1199,1252

questions.text:
A little child was admitted to the hospital by his father due to a fever, a low backache, and chronic hip flexion.
He has already experienced spine TB. The infant has an inguinal swelling upon inspection. Which indicated muscle is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: a
 
  • The inguinal swelling in the image is caused by the psoas abscess extending into the inguinal canal.
  • The psoas major muscle is the most likely muscle to be involved in this case because it is the muscle that is most affected by psoas abscess.
  • Psoas abscess is most commonly caused by infection from the spine, such as from spine TB.
  • The infection can spread to the psoas major muscle through the intervertebral foramina.
   



Reference-: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery Edition 28 th Page No 1104

questions.text: Which of the following is an exception to the supply of the marked part
questions.solution:
The arrow in the image is pointing towards the right ventricle.
BLOOD SUPPLY OF HEART Right coronary artery- It originates from the right (anterior) aortic sinus of aortic artery. It then travels between the right auricle and the root of the pulmonary trunk. It then descends in the right coronary sulcus. It supplies the RA and RV.
Marginal artery- The inferior margin of the right ventricle is supplied by the marginal artery, a branch of the right coronary artery that extends along the inferior border and toward the apex. Left anterior descending (LAD)-The Left Coronary Artery's branch known as the Anterior IV (Left Anterior Descending) Artery supplies the anterior parts of the right and left ventricles and serves as the main blood supply for the IV septum and apex.
Diagonal artery- The anterolateral surface of the left ventricle is supplied by the LAD branch known as the diagonal artery.

questions.text: Which of these is accurate regarding the space pointed by green arrow in the given figure:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Breath sound can be heard more clearly 

The marked arrow indicates the triangle of auscultation.
The marked area is the triangle of auscultation.
Boundaries include-
• Medially by the lateral border of the inferior part of trapezius.
• Laterally by the vertebral border of the scapula.
• Inferiorly by the superior border of latissimus dorsi muscle.
Importance-
• Only part of back which is covered by muscles.
• Respiratory sounds are better heard when ausculted here.
The triangle of auscultation refers to a specific anatomical region on the human body where lung sounds can be best heard. It is an area where there is less muscle and fat coverage, allowing for clearer auscultation of respiratory sounds. Here’s how you can locate it:

  • Position: Stand or sit comfortably with your back exposed.

  • Location: The triangle itself is located roughly between the scapula (shoulder blade) and the latissimus dorsi muscle. Specifically, it is an imaginary triangle-shaped area with its base along the bottom edge of the scapula and its apex pointing towards the lower ribs.

  • Purpose: This area is important for auscultation (listening with a stethoscope) because the underlying lung tissue is closer to the surface here, allowing healthcare providers to hear respiratory sounds such as normal breathing sounds (vesicular breath sounds) or abnormal sounds like crackles or wheezes more clearly.

  • In clinical practice, this region is particularly useful for detecting abnormalities in lung sounds and for assessing respiratory function in patients.



    Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 843,852

questions.text: Which specific muscle aids in the opening of the jaw?
questions.solution:
The muscles marked in the given image are as follows-

a- Masseter- Elevation of jaw and protrusion

b- Medial Pterygoid- Elevation of mandible and protrusion

c- Lateral Pterygoid- Depression of mandible and protrusion of jaw

d- Buccinator- Helps in blowing action

Trick- 

1. All muscles of mastication cause protrusion of jaw except temporalis which causes jaw retraction.

2. All muscles of mastication help in elevation of mandible except lateral pterygoid which depresses the mandible causing mouth opening. 

3. The key to identify lateral pterygoid muscle as shown in the image is to look for its insertion in temporo-mandibular joint.

questions.text: The following image displays numerous foramina at the base of the skull. Which of the following foramina does the mandibular nerve pass through?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: B
 
  • The mandibular nerve (which is the third branch of the trigeminal nerve, or cranial nerve V) passes through the Foramen ovale  at the base of the skull.
  • The base of the skull contains various foramina through which nerves and blood vessels pass.
  • The foramen ovale is located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, on the lateral aspect of the skull base.
  • It serves as a passageway for the mandibular nerve, allowing it to exit the skull and innervate structures in the face and jaw.

   


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 391,566

questions.text: Which of the following jaw movements is controlled by the muscle identified in the following cross section?
questions.solution:
The star pictured above marks the Lateral pterygoid muscle, which connects the lateral
pterygoid plate to the neck of the mandible and the TM joint. It is the only muscle that opens the jaw, and it assists the medial pterygoid muscle in protracting the jaw. (not main function)
Therefore, opening the jaw is the correct response.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 677,678

questions.text: Which of the following is the level of the nerve's nucleus, which supplies the muscle indicated in the diagram?
questions.solution:
The marked muscle here in the eyeball is the medial rectus muscle.
It is supplied by the oculomotor nerve, whose nucleus is at the level of superior colliculus.

Trick to memorize nerve supply of EOMs is- LR-6 SO-4
Lateral Rectus supplied by 6th cranial nerve and Superior Oblique by 4th cranial nerve. Rest all EOMs are supplied by 3rd cranial nerve.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 771,772,773,458

questions.text: In the given image, what is the action of the highlighted muscle?
questions.solution:
The marked muscle is temporalis, and the action of temporalis is elevation of the mandible. The temporalis raises the jaw, which closes the mouth and brings the teeth closer together. Note- All muscles of mastication produce jaw elevation except lateral pterygoid. All muscles of mastication cause protraction of jaw except temporalis. Primary action is elevation.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 677

questions.text: Which of the muscles depicted in the diagram aids in jaw protrusion?
questions.solution:
The lateral pterygoid muscle is shown by the letter "A" in the diagram.
It has two heads and enters the pterygoid fossa below the mandible, working bilaterally to protrude the jaw.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 677,678

questions.text: In this cross-sectional illustration of the neck, locate the vagus nerve:
questions.solution:
Between the internal jugular vein and the internal carotid artery in the neck's carotid sheath, the vagus nerve descends vertically.
This gives us the answer as option ‘C’.
‘D’ is a sympathetic trunk that lies outside the carotid sheath.

questions.text: Which facial line is highlighted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ohngren's line runs from the angle of the mandible to the medial canthus of the eye.

The line designates a plane that is orthogonal to the sagittal plane and separates the maxillary sinus into two sections: (1) the anterior-inferior part, and (2) the superior-posterior part.

The prognosis of tumors that develop in the anterior-inferior region, or below Ohngren's line, is typically better than that of the other group.



Reference-:https://www.otoscape.com/eponyms/ohngren-s-line.html

questions.text: Find the structure in this figure whose paralysis results in a reduction in breathing motions.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: A
 
  • The structure in the figure that is labeled A is the phrenic nerve.
  • The phrenic nerve is responsible for innervating the diaphragm, which is the major muscle of breathing.
  • The phrenic nerve carries motor signals from the brain to the diaphragm, stimulating its contraction and promoting inhalation.
  • Paralysis of the phrenic nerve will result in a reduction in breathing motions and may result in respiratory difficulties or even respiratory failure, depending on the extent of the nerve damage.
  The other structures in the figure are the following:
  • B: Thyrocervical artery
  • C: Inferior thyroid artery
  • D: Vagus nerve


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 550,580

questions.text: What is the name of the artery marked with a black arrow in the above diagram?
questions.solution:
Posterior communicating artery which is a part of the circle of Willis.

According to the labelling given in question, various structures are—

A : optic chiasm, B : internal carotid artery, C : posterior communicating artery, D : optic tract, E : anterior thalamoperforating arteries, F : cerebral peduncle, G : P2 segment of posterior cerebral artery, H : Pl segment of posterior cerebral artery, I : mammillary body, J : tuber cinereum, K : anterior choroidal artery





Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 419

questions.text: The larynx can be seen in the superior and side views in the images below. Which letter represents the vocal cord abductor?
questions.solution:
Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle.

The only abductor of the larynx is Posterior Cricoarytenoid muscle which is the posterior- most muscle.

All other muscles are adductors of the vocal cords. It is also called as the safety muscle of larynx.

questions.text: Which thickened nerve is visible in the picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Great auricular nerve
 
  • The great auricular nerve is a cutaneous nerve that supplies sensation to the skin of the ear and the side of the neck. It is a branch of the cervical plexus.
  • The great auricular nerve is often thickened in people with leprosy, a chronic infectious disease that affects the skin, nerves, and limbs.
  • The facial nerve, vagus nerve, and glossopharyngeal nerve are all cranial nerves that supply the head and neck. They are not visible in the picture.
  • The picture shows a person with probably leprosy, and the thickened nerve is the great auricular nerve.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 554.e1,573

questions.text: Where is the nerve's nucleus that supplies the muscle that has been marked?
questions.solution:
The muscle highlighted is Medial Rectus and is innervated by oculomotor nerve.The oculomotor nerve originates from the third nerve nucleus at the level of 
the superior colliculus in the midbrain. It regulates all extraocular muscles, with the exception of the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles, as well as the striated muscle of the levator palpebrae superioris.

questions.text: Which of the nerves marked in the given image does not cause movement of the eyeball?
questions.solution:
In the image given above

A- Optic nerve(II)
B- Oculomotor nerve(III)
C- Trochlear nerve (IV)
D- Abducens nerve (VI)

Optic nerve does not cause movement of the eyeball.

EOM are supplied by 3rd, 4th and 6th nerves. The optic nerve carries visual impulses from the retina.

All EOM are supplied by 3rd nerve except- Lateral Rectus : 6th nerve, Superior Oblique : 4th nerve

questions.text: From the image given below, identify the marked foramen.
questions.solution:
The bone in the above image is Anterior view of Sphenoid Bone and the foramen is Foramen Rotundum.

Contents of Foramen Rotundum:
  • Maxillary Nerve, second branch of trigeminal nerve
  • Artery of  foramen rotundum
  • Emissary Vein
The foramen located inferomedial to foramen rotundum is the Vidian Canal ( Pterygoid canal ) which transmits
 
  • Vidian nerve - formed by joining of greater petrosal nerve ( branch of facial nerve ) and deep petrosal nerve ( sympathetic plexus of ICA ) and provides secretomotor fibers to lacrimal, nasal and palatine glands.
  • Artery of pterygoid canal ( Arises from 3rd part of internal maxillary artery )
  • Vein of pterygoid canal 


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 566,665,682

questions.text: Which of the marked structures does not contribute to the structure of the larynx
questions.solution:
In the given image A- Hyoid bone B- Thyroid Cartilage C- Epiglottis D- Cricoid Cartilage Hyoid bone does not contribute to the laryngeal structure. Laryngeal structure is made up of 3 paired and 3 unpaired cartilages. Unpaired : Thyroid, cricoid, epiglottis Paired : Arytenoid, corniculate ( cartilage of Santorini ) and cuneiform

questions.text: A patient is admitted with a fracture at the base of the skull that affects the bones of the temporal and occipital regions. Following the trauma, he was unable to speak properly. Which of the marked structures would you examine in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this question, the fracture involves the junction between the temporal bone and the occipital bone. This junction contains the jugular foramen which transmits the 9th, 10th & 11th cranial nerves which may be injured and cause different symptoms. Since the clinical history is suggestive of dysarthria, we can check the uvula to examine the function of cranial nerves IX and X, by eliciting gag reflex. In the given image A- middle meatus, B- uvula, C- tongue and D- larynx


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 598,599,567,568

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the third section of the vertebral artery?
questions.solution:
Vertebral artery is one of the principal arteries that supply the brain. It is the first and largest branch of the first part of Subclavian Artery.It has four parts—

a) Cervical Part

b)Vertebral Part 

c) Suboccipital Part 

d) Intracranial Part,

the 3rd part of vertebral artery moves from foramen transversarium to foramen magnum reaching the posterior arch of the vertebra.

questions.solution:
1. Oculomotor nerve innervates the muscle that is highlighted, which is the Medial Rectus. 

The third nerve nucleus, which is located in the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus, is the source of the oculomotor nerve. 

The third nerve nucleus is situated on the pre-aqueductal grey matter ventral to the cerebral aqueduct.

questions.text: The floor of the region enclosed by the dotted black line is made up of
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Splenius capitis
 
  • The dotted black line in the image encloses the posterior triangle of the neck.
  • The posterior triangle is a triangular space in the neck that is bounded by the trapezius muscle superiorly, the sternocleidomastoid muscle medially, and the clavicle inferiorly.
  • The floor of the posterior triangle is made up of the levator scapulae, middle layer of the deep cervical fascia, and the splenius capitis muscle.

questions.text: Pick the correct nerve that doesn't pass through the foramen marked in the picture.
questions.solution:
The arrow points towards Foramen Ovale, present in the sphenoid bone.
Contents of Foramen ovale include: Trick- MALE

  • Mandibular Nerve (Sensory and motor branch)
  • Accessory Meningeal Artery

The maxillary nerve instead passes through the Foramen Rotundum(not foramen ovale) present in the base of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone.

questions.text: What would be the likely deficit if the area marked below gets affected?
questions.solution:
• The frontal lobe, which houses the Broca's region, is where the arrow in this illustration is pointing. Despite being mostly on the lateral side of the brain, this region extends all the way to the medial surface. Aphasia results from this area being affected.
  • The anterior cerebral artery was not visible in the illustration. The lower limb would have been the correct response if the arrow were pointed at the artery.

questions.text: Select the muscle that is supplied by the cranial nerve nucleus present beneath the area marked by the arrow below.
questions.solution:
The arrow in the given diagram points towards floor of fourth ventricle and towards Facial Colliculus. 
Facial colliculus is an elevated area located in the dorsal pons.
It is formed by fibres from the facial motor nucleus looping over the abducens(VI) nucleus

The 6th cranial nerve supplies the Lateral Rectus muscle.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure 'A' in the image?
questions.solution:
Marked structure in the given image is the posterior commissure.

Commissural fibers forming the rostrum extend laterally, below the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle, connecting the orbital surfaces of the frontal lobes.

Fibers in the genu curve forwards, as the forceps minor, to connect the lateral and medial surfaces of the frontal lobes.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 512,525,537

questions.text: Identify the marked nerve shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Abducent nerve is the marked nerve in the illustration.

When the abducent nerve leaves the brainstem, it moves into the subarachnoid area. It ascends between the pons and the clivus before piercing the dura mater and passes via Dorello's canal to run between the dura and the skull.

It turns sharply forward at the point of the petrous temporal bone to enter the cavernous sinus.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 445

questions.text: The section of the brain is shown below with a region highlighted. What pathology will result from a defect in this area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Paralysis agitans
 
  • The highlighted area in the image is the substantia nigra, which is a part of the basal ganglia.
  • The basal ganglia are a group of nuclei in the brain that are involved in movement, learning, and emotion.
  • Parkinson's disease (paralysis agitans) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is caused by the loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra.
  • Symptoms of Parkinson's disease include tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability.

   



Reference:https://www.britannica.com/science/Parkinson-disease

questions.text: Which of the following structures connects to the arrow-marked structure in the illustration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Amygdala
 
  • The amygdala is the small, almond-shaped structure in the middle of the illustration.
  • It is located in the temporal lobe of the brain.
  • It is involved in the processing of emotions, particularly fear and aggression.
  • The tail of the caudate nucleus is the arrow-marked structure at the bottom of the illustration.
  • The stria terminalis is the bundle of nerve fibers that connects the amygdala to the tail of the caudate nucleus.

   


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 518-520.e1

questions.text: Which of the following is inhibited by the axon of the neuron pointed with an arrow in this cross-sectional image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cerebellar nuclei
 
  • The arrow is showing purkinje fibers.
  • In the central nervous system, Purkinje cells in the cerebellum play a crucial role in inhibiting the activity of cerebellar nuclei.
  • This inhibitory control helps modulate and fine-tune the output signals of the cerebellum.
  • Purkinje cells contribute to the coordination and smooth execution of voluntary movements.
  • Therefore, the axons of Purkinje cells inhibit cerebellar nuclei, aiding in motor coordination.
 


 



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 468-470

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of occlusion of the artery supplying the marked area?
questions.solution:
The marked area is the paracentral lobule.
 
  • This region controls voluntary urination and defecation as well as the movements of the contralateral lower leg and perineum.
  •  Hence, blockage of the artery feeding the paracentral lobule can result in perianal analgesia, urinary incontinence, and rectal incontinence but not apraxia.
Apraxia results from damage to dominant parietal lobe. 


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 512
https://radiopaedia.org/articles/paracentral-lobule

questions.text: Identify the highlighted nerve in the given cranial cavity section.
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image of cranial cavity is oculomotor nerve. It is the third cranial nerve. 
  • Four of the extraocular muscles are innervated by it: the superior, inferior, medial, and inferior oblique muscles. Moreover, it carries parasympathetic fibers that relay in the ciliary ganglion.
  • The nerve begins at the midbrain, medial to the cerebral peduncle's crus, and travels along the lateral cavernous sinus wall before splitting into superior and inferior divisions that pass below the trochlear and ophthalmic nerves.


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 391,563,566

questions.text: In the diagram, identify the nerve whose palsy causes lateral gaze palsy.
questions.solution:
The sixth cranial nerve (abducens nerve), which supplies the lateral rectus muscle, is what causes lateral gaze palsy and it travels within the sinus in close relation with the internal carotid artery.
Hence the answer is option ‘B’

Other options:
A. Occulomotor nerve
C. Trochlear nerve
D. Ophthalmic branch of Maxillary nerve

questions.text: In the marked area, what is the blood supply?
questions.solution:
Marked region is fornix and it is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.
Anterior Cerebral Artery produces multiple anteromedial central branches that supply the anterior columns of the fornix, the cingulate gyms, the para-olfactory areas, the optic chiasm, the lamina terminalis, the hypothalamus, and other regions.
Note-
1. The chief artery of superolateral surface of cerebral hemisphere is middle cerebral artery. 
2. The chief artery of medial surface of cerebral hemisphere is anterior cerebral artery. 
3. The chief artery of posterior surface of cerebral hemisphere is posterior cerebral artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is an outcome of the lesion of the marked structure
questions.solution:
The arrow mark is pointing the medullary pyramids. It contains corticospinal tracts in its base. Corticospinal tracts are comprised of upper motor neurons which decussate in the lower part of the medulla and terminate on alpha motor neurons- which are lower motor neurons innervating the skeletal muscles. Therefore, it's injury in the medulla proximal to decussation will result in contralateral hemiplegia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was diagnosed with tetany, hypoparathyroidism, and a lack of the thymus. Which of the following identified areas is flawed in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: C
 
  • In a normal embryonic development process, the third endodermal clefts contribute to the formation of the thymus and parathyroid glands, respectively.
  • Therefore, the lack of the thymus and the presence of hypoparathyroidism in the 5-year-old boy suggest that there may have been a developmental issue or abnormality in the region corresponding to the third endodermal cleft (Area C in the diagram).
  • In Di George syndrome, a small piece of chromosome 22 is missing, which leads to developmental issues affecting several structures, including the thymus and parathyroid glands.
 
    


   



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464e.149, 275

questions.text: A young patient with hypoparathyroidism and tetany arrived with a missing thymus. In this situation, which of the following marked areas in the image is defective
questions.solution:
DiGeorge syndrome is caused by a defect in the third pharyngeal pouch, which has the thymus and the inferior parathyroid gland as its derivatives. The thymus and parathyroid glands in the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches fail to differentiate. caused by the loss of chromosome 22's long arm. Consequently, it is also known as 22q deletion syndrome.

 

Preference: Gray’s Anotomy The Anotomical Basis of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd page no 1464e.149

questions.text: From where is the marked structure derived ?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the provided specimen is membranous part of the interventricular spectrum, which is generated from the endocardial cushion.

DEVELOPMENT OF INTERVENTRICULAR SEPTUM

The muscular interventricular (IV) septum which has developed from the floor of the primitive atrium in the midline grows toward the fused AV cushions.
Until 7th week, there is the presence of a crescent-shaped interventricular foramen
between the free edge of the interventricular septum and the fused endocardial cushions.
The membranous IV septum closes the IV foramen.
This happens by the end of 7th week due to the fusion of bulbar ridges and the endocardial cushion.
The right bulbar ridge, the left bulbar ridge and the endocardial cushion
fuse to form membranous part of interventricular septum.
The membranous part of the interventricular septum is derived from an extension of tissue from the right side of the endocardial cushion to the muscular part of the septum as well as neural crest cells.

 

 

Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 194,197,199,200

questions.text: Which of the following layers has a large number of desmosomes?
questions.solution:
The given histopathology image is of skin.
Stratum spinosum or prickle cell layer contains abundant desmosomes marked with the legend 'C' in the image.

Picture shows following layers of epidermis:
A : Stratum corneum
B : Stratum granulosum
C : Stratum spinosum
D : Stratum basale

The stratum spinosum, also known as the prickle cell layer, is made up of several layers of densely packed keratinocytes that interdigitate with one another via a large number of cell surface projections. Desmosomes, which give the layer its tensile strength and cohesiveness, anchor the cells to one another. As additional cells are created in the basal layer, these suprabasal cells, which are dedicated to terminal differentiation, eventually ascend upward towards the cornified layer.

In pemphigus group of disorder antibodies are formed against desmosomes, that lead to destruction of cell to cell adhesion and formation of blisters in skin.

questions.text: Where does the peripheral processes of spiral ganglion end?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: C
The peripheral processes of the spiral ganglion end in the organ of Corti, which is a sensory organ located in the cochlea. The organ of Corti contains hair cells, which are the sensory cells that respond to sound. The peripheral processes of the spiral ganglion synapse with the hair cells, and this is how the auditory nerve transmits sound information to the brain.
Other options :  
Option A is the  basilar membrane, which is a structure that supports the organ of Corti. Option B is the outer hair cells Option D is the vestibular membrane

questions.text: What speech impairment results from damage to the area of the brain shown in the micrograph below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Sensory aphasia
 
  • Sensory aphasia (Wernicke's aphasia) is a type of aphasia that results from damage to the temporal lobe of the brain.
  • Damage to this area of the brain can disrupt the ability to understand language, both spoken and written.
  • People with sensory aphasia may have difficulty comprehending what others are saying, and they may also have difficulty finding the right words to express themselves.
  • The micrograph shows the temporal lobe of the brain, and the area that is damaged is Wernicke's area.

questions.text: Which tissue is represented by the following hematoxylin and eosin-stained biopsy?
questions.solution:
Tonsils are small mass of lymphatic tissue located in the wall of the pharynx at the rear of the throat of humans. The term is most commonly used to describe palatine tonsils.

Microscopically, the tonsil is a mass of lymphoid follicles supported on a connective tissue framework. In addition, the center of each of these nodules is densely packed with lymphocytes, and is referred to as the germinal center. 

The luminal surfaces of the tonsils are coated in non-keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.text: Name the cartilage shown in the image below .
questions.solution:
Elastic cartilage, also known as yellow fibrocartilage, is similar in many ways to hyaline cartilage. It contains a semi-rigid mesh of collagen fibres in its extracellular matrix and provides structure and flexibility to tissue. However, the collagen fibres in elastic cartilage are interwoven with numerous elastic fibres, forming a network. This elastic matrix gives elastic cartilage the capacity to bear tension and return to its original shape after being stretched or compressed. The elastic fibres are not visible in regular hematoxylin and eosin-stained sections, and require special staining techniques such as resorcin, fusion and orcein to make them visible.

Examples of elastic cartilage: - pinna, epiglottis.

questions.text:
Select the accurate statement regarding the image given below:


A: Preload                                            B:Afterload
questions.solution:
A - Preload B - Afterload. Preload and afterload are two conditions that affect the force production and work done by a muscle. Preload occurs when the muscle is passively stretched by the load in its relaxed state, leading to an increased overlap of thin and thick filaments in the sarcomere and increased active tension. Afterload occurs when the load acts only on the muscle while it is in active contraction and is supported during relaxed state. Work done is higher during afterload, as displacement is higher and the load is acting on the muscle more forcefully.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 535

questions.text:
The cell counts in various Neubauer's chamber squares after charging with 20 times diluted blood are shown in the following picture. What is the total number of leukocytes?


1. 6000/mm3
2. 2400/mm3
3.  3000/mm3
4. 14200/mm3
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 6000/mm3

The method used here is called Total leukocyte counting (TLC) Principle of the TLC method:
  1. Blood is diluted with a fluid that causes the RBCs’ hemolysis, but WBCs remain intact, and then these are counted in the Neubauer chamber.
  2. Gentian violet lightly stains the leucocytes and allows those to be counted.
          Each of the square has a dimension of 1mm x lmm. Depth is 0.1 mm.
          Volume of one square = (1 x 1 x 0.1) mm3 = 0.1 mm3
          Concentration of cells = n/V x d
          (n= No. of cells, V= Volume of distribution, d= Dilution)
          Cells counted in 4 corner squares = n = (25 + 35 + 40 + 20) = 120
          Total Volume of 4 squares = 4 x 0.1 = 0.4 mm3
          Dilution factor = 20
          WbC Count = 120/0.4 x 20 = 6000 cells/mm3


Reference- https://www.emsdiasum.com/docs/technical/datasheet/68052-14

Myoclonic Seizures:

Myoclonic seizures are short-lived, shock-like muscular contractions, and even when they are widespread, they don't cause any discernible impairments in consciousness. 

Myoclonic seizures mostly affect the shoulders, upper extremities, and face and can happen as separate episodes or in clusters, in which case they are typically not rhythmic.

questions.text: The chart below shows a patient's spirometry curve. Using the curve, calculate the FEV1/FVC ratio.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 80–89%

Here, we need to find FEV1 and FVC first.
FEV1 (forced expiratory volume in 1 second) is the maximum amount of air that the subject can forcibly expel during the first second following maximal inhalation.
  • In the given image the interval between the two dotted lines denotes FEV1
  • FEV1 = 5000-1800 = 3200 ml
  • FVC (Forced vital capacity); the total volume of air that can be exhaled during a maximal forced expiration effort. It is total lung capacity minus the residual volume.
  • FVC = 5000-1300 = 3700
Therefore FEV1/FVC = 3200/3700 = 0.86
So, 80-89% is the correct answer.

questions.text: Determine the ejection fraction using the volume pressure curve that is given.
questions.solution:
From the provided pressure-volume loop,
AB: Isovolumetric contraction from the provided pressure-volume loop
BC: Systolic contraction of the ventricles
CD:Isovolumetric relaxation
Hence,
130 mL is the End-Diastolic Volume (EDV) (Point a).
50 mL is the End Systolic Volume (ESV) (Point d)
Flow Volume (SV) 80 mL = EDV-ESV
Ejection Fraction = SV/EDV = 80/130 = 0.6, or 60% EF


Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition page no 121,122

questions.text: The inward flow pressure in the provided circuit is 100 mm Hg, while the outward flow pressure is 10 mm Hg. The resistance in each parallel circuit is 5 mm Hg/mL/min. How much current will flow via the circuit?
questions.solution:
In fluid mechanics,                                                                 
The hydraulic resistance, R is defined as the ratio of pressure drop, Pi- Po, to flow, Q. Pi is the pressure at inflow
Po is the pressure at outflow
Thus, R = (Pi -Po)/Q
Given each circuit has resistance = 5 mm Hg/mL/min.
Also for resistance in parallel
1/net resistance = 1/r1 + 1/r2 ………1/rn
Thus net resistance in the given question = 1 mm hg/ml min
Hence, by calculation for flow using ohms law, we get
Flow, Q = (100-90)/1 = 90 ml/min.


Reference: https://www.electronics-tutorials.ws/resistor/res_4.html

questions.text: What is the effect on end systolic volume (ESV) during exercise in physiological limits?
questions.solution:
Exercising leads to an increase in venous return to the heart, resulting in higher end-diastolic volume, but the greater contractility of the heart and elevated stroke volume offset this increase and cause the end-systolic volume to decrease.

 

Reference-: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page 308-309

questions.text:
What will be the sequence after the P wave

A. a wave
B. 1st heart sound
C. Filling of ventricles
D. T wave
questions.solution:
The correct sequence on cardiac cycle is  3. A -> C -> B - > D. 
Amongst given option correct answer would be a wave ->Ventricular filling ->1st heart sound ->T wave
 

  • A wave: After the P wave, the a wave on JVP occurs, which represents atrial contraction. This follows the depolarization of the atria (P wave), leading to the contraction of the atria and the push of blood into the ventricles.

  • Filling of ventricles: After the a wave, the ventricles fill with blood following the atrial contraction.(NOTE: 70% of ventricular filling is passive - only about 30% is due to atrial contraction)

  • 1st heart sound (S1): The first heart sound (S1) occurs when the AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) close, signaling the beginning of ventricular systole.

  • T wave: The T wave represents ventricular repolarization and occurs much later, after the ventricular contraction (systole) has finished.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 529,530

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the basal electrical rhythm of the intestines?
questions.solution:
Instead of the amplitude, the stimulus frequency determines the tone of the contraction.

The interstitial cells of Cajal present in the Aurbachs plexus produces slow waves, also known as Basal Electric Rhythm(BER) which is cyclical variations in Resting Membrane Potential varying between -40 to -60 mv. When a stimulus comes in the form of food, hormones etc BER + stimulus forms the Spike potential causing Ca ions to bind to calmodulin and causing muscle contraction + movement. 

Value of BER varies with site in the GIT.
Stomach 4/min
Duodenum 12/min
Ileum 9/min
Caecum  2/min
Colon and Rectum 4-6/min
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 486

questions.text: The graph that follows shows the maximum renal tubular transit for glucose excretion in a diabetic patient. In a patient with a blood sugar level of 200 mg/dL and a glomerular filtration rate of 90 mL/min, what will the urine glucose level be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  30 mg/min
 

We have to find the total amount of glucose excreated (urine glucose)

  • Excretion = Total filtered glucose – Total reabsorbed glucose

  • Total filtered glucose = GFR x plasma concentration

  • Total reabsorbed glucose = transport maximum

Urine glucose = (90 ml/min x 2mg/ml) – 150 mg/min

=180 mg/min – 150 mg/min

=30 mg/min


Reference:Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no 346

questions.text: Which part is responsible for the formation of the macula densa?
questions.solution:
Macula densa is a part of Distal tubule.

Macula densa cells are strategically positioned in the distal tubule (part of juxtaglomerular apparatus) with their apical membrane exposed to the tubular fluid, whereas their basilar aspects are in contact with cells of the mesangium and the afferent arteriole. They sense the Na+ concentration and take part in Tubulo-glomerular feedback.

questions.solution:
A = Polycationic
B = Neutral
C = Polyanionic

Since the Glomerular filtration membrane has a negative charge, it favors filtration of positively charged ions and inhibits the transport of anions. Therefore, A has the max filterability followed by B and C.

questions.text: Where in the tubule would a patient with severe central diabetes insipidus have the lowest tubular fluid osmolality?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: D
 
  • Vasopressin or Anti Diuretic Hormone is secreted by Hypothalamus and is stored in Posterior Pituitary.
  • It is released from Posterior Pituitary in response to increase in plasma osmolarity and decrease in blood volume.
  • It acts on V2 receptors present in the Principal cells of the Collecting Ducts which leads to increased insertion of Aquaporin receptors. This leads to water reabsorption

In Central diabetes Insipidus there is deficiency of Anti Diuretic Hormone. This decreases the water reabsorption in the collecting ducts, thereby decreasing the tubular fluid osmolarity in the collecting ducts.

questions.text: What vitamin is lacking if patient presents with the following?
questions.solution:
The image shows Casal necklace seen in Niacin deficieny. Vitamin B3 (also known as niacin or nicotinic acid) is an essential nutrient involved in hundreds of biochemical reactions in the body. Deficiency of this vitamin can lead to pellagra, a condition characterized by skin lesions, gastrointestinal disturbances, and mental disturbances. Symptoms of vitamin B3 deficiency can include inflamed and scaly skin in sun-exposed areas (pellagra rash), sore or inflamed tongue and mouth, mental confusion, diarrhea, headaches, anorexia and fatigue. Other possible signs of deficiency include poor circulation, depression, irritability, and a weakened immune system. If left untreated, severe deficiency can lead to seizures, coma, or even death.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 534.

questions.text: A middle-aged farmer produced maize primarily as a staple crop. He appears before the OPD as depicted in the picture. He also complains of having diarrhea. Which vitamin deficiency is evident?
questions.solution:
Diarrhea, dermatitis (lesions on the neck), and a maize-rich diet - all point towards Niacin deficiency (option 1) also known as Pellagra.
It is caused by a lack of dietary niacin or its precursor, the amino acid tryptophan. A maize (corn) diet is one possible cause of pellagra, due to its low tryptophan content and hence, low conversion to niacin in the body causing niacin deficiency and symptoms of Pellagra



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 528.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient who is bedridden is taking medication. The patient manifested the following skin lesion five days after beginning the medication, as indicated in the picture. It is because of-
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Deficiency of protein 'C'
 

  • Warfarin-induced skin necrosis is a rare but serious complication that can occur shortly after starting warfarin therapy. It is associated with a deficiency of protein C, an important natural anticoagulant protein.

    Mechanism of Warfarin-Induced Skin Necrosis:

  • Role of Protein C:

    • Protein C is a natural anticoagulant that inhibits clotting factors (especially factors V and VIII) in the coagulation cascade.
    • Warfarin initially inhibits the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (including factors II, VII, IX, X), which leads to a transient period of decreased anticoagulant proteins like protein C and protein S. This creates a temporary procoagulant state.

  • Timing and Pathophysiology:

    • Warfarin-induced skin necrosis typically occurs within the first few days to weeks of starting warfarin therapy, especially when it is initiated at higher doses without concurrent administration of heparin.
    • In individuals with an underlying deficiency of protein C (either inherited or acquired), this initial procoagulant effect can lead to microthrombi formation in small blood vessels, particularly in the skin.

  • Clinical Presentation:

    • Patients present with painful, erythematous plaques or patches that rapidly progress to areas of skin necrosis (blackening of the skin due to tissue death).
    • The most commonly affected areas include the breasts, thighs, abdomen, and buttocks.

  • Diagnosis and Management:

    • Diagnosis is clinical and based on the characteristic presentation of skin necrosis in a patient recently started on warfarin.
    • Management involves immediate cessation of warfarin therapy and administration of vitamin K to reverse its effects. Heparin or low-molecular-weight heparin may be used temporarily to bridge until vitamin K levels normalize.
    • Protein C concentrate or fresh frozen plasma (FFP) containing protein C can be administered to replace the deficient protein and restore anticoagulant balance.

  • Prevention:

    • To minimize the risk of warfarin-induced skin necrosis, especially in patients with known protein C deficiency, warfarin therapy should be initiated at lower doses and overlapped with heparin until adequate anticoagulation is achieved.

  • Long-Term Management:

    • Patients who experience warfarin-induced skin necrosis should be managed by a hematologist or thrombosis specialist. They may require alternative anticoagulation strategies, such as direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs), which do not affect protein C levels to the same extent.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page no 668.

questions.text: The results of the tests for proteins, sugar, and ketones are listed below. Which of the following will show up as positive in urine when someone is starving?
questions.solution:
Only 3 will be positive in cases of starvation.

Test 1 - Biuret test for proteins
Test 2 - Benedicts test for reducing sugars
Test 3 - Rothera’s test for ketone bodies.

Higher than normal quantities of ketone bodies present in the blood or urine constitutes hyperketonemia or ketonuria, respectively. The overall condition is called ketosis. The basic form of ketosis occurs in starvation. Ketone bodies will be positive in starvation in the patient's urine.


In **diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)**, both urine sugar and ketones are present, while in **starvation ketosis**, urine sugar is absent, but ketones are present.


Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 84.

  • It is further degraded to 5-OH indole acetic acid.
  • Synthesized in argentaffin cells in intestine, platelets and brain.

questions.text: Which is a deficiency amidst the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image is representative of the Casals necklace, which is seen in pellagra and denotes tryptophan deficiency.
Pellagra can occur due to:
Vitamin B3 (Niacin)- which is produced from tryptophan and requires vitamins B2 and B6 for its production, may contribute to pellagra.
Hartnups disease: Tryptophan malabsorption is caused by Hartnups disease, which is caused by a defect in the membrane transport of tryptophan across PCT and enterocytes. A tryptophan deficiency results from this.
Carcinoid syndrome: Increased serotonin production causes tryptophan to be diverted away from the NAD+ pathway.
Vitamin B6 deficiency: Niacin production is hampered in cases of vitamin B6 insufficiency due to deficient kynureninase.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews Biochemistry, 5th edition, Page no 380.

questions.text: A DNA's structure is displayed below. What ties two nitrogenous bases together?
questions.solution:
Nitrogenous bases are held together by hydrogen bonds.

Deoxyguanosine nucleotide and deoxycytidine nucleotide are joined by three hydrogen bonds created by hydrogen linked to electronegative N or O atoms, while the A-T pair is joined by two hydrogen links.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 397.

questions.text: What is the phenomenon shown below?
questions.solution:
Complementation is a process in genetics where two strains of an organism with different homozygous recessive mutations that produce the same mutant phenotype, such as a change in wing structure in flies, are mated or crossed and the offspring has a wild-type phenotype. The blue-white assay is a technique used to screen for and detect gene uptake during genetic engineering based on the principle of alpha-complementation of the beta-galactosidase gene. A defective galactosidase gene product activity is complemented by a similarly defective gene product from a plasmid, which together become active. This can be used to determine a successful gene uptake as it disrupts the plasmid gene product and complementation cannot occur, resulting in white colonies and an unsuccessful gene insertion will result in blue colonies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 445.

Seg 2- Doesn't need to be transcribed

There, the answer is promotor W and Y.

questions.text: What anomaly from the list below is present in the given karyotype?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option (4) Gynecomastia with long thin limbs
  • The given Karyotype shows two X chromosome and single Y chromosome (XXY) pointing towards Klinefelter's syndrome.
  • Klinefelter syndrome is  male hypogonadism that occurs when there are two or more X chromosomes and one or more Y chromosomes. It is the likely diagnosis (47, XXY) in the given karyotype
  • Clinical features of Klinefelter's include eunuchoid body habitus with abnormally long thin legs; small atrophic hyalinized testes often associated with a small penis; and lack of such secondary male characteristics as deep voice, beard, and male distribution of pubic hair. Gynecomastia may be present. (Hence - option 4 is correct)
  • CVS abnormalities include mitral valve prolapse and varicose veins. 
Other options
High pitched cry is seen in Cri-du-chat syndrome (del 5p) ; Round face with protruding tongue is seen in trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) and short stature with webbed neck is afeature of Turner's syndrome(45, X0)

questions.text: Which specific stain has been used in the liver biopsy shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Sweet's Reticulin Stain
 
  • Sweet's reticulin stain has been used in the liver biopsy.
  • Sweet's reticulin stain is a histochemical staining technique used to visualize the reticulin fibers in tissues, particularly in the liver.
  • It helps in assessing the architecture of liver tissue and detecting abnormalities such as fibrosis or cirrhosis.
  • The stain highlights the reticulin framework around hepatocytes and blood vessels, providing important information about the liver structure and any disruptions in the reticulin network.

questions.text: Identify the star marked structure in the illustration below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lipofuscin granules
 
  • The marked structure in the given image is the accumulation of lipofuscin granules in perinuclear location. 
  • Lipofuscin, sometimes referred to as lipochrome or "wear-and-tear pigment," is an insoluble pigment.
  • Lipofuscin is composed of polymers of lipids and phospholipids in complex with protein, suggesting that it is derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of intracellular membranes.

questions.text: The liver biopsy histology of a patient with hemochromatosis is provided below. Which stain from the list below was applied?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Prussian blue

* [Extra Edge]: Uses of Prussian blue stain
 
  • Hemochromatosis is a metabolic disorder which results in deposition of excess iron in the body in the form of hemosiderin. Tissues having iron deposition can then be stained with the help of Prussian Blue Stain. 
  • Intracellular ferritin is located in the cytosol and in lysosomes, in which partially degraded protein shells of ferritin aggregate into hemosiderin granules. Iron in hemosiderin is chemically reactive and turns blue-black when exposed to potassium ferrocyanide, which is the basis for the Prussian blue stain.


In Heriditary Haemochromatosis, the gene affected is HFE gene chromosome 6.
                                 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 655.

questions.text: A 12-year-old youngster suffered a cut on his forearm four days prior. Due to the creation of granulation tissue, the bleeding has now stopped. A portion of the granulation tissue was also included in the material when conducting a skin biopsy. Below is a diagram illustrating granulation tissue's histology. This granulation tissue contains what kind of collagen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Type 3
 
  • In the given image, we can see that the granulation tissue is 4 days old, which means that the matrix is still composed of type III collagen, fibrin, plasma fibronectin and other components.
  • This matrix is in the process of being replaced by a matrix predominantly composed of type I collagen. Eventually, this will convert into a pale, avascular scar, containing spindle-shaped fibroblasts, collagen fragments, and other ECM components.
* Timeline Of Wound Healing by Primary Intention:
 
  • Within 24 hours, neutrophils are seen at the incision margin, migrating toward the fibrin clot.
  • Within 24 to 48 hours, epithelial cells from both edges have begun to migrate and proliferate along the dermis yielding a thin but continuous epithelial layer that closes the wound.
  • By day 3, neutrophils have been largely replaced by macrophages, and granulation tissue progressively invades the incision space.
  • By day 5, neovascularization reaches its peak as granulation tissue fills the incisional space.
  • During the second week, there is continued collagen accumulation and fibroblast proliferation.
  • By the end of the first month, the scar comprises a cellular connective tissue largely devoid of inflammatory cells and covered by an essentially normal epidermis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 110.

questions.text: The image below shows cellular changes which happened to a patient who is 45 years old, chain smoker with control being normal epithelium and CS being post smoking. This image represents which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Metaplasia

  • Metaplasia is a condition in which a mature adult tissue type is replaced by a different kind of tissue.
  • The picture depicts a typical example of metaplasia where columnar epithelium (left) is replaced by squamous epithelium (right).
  • This metaplasia is usually caused by chronic exposure to a number of factors such as smoking or chronic bronchitis, presence of stones in biliary tract, salivary duct or pancreatic duct. It is also seen in conditions like Barrett’s esophagus and Myositis ossificans.
  • The pathogenesis of metaplasia is thought to be due to a reprogramming of stem cells in the tissue and can be reversed, although it can lead to malignant transformation of the metaplastic epithelium.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 61.

choices.text: Chronic venous congestion of Liver; dark area viable and grey area necrosed.
Chronic venous congestion of Liver; dark area necrosed and grey area viable.

questions.text: The sliced liver of a patient who passed away from heart failure is depicted in the following image. Which of the following statements is true based on the specimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Chronic venous congestion of Liver; dark area necrosed and grey area viable.
 
  • The given image in the question shows the nutmeg appearance of liver typically seen in chronic venous congestion of liver.
  • It is seen during right heart failure resulting in congestion of blood in the systemic organs. Because of chronic venous congestion, there is back pressure on the hepatic veins (central veins) resulting in necrosis of the central region which appears dark in color (centrilobular necrosis and periportal fibrosis). The periportal region remains viable and is grey in color.

Fig: Chronic Venous Congestion microscopic examination (nutmeg liver)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 517.

questions.text: patient came in with an intermittent fever, no weight loss, and no anorexia, but a retroperitoneal tumor. Results from the peripheral smear were normal. The mass is shown in both gross and microscopical form. What’s the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Castleman’s disease


*Clinical Features:

  1. B symptoms: fever, weight loss, night sweats, fatigue 

  2. Splenomegaly or Hepatomegaly

  3. Fluid accumulation (edema, anasarca, pleural effusion)

* [Extra Edge]: Castleman disease

  1. Castleman disease (CD) is a rare, nonclonal lymphoproliferative disorder having distinct subtypes depending on its etiology, pathology, and clinical presentation. It can affect lymph nodes of any body region, imitating both benign and malignant malformations, including the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis.

  2. The hyaline vascular type has an increased number of lymphoid follicles with a broad mantle zone and hypoplastic germinal center. Centrally placed germinal center is surrounded with small lymphocytes arranged in concentric circles, forming an "onion skin-like" structure. The center of these follicles is penetrated by hyalinized capillaries resembling a "lollipop" (also known as the lollipop sign).

  • Histopathologic screening of lymph nodes is done to assess a single node involvement (suggestive of UCD) or a multimode involvement (suggesting MCD) after excluding other infectious, malignant, and autoimmune disorders that exhibit their characteristic features in the lymph nodes. In addition, their characteristic lymph node features are also noted.

  • The lymph node size must be enlarged.

  • IL-6 has proven to be a specific biomarker for this disease, contributing to its pathogenesis, symptomatology, and histopathology. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 257.
Online Reference: Ehsan N, Zahra F. Castleman Disease. [Updated 2023 Apr 27]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK576394/

questions.text: Which of these is a condition depicted in flow cytometry?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hyper IgM syndrome
 
  • The given flow cytometric findings are suggestive of hyper IgM syndrome.
  • This is because B cells are positive for CD-19 on X-axis and negative for CD-40 on Y-axis when compared to normal individual.
  • Lack of CD-40 on the surface of B cells is the cause of hyper IgM syndrome.
  • In this disorder, affected patients have IgM antibodies but are deficient in IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies.
  • Mature B cells are present, but they are incapable of Ig class switching and affinity maturation, because of a defect in CD4+ helper T cells or an intrinsic B-cell defect.
  • Approximately 70% of individuals with hyper-IgM syndrome have the X-linked form of the disease, caused by mutations in the gene encoding CD40L located on Xq26 that interfere with CD4+ helper T cell function.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 244.

questions.text: Pick the diagnosis in the kid of A 5 years old child presented to the clinic with h/o of recurrent infections. O/e the child had rashes as shown below. Routine blood investigations revealed the patient had low platelets.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

  • Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome (WAS) is a rare X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the WAS Protein Gene.
  • The syndrome is characterized by recurrent infections, eczema, and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count).
     
  • Patients are also at risk for autoimmunity, allergies, and malignancy. WAS is usually diagnosed in infancy, but it can be diagnosed in later life in rare cases.
  • The diagnosis is made with the use of laboratory tests, physical exams, and examining family histories.
  • Treatment typically involves managing infection risk with antibiotics, managing eczema with topical steroids and other treatments, and managing thrombocytopenia with platelet transfusions and/or immunomodulatory medications. Bone marrow transplantation may also be an option for some patients.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 246.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient has swollen tonsils, a sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. The following image depicts the removed tonsil's histological features. What is the responsible organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) EBV
 
  • The histological features of swollen tonsils, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).
  • The image provided shows characteristic histological findings of infectious mononucleosis, including hyperplastic germinal centers, infiltrating lymphocytes, and reactive lymphoid follicles.
  • EBV is a member of the herpesvirus family and is transmitted through saliva, making it a common cause of infectious mononucleosis.
  • The virus infects B cells, leading to their proliferation and subsequent immune response, resulting in the clinical presentation observed in the patient.
* [Extra Edge]: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

  • EBV is a ubiquitous herpesvirus implicated in the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphomas, B-cell lymphomas in patients with T-cell immunosuppression (HIV infection, transplant recipients), and several other cancers.
  • The EBV genome harbors several genes encoding proteins that trigger B-cell signaling pathways; in concert, these signals are potent inducers of B-cell growth and transformation.
  • In the absence of T-cell immunity, EBV-infected B cells can rapidly “grow out” as aggressive B-cell tumors.
  • In the presence of normal T-cell immunity, a small fraction of infected patients develops EBV-positive B-cell tumors (Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma) or carcinomas (e.g., nasopharyngeal carcinoma).
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 357.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man who had acute, uncontrollable diarrhea presented. His kidney and bone marrow were sampled, as can be seen in the images below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Multiple myeloma 
 
  • The image shows: Cast Nephropathy in multiple myeloma. In the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts, casts are often present, characterized by their irregular, angulated, and geometric shapes with fracture planes, sometimes forming a jigsaw puzzle-like arrangement.
  • Occasionally, these casts exhibit a lamellated or crystalline appearance. They stain strongly eosinophilic on H&E, pale or weakly positive on PAS, and red-violet (metachromatic) on trichrome, reflecting their varying compositions of light chains and Tamm-Horsfall proteins. Casts are frequently lined with reactive tubular epithelium and can be associated with polymorphonuclear cells, syncytial giant cells, or granulomatous reactions. Some casts are congophilic, showing amyloidogenic activity, posing a risk for systemic amyloidosis. Additionally, proximal convoluted tubules may exhibit acute tubular injury.
  • Multiple myeloma is the most likely diagnosis. The images show plasma cells infiltrating the bone marrow and forming characteristic sheets or aggregates.
  • Multiple myeloma is a hematological malignancy characterized by the proliferation of abnormal plasma cells in the bone marrow.
  • The presence of these abnormal plasma cells, along with the clinical symptoms of acute diarrhea and renal damage, supports the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.
  • Further tests, such as serum and urine protein electrophoresis, can help confirm the presence of monoclonal immunoglobulins.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 607.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient who previously experienced tonsillitis and a high-grade fever two months ago now has cervical lymphadenopathy. a peripheral smear with a WBC value of 22 109 /L demonstrates lymphocytosis. The mono spot test came back empty. After a tonsillectomy, big cells intermingled with lymphocytes were discovered. The cells had CD20, EBV-LMP1, MUM1, and CD79a positivity. CD3-positive background cells were present. The cells do not express CD15. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) EBV-positive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

The image shows a malignant proliferation of cells. CD20/CD79a positivity points towards the B-cell origin of the neoplasm and EBV LMP1 positivity points towards an EBV-driven neoplasm.
Since CD 15 is negative - Classical Hodgkins Lymphoma is ruled out and negative mono-spot test rules out Infectious mononucleosis.
The likely diagnosis hence in this particular scenario is EBV-positive diffuse large B cell lymphoma. 
 


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 600.

questions.text:
Which of the following tubes contains sodium fluoride as an anticoagulant?
1. 
2. 
3.
4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Gray vacutainer

Gray vacutainer contains sodium fluoride and is used for glucose estimation because sodium fluoride inhibits glycolysis.

* [Extra Edge]: Color Coding of Vacutainers


Online Reference: Gupta S, Kaur H. Inhibition of Glycolysis for Glucose Estimation in Plasma: Recent Guidelines and their Implications. Indian J Clin Biochem. 2014 Apr;29(2):262-4. doi: 10.1007/s12291-013-0405-1. Epub 2013 Nov 22. PMID: 24757316; PMCID: PMC3990791.

choices.text: Hodgkin’s lymphoma; Epstein Barr Virus and Reed Sternberg cells
Hodgkin’s lymphoma; Epstein Barr Virus and Embryo cell
Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma; HIV and Giant B cell

questions.text:
For the past two years, a 12-year-old kid has had enlargement of bilateral cervical lymph nodes. A lymph node biopsy displays the image below.
Which of the following diagnoses, etiologies, and cells are correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hodgkin’s lymphoma, Epstein Barr Virus and Reed Sternberg cells

The histopathology displayed shows Reed-Sternberg cells typical of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
They are distinct neoplastic giant cells that stimulate reactive lymphocytes, histiocytes (macrophages), and granulocytes to assemble in large numbers.

* [Extra Edge]


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 611.

questions.text: What will a five-year-old patient with HbA2 3% and HbF 97% have on their peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 1, 2 and 3
 
  • Presence of 3% of HbA2 and 97% of HbF in a child is highly suggestive of thalassemia major.
  • In thalassemia major, nucleated RBCs with target cells, Howell-Jolly bodies and teardrop cells (Dacrocytes) are seen, which implies 1,2 and 3 as the correct option.
  • Blood smears show severe red cell abnormalities, including marked variation in size (anisocytosis) and shape (poikilocytosis), microcytosis, and hypochromia.
  • Target cells (so called because hemoglobin collects in the center of the cell), basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells also are common.
  • Inclusions of aggregated α chains are efficiently removed by the spleen and not easily seen.
  • The reticulocyte count is elevated but is lower than expected for the severity of anemia because of ineffective erythropoiesis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 645.

choices.text: Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia
Clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia
Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman reported having arthralgia, cyanosis of the nose, blue lips, and persistent weariness throughout the month of December. The image below depicts a peripheral blood smear. What is the most plausible reason for the observed findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia
 
  • The most likely cause is clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anaemia.
  • Spherocytes, which are only present in hereditary spherocytosis and autoimmune hemolytic anaemia, are clearly visible in the peripheral smear seen above.
  • The described history of wintertime cell lysis is typical of cold antibody type autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

*Mnemonic trick: -
IgG- G for garam(hot)- Warm agglutination
So, remaining cold agglutination is IgM mediated.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 649.

questions.text: Identify the cell which is raised markedly in worm infestations in the given Leishman’s stained blood smear.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) C
 
  • In cases of worm infestations, particularly helminthic infections, eosinophils are known to increase significantly in the blood smear.
  • Eosinophilia is a characteristic feature of parasitic infections and is often observed in response to the presence of worms or their larvae in the body.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 398.

questions.text: The following are detected using toluidine blue staining:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Mast cell
 
  • Toluidine blue is a stain that can differentiate basophils and mast cells based upon its chemical reaction with acid mucopolysaccharides present in the cell granules.
  • This form of staining, however, may not be effective when the level of acid mucopolysaccharides are low - as seen in malignant mast cells or basophils. To identify this type of cell more definitively, immunohistochemical markers, such as staining for mast cell tryptase, can be used in replacement of toluidine blue staining.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 206.

questions.text: Deficiency of what led to this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Vit. B12 deficiency
 
  • Pernicious anemia (PA) is an autoimmune macrocytic anemia caused by a vitamin B12 deficiency due to a lack of intrinsic factor which is an important factor for the absorption of B12 in the small intestine.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms such as paresthesia, and a decreased Hemoglobin (Hb) value of 6gm% is a sign of anemia.
  • Characteristic features seen on a peripheral smear that occurs due to megaloblastic anemia can include macrocytes, and neutrophils with hyper segmented nuclei.
  • Endoscopy findings can reveal atrophy of gastric mucosa, which can result in decreased absorption of vitamin B12 due to a lack of intrinsic factor, and therefore lead to its deficiency.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 652.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with easy fatiguability, pallor, hyperpigmented knuckles, and white nails. The findings from her hand are displayed below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) B 12 deficiency

In the given scenario, the likely diagnosis is vitamin B12 deficiency. It is characterized by- 
1. Fatigability
2. Pallor
3. White nails
4. Hyper-pigmented knuckles

The first three signs describe an anemic picture, while the fourth one is specific for B12 deficiency.
Hyperpigmented knuckles are either due to increased levels of melanin or decreased levels of reduced glutathione which activates tyrosinase and thus leads to increased transfer to melanosomes. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 652.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy arrives at the emergency department complaining of neck swelling. Cervical lymphadenopathy was discovered during the examination. Following a lymph node biopsy, HPE revealed the image below. Identify the cancer and the characteristic feature.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hodgkin’s with R-S cells; EBV infection

  • The given image shows Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells) which are considered pathognomic/typical of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • They are distinct neoplastic giant cells (30-60 um in size) with abundant cytoplasm, 2 large nuclei, and 2 large inclusion like nucleoli giving an Owl Eye appearance that stimulate reactive lymphocytes, histiocytes (macrophages), and granulocytes to assemble in large numbers. Reed Sternberg cells in a background of inflammatory cells infiltrate are diagnostic of Hodgkin's Lymphoma.
  • Hodgkin's Lymphoma is typically associated with EBV infection.  


* [Extra Edge]: Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells)



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 611.

questions.text: A baby who was 14 months old and whose Hb level was 6.3 gm% received repeated blood transfusions during the previous nine months. Which of the following will be the best investigation for this patient's final diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Globin gene sequencing
