Decreased hemoglobin levels, multiple target cells on peripheral smear and history of multiple blood transfusions point towards thalassemia.
In cases of thalassemia definitive diagnosis is done though Globin gene sequencing.

Investigations for hemoglobin disorders include:
  • Screening by hemoglobin electrophoresis.
  • Investigation of choice is HPLC.
  • Definitive diagnosis though globin gene sequencing.
* [Extra Edge]:

  • HbH disease, which is usually due to compound heterozygosity for one chromosome with both α-globin genes deleted and one chromosome with only a single α-globin gene, is defined by the hematologic findings along with varying levels of reticulocytosis.
  • At birth, when hemoglobin is separated by HPLC, 20–30% Hb Bart’s is present; in adults, traces to 40% HbH are present along with residual Hb Bart’s in some cases.
  • HbH inclusions can be induced in some red cells after incubation and staining with brilliant cresyl blue.
  • Hemoglobin composition in Hb Bart’s hydrops fetalis is predominantly Hb Bart’s with some Hb Portland if the deletion removing α-globin genes preserves the ζ-globin gene.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 645.

questions.text:
Which is the most likely diagnosis for the given peripheral smear

 1. B 12 deficiency
 2. IDA
 3. HS
 4. MDS
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) B 12 deficiency
 
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils are seen in both Megaloblastic anemia due to B12 deficiency and in Myelodysplastic syndrome. But since vitamin deficiency is much more common it is the better answer.
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils refers to neutrophils with more than 5 nuclear lobules.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 654.

questions.text: The following diad is true regarding the given image and the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Bite cells: G6PD deficiency 
 
  • Bite cells and helmet cells are characteristic of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.
  • G6PD deficiency is an inherited enzymatic disorder that leads to red blood cell membrane damage and the formation of Heinz bodies.
  • Bite cells are formed when macrophages in the spleen remove the Heinz bodies from the red blood cells, leaving characteristic "bites" or notches.
  • Therefore, the correct match is Bite cells - G6PD deficiency.




Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 641.

questions.text: A patient has Pancytopenia and back pain. The accompanying image displays a bone marrow aspirate. The conclusion is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Multiple myeloma
 
  • Pancytopenia (reduction in red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets) along with back pain suggests a possible bone marrow disorder.
  • Bone marrow aspirate in multiple myeloma typically shows:
    • Increased plasma cells (abnormal, cancerous plasma cells).
    • Replacement of normal bone marrow elements by these abnormal plasma cells.
    • Rouleax formation (RBCs being stacked up).
  • Multiple myeloma is a malignant neoplasm of plasma cells, which can infiltrate the bone marrow and cause pancytopenia
  • Inclusions in Myeloma are - 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 608.

questions.text: During a football game, a 29-year-old male athlete passed away after abruptly collapsing. The following discovery was made during a gross inspection at the autopsy. His family had already had two deaths that were comparable. What is the most likely cause of his death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

The above clinical scenario is typical of HCM. The autopsy heart also shows hypertrophied myocardium

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)
  • 60-70% - familial
  • Autosomal dominant (most commonly-  alpha-myosin heavy-chain mutation)
  • May cause sudden death in athletes due to ventricular arrhythmia
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 572.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient complained of severe dyspnea. There was mitral stenosis with LA hypertrophy. Plants on the mitral valve, which was removed.
What does the image of HPE show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Aschoff nodule

The presented image displays a confined nodule of mixed mononuclear inflammatory cells with accompanying necrosis.
Large active macrophages inside the inflammation exhibit conspicuous nucleoli and chromatin that has been compressed into long, wavy ribbons (caterpillar cells). The results imply the existence of Aschoff's body.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: The heart of a patient after a myocardial infarction is shown below, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. What can you say regarding the infarction's age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 6 hours.

  • The myocardial biopsy is showing some coagulative necrosis along with wavy fibers with widened spaces between the dead fibers, which contain edema fluid and scattered neutrophils.
  • No dense neutrophilic infiltrate is seen. These are typical early changes after MI, seen within 6 hours of infarction.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 547.

questions.text: In a patient, commissures fuse together and there are vegetations on the mitral valve along the lines of closure. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Rheumatic endocarditis

The image is showing small vegetations in a row along the lines of closure of valves and commissural fusion can be seen. This is typically seen in Rheumatic Endocarditis.


Fig: Acute rheumatic mitral valvulitis


Fig: Various Types of vegetations

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient who had been experiencing exertional dyspnea for the previous month presented to the OPD. He had experienced significant mitral stenosis. A prosthetic valve was used to replace his sick valve. A biopsy was taken from the removed valve. Determine the disease implicated and the typical biopsy finding.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Aschoff nodules, Rheumatic Heart disease

  • The given clinical history is suggestive of rheumatic heart disease.
  • It is an immunologically mediated multi - system disease. It is caused due to type 2 hypersensitivity reaction which usually occurs 2-3 weeks after a Beta haemolytic Streptococcal infection. This is due to molecular mimicry of Streptococcal Antigen with glycoprotein in heart and joints. In chronic rheumatic fever, patient develops mitral stenosis. Diagnosis is by Revised Jones Criteria.
  • Aschoff Bodies (Pathognomic for RHD) consists of lymphocytes, plasma cells, giant cells, fibrinoid necrosis, collagen and cells with wavy, slender, ribbon - like nucleus (Caterpillar cells/Antischkow Cells)


Fig: Microscopic appearance of an Aschoff body

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text:
While running, one athlete fell and passed away instantly. The heart's autopsy region is shown.
Which of the following statements about the condition is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia
 
  • This is a case of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM). The most common cause of death is ventricular arrythmia.
  • Major clinical problems in HCM are atrial fibrillation, mural thrombus formation leading to embolization and possible stroke, intractable cardiac failure, ventricular arrhythmias, and, not infrequently, sudden death, especially with certain mutations.
  • Indeed, HCM is one of the most common causes of sudden, otherwise unexplained death in young athletes.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 573.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does the given graph most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 3) Interstitial lung disease
 
  • The compliance curve is shown by the pressure-volume loop above, and its decreased slope suggests decreased compliance.
  • Interstitial lung disease is a common example of a restrictive lung disease in which this is commonly observed. Increased compliance is a symptom of obstructive lung disease like emphysema.
   
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 688.

questions.text:
A patient who was depressed and had a history of the rapid onset of dyspnea arrived. An X-ray of the chest reveals bilateral diffuse infiltrates, with the right middle
and lower lobes being more heavily affected. Despite treatment, he was not able to be saved, and an autopsy revealed that his lungs looked grossly normal.
The following was revealed through histopathology: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia
 
  • The given histological slides depict a granuloma with multinucleated giant cells reacting to acellular debris that could be foreign matter that has been inhaled, similar to what is seen in vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia.
  • Depressed patient, history of rapid start of dyspnea, and chest X-ray revealing bilateral diffuse infiltrates with predominance of involvement of the middle and lower lobes suggest the diagnosis of aspiration pneumonia.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 711.

questions.text: 85-year-old man was involved in a car accident and visited the hospital. He sustained multiple lower-limb fractures, rib fractures, and lung contusions. He eventually passed away from his wounds. An autopsy lung biopsy revealed the following characteristics. What is the most probable reason for his demise?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Fat embolism

  • Fat embolism is the most probable reason for his demise.
  • The patient has a history of a traffic accident with a lower limb fracture, which results in fat embolism since lengthy bone fractures cause microscopic fat globules to leak.
  • The small pulmonary artery branch in this region of the lung has distinct, circular holes (fat globules) that are typical of a fat embolism.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 131.

questions.text: A patient presented with a 4 months’ history of cough with diarrheal episodes. Bronchoscopy revealed an intrabronchial polyp. Biopsy from the polyp showed atypical cells with microscopic necrosis and 5 mitotic figures per 10 high-power fields as shown below. Chromogranin staining was positive. What is the diagnosis and grade of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Atypical carcinoid grade 2

  • The patient has carcinoid syndrome, according to this clinical situation.
  • Chromogranin positivity supports the tumor's neuroendocrine origin. The difference between typical and atypical carcinoids is that typical carcinoids have less than two mitoses per ten high-power fields and do not exhibit necrosis, whereas atypical carcinoids have between two and ten mitoses per ten high-power fields and/or necrotic foci.
  • These have been categorized as grade 2 carcinoids.
  • As a result, the patient has a Grade 2 Atypical Carcinoid. Atypical carcinoids also show increased pleomorphism, have more prominent nucleoli, and are more likely to grow in a disorganized fashion and invade lymphatics.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 723.

questions.text: A middle-aged immunocompromised man arrived with a fever and shortness of breath. A middle lobe lesion with infiltration was seen on HRCT. The image displays a lung biopsy taken from the lesion. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) CMV pneumonia 
 
  • This diagnosis was suggested due to a middle-aged immunocompromised male presenting with a history of fever and breathlessness, and HRCT showing a middle lobe lesion with infiltration.
  • Analysis of the lung biopsy image revealed many cells with intranuclear inclusions, suggesting CMV pneumonia as the likely diagnosis.
  • In immunosuppressed individuals, such as transplant recipients and HIV-infected individuals, CMV infection can lead to severe, life-threatening problems, particularly of the lungs and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Pneumonia caused by CMV is characterized by an interstitial mononuclear infiltrate with foci of necrosis along with enlarged cells with intranuclear inclusions. This can result in acute respiratory distress syndrome.
  • The intestinal infection can lead to intestinal necrosis and ulceration which can cause pseudo membranes and debilitating diarrhea.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1139.

questions.text: A worker who had spent the previous 20 years working in a manufacturing suddenly had pleural thickening and fibrosis. The graphic below depicts the lesion's histopathology. Most likely medical condition is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Asbestosis 

The diagnosis of asbestosis is suggested due to the presence of pleural thickening, fibrosis, and asbestos bodies found on the image.
  • Asbestos bodies are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods with a translucent center which are formed when macrophages phagocytize asbestos fibers, and the iron is derived from phagocyte ferritin.
  • In addition, other inorganic particulates may become coated with similar iron-protein complexes which are known as ferruginous bodies. This diagnosis is further supported by the history of working in an asbestos factory for 20 years.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 695.

questions.text: What condition does the picture represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lobar Pneumonia
 
  • The image shows uniform involvement of whole lobe and therefore it is a case of lobar pneumonia.
  • Patchy consolidation of the lung is the dominant characteristic of bronchopneumonia, while consolidation of a large portion of a lobe or of an entire lobe defines lobar pneumonia.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 708.

questions.text: What condition does the picture represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Miliary tuberculosis
 
  • The picture represents miliary tuberculosis, which is characterized by widespread dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis throughout the body.
  • Miliary tuberculosis appears as numerous small, millet seed-like granulomas in various organs, including the lungs.
  • These granulomas consist of central caseous necrosis surrounded by epithelioid macrophages, multinucleated giant cells, and lymphocytes.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 373.

questions.text: A 30 years old woman with dyspnea, cough, sputum production and wheezing dies of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was a non-smoker and alcoholic. The lung autopsy is portrayed. Which of the following conditions was most likely associated with the woman's death
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2)   \(\alpha~\)-1 antitrypsin deficiency
 
  • The Gross specimen suggest emphysematous lungs, it is a chronic lung disease that results in damage to alveoli, the small air sacs in the lungs- pan acinar emphysema.
  • When damaged, alveoli lose their flexibility and cannot feed enough oxygen into the bloodstream.
  • Emphysema is typically caused by long-term exposure to cigarette smoke, as well as environmental pollutants like car exhaust. Alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) is a protein produced in the liver that helps protect the lungs from damage caused by inflammation.
  • Individuals with emphysema are often low on AAT, leaving their lungs and alveoli vulnerable to the effects of smoking, air pollutants, and other irritants. Though is can be present without active smoking also.
  • Without the protection of AAT, the lung tissue gradually becomes damaged and scarred, leading to difficulty breathing, coughing, and a decreased quality of life.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 679.

questions.text: The electron microscopic image of alveoli is given below. Which among the following marked structure is inflamed and swollen in COVID-19 ARDS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Endothelium
 
  • The endothelium of the alveoli is inflamed and swollen in COVID-19 ARDS.
  • Histopathological findings include diffuse alveolar damage, hyaline membrane formation, and inflammatory infiltrates.
  • The endothelial cells show signs of inflammation, such as cytoplasmic swelling and vacuolation.
  • The presence of viral particles within the endothelial cells and vascular endothelial damage contribute to vascular leakage and edema.
  • These histopathological changes lead to impaired gas exchange and respiratory failure in severe cases of COVID-19 ARDS.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2270.

questions.text: A 50-year-old industrial worker arrives at the OPD with a cough and dyspnea. Upon examination, it was discovered that he had lung fibrosis and pleural thickening. The lung biopsy resulted in the following discovery. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Asbestosis

  • The given clinical history is suggestive of Asbestosis. It is an occupational lung disease especially seen in shipping industry. Occurs because of chronic exposure to Asbestos. Patient complaints of cough, dyspnea.
  • It usually affects the lower lobes of lung and presents as —Pleural plaque (Most Common Lesion), Lung Cancer or malignant mesothelioma (Most specific finding of asbestosis, needs about 25 years of exposure). H&E demonstrates asbestos/ferruginous bodies (dumbbell shaped bodies)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 695.

choices.text: Nutmeg liver with dark areas of perivenular dead hepatocytes and gray areas of periportal viable hepatocytes
Nodular regenerative hyperplasia of liver induced due to OCPs
Nutmeg liver with pale areas of necrosis and dark congested areas of perivenular viable hepatocytes

questions.text: The following findings are revealed by a liver biopsy. What is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Nutmeg liver with dark areas of perivenular dead hepatocytes and gray areas of periportal viable hepatocytes
 
  • This iconic image of Nutmeg liver shows the liver with chronic passive venous congestion. Necrotic hepatocytes make up the dark, crowded spots, whereas viable hepatocytes are present in the paler, brownish-looking areas around them.
  • In chronic passive hepatic congestion, the centrilobular regions are grossly red-brown and slightly depressed (because of cell death) and are accentuated against the surrounding zones of uncongested tan liver (nutmeg liver).
  • Microscopically, there is centrilobular congestion and hemorrhage, hemosiderin-laden macrophages, and variable degrees of hepatocyte dropout and necrosis
To remember this, think the blood supply comes via portal vein and Hepatic artery from the portal triad towards the center of the lobule, so when there is stasis the first to be affected is the centrilobular area than the periportal area which is close to the vascularity. It is therefore - Periportal fibrosis and Centrilobular necrosis seen in CVC liver
                                        

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 533.

choices.text: H. pylori infection, Silver stain, Gram-negative coccobacilli

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient complains of heartburn. An upper GI endoscopy was done and a biopsy from a suspicious lesion showed the following picture.
What is the significance of this? What particular stains are you going to use for confirmation, and what are you looking for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Barrett’s esophagus, mucin stain, dysplasia
 
  • The histological picture of the esophagus shows intestinal-type epithelium with goblet cells, characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.
  • Mucin stain helps to better define the extent of dysplasia and rule out malignant transformation.
  • Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.
  • Non-goblet columnar cells, such as gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present, but there is not universal agreement as to whether they are sufficient for the diagnosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman complained of recurring bloody diarrhea. Multiple geographic ulcers are seen during colonoscopy, as seen in the histological analysis below.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Crohn’s disease

  • The histology of what appears to be a geographical ulcer is indicating a transmural inflammation, meaning it extends through the lamina propria and the muscle layer.
  • A non-caseating granuloma too is seen. Therefore, Crohn's disease is the most likely diagnosis.
  • In contrast, amoebic colitis yields a flask-shaped ulcer and pseudomembranous colitis have ischemic cryptitis and pseudo membrane on histology.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 800.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient was admitted with dysphagia. What is the result of the upper GI biopsy of the esophagus indicated in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Barrett’s esophagus
 
  • The result of the upper GI biopsy of the esophagus indicated in the image is consistent with Barrett's esophagus.
  • Barrett's esophagus is a condition characterized by the replacement of the normal squamous epithelium of the lower esophagus with specialized intestinal-type columnar epithelium (intestinal metaplasia).
  • It is commonly associated with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is a premalignant condition for the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient comes in with fever, diarrhea, and intense abdominal pain that lasts for six hours. As seen, an erect abdominal X-ray was taken. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Toxic megacolon
 
  • The most probable diagnosis for the patient with fever, diarrhea, and intense abdominal pain seen in the erect abdominal X-ray is toxic megacolon.
  • Toxic megacolon is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by severe inflammation and dilation of the colon, usually due to severe infection or inflammatory bowel disease.
  • It can present with symptoms such as abdominal pain, fever, diarrhea, and signs of systemic toxicity.

Crohn’s vs ulcerative colitis:


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2475.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old patient was diagnosed with intussusception, which required surgery and the removal of a section of his intestine that had several polyps.
Pathology was visible using microscopy as follows: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hamartomatous polyps 
 
  • The histology shows a sizable, large, pedunculated polyp with a distinct lobulated shape.
  • Well-developed smooth muscle and an arborizing network of connective tissue are seen to extend into the polyp, and it's surrounded by normal intestinal epithelium rich in goblet cells.
  • This is typical of PJ syndrome (Peutz-Jegher syndrome) which has hamartomatous polyps. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 808.

questions.text:
An endoscopic image of an esophageal lesion is shown below.



What is the expected histopathology finding?


1. 



2. 




3. 




4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Barrett's esophagus
 
  • The given endoscopic image is of Barrett's esophagus, the pale region signifies squamous epithelium of esophagus and the reddish region signifies columnar region.
  • The histopathologic image of option 3 shows the squamous to columnar metaplasia seen in Barrett's esophagus.
  • Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.
  • Non-goblet columnar cells, such as gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present, but there is not universal agreement as to whether they are sufficient for the diagnosis
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text: A child, of age 5 diagnosed with anal polyp. The most Histopathological image is given below. What diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Juvenile Polyp

  • Juvenile polyps are a common type of polyp that occurs mostly in children and adolescents.
  • Diagnosis is usually made after a colonoscopy. During the colonoscopy, the doctor will take a small sample of the polyp and examine it under a microscope to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Other tests can also be used to diagnose juvenile polyps, including imaging tests, such as X-rays or CT scans, to get a better look at the inside of the colon.
  • Finally, a colon biopsy may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and to differentiate between benign and malignant polyps. Microscopy reveals dilated glands filled with mucin, inflammatory debris.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 808.

questions.text: The absence of marked Cells will present with all except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Zollinger Ellison syndrome

The marked structures are Parietal Cells which secrete HCl and Castle's intrinsic factor.

Within the stomach, the most remarkable feature is a marked increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia. Gastrin also induces hyperplasia of mucous neck and endocrine cells within oxyntic mucosa.
In case of Zollinger Ellison syndrome, there is massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

* They are absent in:
  • Vit B12 deficiency
  • Intrinsic factor deficiency
  • Type 1 gastric carcinoid syndrome

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 773.

questions.text: An older male patient complained of eyesight blurriness. Cotton wool patches were seen on the retina during a fundus examination, and a systemic test revealed diminished peripheral sensations and decreased urine production. What result did the subsequent kidney biopsy reveal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesion.

Above clinical scenario is Common finding in case of Diabetic Retinopathy with Cotton wool spot with involvement of kidney microvasculature. 

  • In view of Diabetic nephropathy these 3 lesions are encountered: (1) glomerular lesions; (2) renal vascular lesions, principally arteriolosclerosis; and (3) pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis.
  • The most important glomerular lesions are capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and nodular glomerulosclerosis.

* [Extra Edge]: Nodular Glomerulosclerosis or Kimmelstiel-Wilson Disease

  • In this disease the glomerular lesions take the form of ovoid or spherical, often laminated, PAS-positive nodules of matrix situated in the periphery of the glomerulus.
  • They lie within the mesangial core of the glomerular lobules and may be surrounded by patent peripheral capillary loops or loops that are markedly dilated.
  • The nodules often show features of mesangiolysis, defined by disruption of anchoring interactions between the capillaries and the mesangial stalks. The loss of these support structures may lead to the formation of capillary microaneurysms.
     
* Audio Explanation:
 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1111.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man who had been experiencing 4 days of frothy urine arrived with facial puffiness. There may have been an acute renal damage. Direct immunofluorescence and electron microscopy images from a kidney biopsy are presented below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Membranous glomerulopathy
 
  • Membranous glomerulopathy is the most likely diagnosis. The images show immune complex deposits along the glomerular basement membrane, which is characteristic of membranous glomerulopathy.
  • Membranous glomerulopathy is an autoimmune kidney disease where the immune system mistakenly attacks and damages the glomerular basement membrane.
  • This leads to thickening of the membrane and impaired kidney function.
  • The presence of immune complex deposits can be confirmed through immunofluorescence staining.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text:
The image below shows the immunofluorescence staining pattern from a kidney sample taken from a 35-year-old patient who was experiencing proteinuria.
What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Lupus nephritis

The most probable diagnosis is of Lupus nephritis.
 
  • Strong IgA, IgM, and C3 staining may be seen in the picture, although IgG positive staining is lesser.
  • All kinds of glomerulonephritis present in SLE, as well as positive IgA, IgM, C3, and IgG, are frequently observed (lupus nephritis). IgG and C3 positivity is present in PSGN and Goodpasture syndrome; IgM and C3 positivity is seen in FSGS.
  • It is called full house effect. 
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: A patient who underwent a kidney transplant is suffering with decreased urine production. The microscopic image from a urinalysis is displayed below. Identify the structure that has an arrow on it:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hyaline casts

The structure marked in the above diagram is a Hyaline cast.

It appears to be a Waxy cast, but Hyaline cast is the best response because it develops from a hyaline cast.

* [Extra Edge]: Hyaline Casts

  • Normal: Up to 5 casts/low-power field
  • Associations: Normal finding in concentrated urine, fever, exercise, diuretics, pyelonephritis, chronic renal disease
Online Reference:
Queremel Milani DA, Jialal I. Urinalysis. [Updated 2023 May 1]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557685/

questions.text: A kidney specimen stained with FITC for IgG is shown below. What does this hint at?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Goodpasture’s syndrome

The immunofluorescence above is showing Linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane seen in  Goodpasture’s syndrome.

  • In Membranous glomerulonephritis , Granular IgG (Against GBM) deposits are seen.
  • In Buerger’s disease there is IgA deposition.
  • SLE may have a picture similar to Membranous Glomerulonephritis i.e. Granular IgG immune complexes deposits, but this is not characteristic.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: A kidney specimen that was removed is displayed below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Flea-bitten kidney of malignant hypertension
 
  • The image shows a kidney with multiple small hemorrhages, resembling a "flea-bitten" appearance.
  • This finding is characteristic of malignant hypertension, where severe hypertension causes damage to the renal blood vessels leading to hemorrhages.
* Other options:
 
  • Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis typically presents with glomerular changes such as glomerular hypercellularity and crescent formation, which are not observed in this image.
  • Chronic glomerulonephritis is characterized by chronic inflammation and fibrosis in the glomeruli, which is not seen in this image.
  • Amyloidosis would show amyloid deposits within the kidney, which are not evident in this image.

* [Extra Edge]: Nephritic syndromes


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2091.

questions.text: An unconscious patient with a history of not eating for more than two days is brought to the emergency room. Which of the following tests will be positive for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) only iii
 
  • In the given question, patient presents with history of starvation for more than 2 days which can result in production of ketone bodies.
  • Test for ketone bodies is Rothera’s test.
  • Positive test gives a purple ring. Positive in case of acetone and acetoacetate. Negative in case of Beta hydroxy Butyrate.

1st image - Benedict test - shows glucose in urine, which is absent in starvation, 2ns image - Heat and acetic acid test for proteins. 

Online Reference: Comstock JP, Garber AJ. Ketonuria. In: Walker HK, Hall WD, Hurst JW, editors. Clinical Methods: The History, Physical, and Laboratory Examinations. 3rd edition. Boston: Butterworths; 1990. Chapter 140. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK247/

questions.text: What is depicted in the below image concerning urinary crystals?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Struvite

The given image is of Struvite crystals (Coffin Lid shaped)
They are typically seen in UTI caused by urease-producing organisms (E.g. Proteus)

*[Extra Edge]:
  • Struvite stones, also known as infection stones or triple phosphate stones, form only when the upper urinary tract is infected with urease-producing bacteria such as Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella pneumoniae, or Providencia species.
  • Urease produced by these bacteria hydrolyzes urea and may elevate the urine pH to a supraphysiologic level (>8.0). Struvite stones may grow quickly and fill the renal pelvis (staghorn calculi).


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2373.

questions.text: Which urinary crystals are visible in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Calcium oxalate

Calcium oxalate crystals are shown (Envelop Shaped)



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2372.

questions.text: The following cannot cause the renal pathology is given in the figure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diabetes mellitus
 
  • Flea-bitten appearance of the kidney refers to multiple petechial hemorrhages on the renal surface.
  • Conditions associated with this pathology:
    • Hemolytic uremic syndrome: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury due to platelet aggregation and microthrombi formation in renal microvasculature.
    • Malignant hypertension: Severe hypertension leading to arteriolar damage and fibrinoid necrosis in renal arterioles.
    • Infective endocarditis: Infection of heart valves leading to embolic infarctions in the kidney.
  • Diabetes mellitus does not typically cause the flea-bitten appearance of the kidney.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 923.

questions.text:
An adnexal tumour is plaguing a 35-year-old woman. LDH was increased, CA199 was normal, CA125 was just slightly elevated. The gross and microscopic images of the tumour after it was removed are shown below. Which diagnosis is most likely?

1 .Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma
2. Dysgerminoma
3. Teratoma
4. Choriocarcinoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Dysgerminoma
 
  • LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) is an enzyme that can be elevated in certain tumors, including dysgerminoma.
  • CA-19-9 and CA-125 are tumor markers that are typically elevated in different types of ovarian tumors, but in this case, they are within the normal range or only slightly elevated, making dysgerminoma more likely.
  • Dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor that commonly occurs in young women and has specific histological features, as shown in the images.
* Tumor Markers:


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1024.

questions.text: What condition does the picture represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Seminoma

Gross morphology shows pale yellow color enlarged testis with no focal regions of hemorrhage or necrosis.
  • The picture shows a histological image of seminoma, a type of germ cell tumor of the testis.
  • Pathologically, it is characterized by uniform tumor cells with large round or polygonal shape, clear cytoplasm, and central prominent nucleoli.
* Other options:
  • Germ cell differentiate tumor is a broad term that encompasses various types of testicular tumors, including seminoma, embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor, teratoma, and choriocarcinoma.
  • Non-seminoma refers to testicular tumors that are not pure seminomas, usually comprising a mixture of different germ cell tumor types.
  • Teratoma is a type of germ cell tumor that contains differentiated tissues derived from multiple germ layers.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 970.

questions.text: The Pap smear of a 45-year-old woman with a left ovarian tumour in her late menstrual phase squamous cells is shown below. What is the tumor's most likely histology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Granulosa cell tumor
 
  • The image shows clusters of cells resembling granulosa cells (Carl Exner body), which are characteristic of a granulosa cell tumor of the ovary.
  • Serous papillary carcinoma typically shows papillary structures and atypical glandular cells. Mucinous adenocarcinoma would show mucin-producing glandular cells.
  • Dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor that typically occurs in younger women and is not consistent with the histology seen in the image.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1026.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman underwent right hemithyroidectomy due to what appears to be a long-standing nodule in the right lobe measuring 2 cm by 2 cm. Histopathological evidence points to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Papillary carcinoma
 

  • Nuclear clearing causing the Orphan Annie eye appearance in the histopathology image - empty-looking nuclei - this points towards Papillary Carcinoma. 
  • Its called Orphan Annie eye due to its resemblance to the eyes of an American comic character "Orhan Annie"


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1088.

questions.text: From the given options, which is the most likely diagnosis where X-ray shows a lytic lesion of the lower limb and the biopsy shows fibroblastic proliferation, osteoclast, and inflammatory cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) GCT
 
* Giant cell tumor (GCT)-
  • Another name for it is osteoclastoma.
  • Long bones' epiphyses are affected (MC-Distal femur).
  • The female to male ratio is 1.5 to 1.
  • The average age group is 35 years, and those over 20 years old account for 80% of cases.
  • Egg shell crackling when palpated; Jaffe's criterion is used to determine the Osteoclastoma's histological grade.
  • X-ray diagnosis: Soap bubble lesion.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1193.

questions.text: The image below shows a gross illustration of a bone tumor at the lower end of a femur in a 10-year-old child. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Osteosarcoma
 
  • Osteosarcoma is the diagnosis based on the clinical picture given.
  • Giant cell tumor only occurs after growth plate fusion, i.e. after 20-40 years.
  • Osteoblastoma is seen in the diaphyseal region.
  • Chondroblastoma is most commonly seen in elderly population.
  • Also, it is greyish/bluish in color.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1188.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman had her hip replaced. She ended up loosening after 9 years, necessitating the removal of the implant. Below is a picture of the lesion's histology. What is the most probable reason for this ailment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Metallosis
 
  • Most likely cause of this condition is metallosis.
  • It happens when metal pieces from hip implants or other joint replacement devices scrape against one another and release small amounts of metal into the surrounding tissues and blood.
  • Histopathology shows the presence of black pigment interspersed within extensive fibrosis.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 224.

questions.text: Identify the acessory protein indicated in the diagram below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alpha actinin

The star in image shows Z line. 

Z- line 
The Z line is mostly made up of alpha-actinin homodimers arranged in an antiparallel pattern,
which serves as a framework for the insertion of thin filaments made of actin, titin, and nebulin/nebulette.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1804.

questions.text: The microscopic appearance of schwannoma—a nerve sheath tumour most typically involving the cerebellopontine angle—is seen below. What does the region shown with arrow represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Antony A pattern

The microscopic appearance of schwannoma typically shows a pattern known as Antony A pattern. This pattern consists of spindle cells arranged in a palisading pattern with nuclear alignment.
Therefore, the correct answer is 2. Antony A pattern.

The hypercellular part - Antoni A containing Verouccay bodies
The hypocellular area - Antoni B


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: Investigation of a patient with bilateral proptosis determine the diagnosis using the region's biopsy that has been provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Schwannoma
 
  • The given histopathological slide along with clinical features goes in favor of schwannoma. 
  • Schwannomas often abut orbital apertures, and patients present with nonspecific symptoms such as progressive painless proptosis.
  • On histopathological examination, in the Antoni A pattern of growth, elongated cells with cytoplasmic processes are organized in fascicles in regions of moderate to high cellularity and substantial stromal matrix.
  • The "nuclear-free cones" of processes that lie in between the regions of nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies.
  • A loose meshwork of cells, microcysts, and myxoid stroma make up the Antoni B pattern of head and neck tumors, which are less densely cellular.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

choices.text: There is loss of function type of mutation
It is a trinucleotide expansion mutation related disorder
Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome

questions.text: Select the accurate option for Huntington 's Chorea.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) It is a trinucleotide expansion mutation related disorder
 
  • Huntington Disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant movement disorder caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat expansions in a gene located on 4p16.3, which encodes the protein huntington.
  • The number of repeats increases with each generation, causing an earlier onset in subsequent generations. Clinically, HD presents with a triad of motor, cognitive, and psychiatric symptoms, including involuntary jerky movements, dementia, behavioural changes, and an increased risk of suicide.
  • Pathologically, HD is characterized by atrophy of the caudate nucleus and putamen as well as the loss of neurons and the accumulation of intranuclear inclusions containing ubiquitin. It is most commonly transmitted from father to child.
Memorizing Trick: -
Hunter- CAGE
Huntington- CAG repeats
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1285.

questions.text: Which nerve is obstructed in the following picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Nasociliary nerve
 
* Nasociliary nerve block- Close to the ethmoidal foramen, the nasociliary nerve is blocked before it splits into nasal branches of the anterior ethmoidal nerve and the intratracheal nerve. 
  • Epinephrine-free solutions ought to be applied here to reduce the risk of retinal artery spasm. 
  • One centimeter above the medial canthus, halfway between the posterior palpebral fold and the eyebrow, a 15–30 mm, 25–27-gauge intradermal needle is inserted. 
  • After that, it is aimed medially and backward in order to make contact with the orbit's bony roof. 
  • After a negative aspiration test, a maximum of 2 mL of local anesthetic solution is slowly injected at a depth of 1.5 cm, at the anterior ethmoidal foramen. The external nasal nerve can be blocked by continuously injecting while removing the needle. 
  • The finger's compression of the inferior angle of the eye helps the solution diffuse into the foramen.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3438.

questions.text: The camera was mounted to the microscope to capture this image. What specifications does such a microscope need to meet?
questions.solution:
• The given picture shows a specimen viewed under a fluorescence microscope.
  • Parts of fluorescence microscopes - (1)Excitation filter (2)Dichroic mirror (also known as a dichroic beam splitter) (3)Mercury vapor lamp/xenon lamp.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 10.

questions.text: Which of the following designations best describes the microscope's condenser?
questions.solution:
For the given image, structure marked C corresponds to condenser.

   

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 10.

questions.text: Mention the fundamentals of the given test for HBV
questions.solution:
The immunochromatographic test for Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) is a diagnostic technique that utilizes a specialized cassette strip to detect the presence of three major antigens (HBsAg, HBAg and HBeAg) associated with HBV. The cassette contains a sample application pad, a conjugate pad, a nitrocellulose membrane, and a visible readout. The sample is first applied to the application pad and then transferred to the conjugate pad, which contains colored particles such as blue latex beads that are specifically bound to antibodies against the HBV antigens. When the sample is added to the conjugate pad, any HBV antigens present in the sample will bind to the antibodies in the conjugate pad, forming a visible cluster of colored particles. The sample is then transferred to the nitrocellulose membrane where the binded antigen-antibody complexes are able to migrate along the membrane. The membrane is then read visually. If a visible readout of the colored clusters appears then the test is considered positive and the patient is diagnosed as HBV positive.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 547.

choices.text: Routine microscopy with a negatively stained background

questions.text: A patient is suffering from Hepatorenal syndrome. The patient's urine was collected, and a sample of it was analyzed under a microscope. What approach is being utilized to make the organism visible, out of the following list?
questions.solution:
• The given image is of a Leptospira visualized using Dark Field Microscopy. 
  • Dark field microscopy is a microscopy technique that involves illuminating a specimen with oblique or off-axis light, resulting in a dark background surrounding the specimen. This technique allows for the observation of the motility of the thin, tightly-coiled, and flexible Leptospirae as they have a thin axial filament and delicate membrane which can appear only as a chain of minute cocci. It is the most specific and sensitive technique to visualize the organism when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present.
  • The Leptospira infection is suggested from the hook-like appearance of the spirochetes seen in the dark field microscopy image along with the clinical history with the patient having Hepatorenal syndrome.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 11.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old non-immunized child reported to the OPD with pseudomembrane over the tonsils. A sample of the throat was collected, stained, and inspected under a microscope. Choose the correct stains from the options provided.
(i) Albert stain 1
(ii) Albert stain 2
(iii) Iodine
(iv) Acetone
(v) Methylene blue
(vi) Safranin
(vii) Water
questions.solution:
The given image shows a microscopic image of a Coryenebacterium diptheriae (History of pseudomembrane/unvaccinated child points towards diphtheria) stained with Albert’s stain.

Albert’s Staining is a type of differential stain that stains metachromatic granules/volutin granules of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Albert stain is composed of two reagents— Albert stain 1 and 2 which are applied to slide respectively.

Albert Solution 1:

  • toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic acid, and alcohol

Albert solution 2:

  • Iodine and Potassium iodide in water


Albert's, Neisser's and ponder's stain are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules (Volutin/Babes Ernst granules) of corynebacterium diphtheria.

Among the given options, best answer is option (1).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 673.

questions.text: What is the name of the procedure whereby macrophages engulf various cells as seen in the picture?
questions.solution:
• Emperipolesis is the active engulfment of one cell by another, which remains intact. Seen in Rosai Dorfman disease.
  • In contrast to phagocytosis, where the engulfing cell is killed by the protective action of lysosomal enzymes, it exists momentarily within another cell and with an entire normal structure.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 840.

questions.text: What purpose does the technique shown in the image serve?
questions.solution:
The given diagram is known as the hybridoma technique for the development of monoclonal antibodies.

A mouse is given an antigen to which B cells in the spleen make antibodies.
These lymphocyte cells (seen as spleen cells in the diagram) are gathered and combined with myeloma cells to form hybridomas.
These hybridomas then divide and produce monoclonal antibodies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 150.

questions.text: Mention the class of antibody shown in the immunoglobulin structure.
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulin A (IgA) is a type of antibody found in the secretions of the body such as saliva, tears, respiratory and intestinal mucosal secretions. IgA is a dimer, consisting of two monomers joined together by a J-chain. There are two subclasses of IgA, IgA1, found predominately in serum, and IgA2, found predominantly in the body secretions. Due to its secretory component, IgA is effective at mediating local or mucosal immunity, meaning it can protect against infection on the mucosal surface like in the digestive or respiratory system. IgA is the most abundant antibody found in the human body and is therefore important in protecting against infections.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 99.

questions.text: Identify the conjugated antibody in the following figure:
questions.solution:
In the given figure, the antibody numbered 1 is the conjugate antibody.
 
The figure shows a molecular investigation technique which is used for the detection of the antibody marked 2. Since the antibody 1, is attached to the primary antibody (marked 2), it is known as the secondary or conjugated antibody with which a conjugated enzyme is attached. This conjugated enzyme is used to form an end product which can be easily detected. In this manner, the levels of Antibody 2 are measured indirectly.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 116.

questions.text: Which bacteria are seen in the next stained slide?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Nocardia asteroides

The image shows acid-fast bacteriae with fine, right-angled, branching filaments which is characteristic of Nocardia asteroides. They are seen as pink rods against a blue background.
Other options – Actinomyces israelii is not acid-fast. 
M. tuberculous and M. leprae are straight rods with the absence of branching.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 399.

questions.text: The image below shows a wet mount of a scraping taken from a young, sexually active female with a genital ulcer. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image showing Donovan bodies in Wright / Giemsa - stained impression. Smears indicate a diagnosis of donovanosis caused by klebsiella granulomatis. They appear as rounded coccobacilli within cystic spaces in large mononucleosis cells (called pund cells).
Klebseilla granulomatis shows bipolar condensation of chromatin giving a Safety pin appearance.
 
other options:-
(2) Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes gonococcal urethritis with purulent discharge
(3) Haemophilus ducreyi causes Chancroid - having painful soft ulcer which bleeds on touch and painful bubos.
(4) Gardnerella vaginalis causes vaginitis - no itching with white discharge of fishy smell. They show characteristic vaginal epithelial cells containing intracellular organisms called Clue cells.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 681.

questions.text: The nasal biopsy from a patient with a brain abscess revealed the following image. Name the organism observed and the stain applied.
questions.solution:
The image shows filamentous Gram-stained Nocardia.
They are also acid-fast and can be stained by the Modified Ziehl­ Neelsen technique. Nocardia asteroides is the most frequently found species infecting humans, and most cases occur as an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients.
Because it is acid-fast to some degree, it stains only weakly Gram-positive.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 399.

questions.text: An ulcer in the vaginal area was seen in a 24-year-old female patient. The following image was obtained from a cervical smear that had been Giemsa stained. Determine the responsible agent
questions.solution:
Coccobacilli seen in the above giemsa-stained specimen suggest a diagnosis of Granuloma Inguinale. Donovan bodies are seen intracellularly in mononuclear cells.
Granuloma lnguinale:
Donovanosis, also known as granuloma inguinale, is a long-lasting inflammatory condition brought on by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis, a tiny, encapsulated coccobacillus closely linked to the Klebsiella genus. The organism is sexually transmitted. Presents with the painless genital ulcer.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 404.

questions.text: Which organism can you identify from the image?
questions.solution:
The given illustration shows endoflagellum which is seen in Leptospira among the given options. 

Treponema, borrelia and leptospira are all spirochetes and they contain the typical endoflagellum (axial filament).

The flagella-like organelles in the periplasmic region enclosed by the outer membrane are known as endoflagella (axial filaments). At each end of the creature, the endoflagella start and wind around it, expanding to and overlapping at the middle.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 377.

questions.text: Identify the following organism from the given image?
questions.solution:
The picture displays colonies of pink bacilli against a blue background with acid-fast staining indicating that the organisms are acid fast.

Corynebacterium and Actinomyces are excluded because they are not acid fast.

Even though nocardia is acid fast, it appears as long, slender thread with branches.
Therefore, based on the aforementioned scenario, the culture is of mycobacterium and shows a large number of bacilli.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 13.

questions.text: Identify the bacteria seen in the following gram stained specimen.
questions.solution:
In the given image, Cocci are depicted in pink colour, suggesting they are gram -ve.

Only gram -ve cocci in the options : N. Gonorrhoeae

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae are lanceolate gram positive cocci in pairs.
  • Staphylococcus aureus are gram positive cocci found in grape-like clusters..
  • Haemophilus influenzae are gram negative bacilli or coccobacilli.
The given slide shows gram negative diplococci within the polymorphs, characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. It is non-sporulating, non-motile diplococcus that is aerobic but may grow anaerobically also. It is oxidase and catalase positive. It shows twitching motility. It is flagella independent form of bacteria translocation over moist surfaces that occurs by the extension and retraction of polar type 4 pili. These pili act as virulence factors by promoting attachment to host cells and inhibiting phagocytosis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 230.

questions.text: A patient with benign prostate enlargement was hospitalised for three weeks. He soon suffered what was likely a urinary tract infection related to his catheter. For culture, the catheter tip was submitted, and it was grown on blood agar. The blood agar has the following appearance after 24 hours. What is the UTI's most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
The given image of blood culture finding shows Bull's eye swarming pattern exhibited by Proteus.

Proteus species move very actively by means of peritrichous flagella, resulting in swarming on solid media. It can be suppressed by the addition of
•Phenylethyl alcohol
•Chloral hydrate
• Sulfonamides
•Sodium azide
•Boric acid
Increasing concentration of agar to 6%
Proteus species can cause urinary tract infection, and nosocomial infections such as hospital acquired pneumonia, surgical site infections, etc.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 288.

questions.text: Identify the organism seen in the silver impregnation micrograph below.
questions.solution:
The given image is a dark field microscopy image showing a spirochete with Hook-like appearance, suggesting Leptospira
  • Borrelia: Slender spirals measuring 0.2 µm in width and 5-15 µm in length
  • Treponema: Loose/Irregular Spirals
  • Ehrlichia:Tightly coiled, thin flexible spirochetes 5-15 µm long with very fine spirals 0.1-0.2 µm wide.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 378.

questions.text: The following is an image of a 23 year old female. Her blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg, and she also has stiff neck. A lumbar puncture showed 4200 cells per microlitre, a protein level of 198, and a glucose level of 21 mg/dL. Which of the following statements about the organism responsible for this ailment is true?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram negative diplococci.
Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial hemorrhages. some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse - Friderichsen syndrome.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 232.

questions.text: A 26 years old male presented with fever and headache for 3 days. His BP is 90/60 mm Hg and examination revealed the following rash on the legs. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The case provided is of pyogenic meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis (Meningococcus). Petechial or purpuric non-blanching rashes are commonly seen in patients with meningitis by this organism. It is a capsulated Gram negative diplococci and ferments glucose and maltose.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 232.

questions.text: Gram-stain most likely reveals the following organism:
questions.solution:
Purple paired cocci can be seen in this figure, which are apparantly Lanceolate. Hence, this is a Gram-positive cocci, likely to be Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 224.

questions.text: Pick the suggestive method to use on a brother of a 5 years old boy who had a sore throat for the last two days. He has a greyish-white pseudomembrane around his tonsils and diphtheria is suspected. The brother got the last booster 22 months back.
questions.solution:
All contacts of a diphtheria patient irrespective of whether they received their primary immunization or booster dose, Prophylaxis with oral erythromycin is required. Those whose primary course or booster dose was received more than two years ago should only receive a booster dose of diphtheria toxoid. Non-immunized close contacts should receive prophylactic penicillin or erythromycin and also receive 1000-2000 units of diphtheria antitoxin as well as active immunization against diphtheria. All contacts should be placed under medical surveillance and should be examined daily for at least a week after being exposed, and the bacteriological surveillance of those close contacts should be continued for several weeks doing weekly swabbing.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 245.

questions.text: A child develops septic shock following meningitis. On examination the child has a petechiae rash as shown in the figure. Which of the following is a gram negative diplococcus that can be the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Neisseria meningitidis is a type of bacteria that is responsible for many cases of meningitis and other serious infections. The bacteria is a capsulated, intracellular gram-negative diplococci, meaning that under a microscope it appears as two lenses in a half-moon shape and it is classified into thirteen different serogroups based on the capsular polysaccharide that coats the organism.
Humans are the only natural host for infection by this bacteria. Transmission is through inhalation of droplets.
Disease caused by Neisseria meningitidis can be diagnosed through Gram staining, culturing on selective media, serological testing, and molecular testing such as multiplex PCR.
Treatment of disease caused by Neisseria meningitidis can be done with antibiotics such as ceftriaxone and cefotaxime or penicillin, chemoprophylaxis with rifampicin and ciprotioxacin, and vaccine prophylaxis such as a polysaccharide vaccines. Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Escherichia coli are both gram-negative bacilli and Streptococcus pneumonia is a gram-positive diplococci.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 232.

questions.text: The image shows the gram stain of Urethral discharge in a man. Which of the following is not a property of the organism?
questions.solution:
Gram-negative diplococci, which are indicative of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, are visible in the polymorphs in the provided gram stain.
Neisseria is not always found inside cells; it can also exist extracellularly. Hence, it is facultative intracellular and not obligate intracellular.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 231.

questions.text: The following bacteria toxin act by -
questions.solution:
The organism in the provided image is Corynebacterium diphtheriae because of the gram-positive rods' club-shaped ends, beaded appearance, and Chinese-letter pattern of arrangement.
 
The diphtheria toxin acts by ADP-Ribosylation of elongation factor 2- eF2, thus inhibiting polypeptide chain and protein synthesis by inactivating the elongation factor 2 (EF-2).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 240.

questions.text: On the bacitracin sensitivity disc test, identify the organism:
questions.solution:
The results of the bacitracin sensitivity disk test are indicative of Streptococcus pyogenes, which generate large clear zones of B-hemolysis (approx 1 cm in diameter) surrounding colonies larger than 0.5 mm. S. pyogenes is also PYR-positive (hydrolytion of I-pyrrolidonyl-B-naphthylamide) and usually sensitive to bacitracin.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 217.

questions.text: Which organism is represented by the effacement and attachment of intestinal cells in the illustration below?
questions.solution:
Entero Pathogenic E. coli (EPEC) is an organism that demonstrates effacement and attachment of the intestinal cells, as seen in the image. The precise cause of diarrhea associated with EPEC is yet to be determined. These pathogens are not invasive and do not generate enterotoxins. EPEC adherence factor (EAF), a protein coded by a plasmid, has been linked to attachment in the case of infantile enteritis. The other mechanism by which EPEC attaches to the enterocyte membrane is through a chromosomally regulated locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE). This pathogenicity island, which houses a gene coding for the intimin protein, causes disruption of the intestinal brush borders and microvilli.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 285.

questions.text: The figure depicts Pathogenesis of which of the following
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin produced by Clostridium botulism. Clostridium botulism- gram-positive organism producing sub terminal, oval and bulging spores. The botulinum strains are categorized into 8 different types according to their toxin production- Types: A. B, Cl C2, D, E, F and G Acetylcholine (Ach) generation or release at the NM junction and synapses is blocked by proteolysis of the SNARE proteins by botulism toxin. The poison does not impact the central nervous system or cross through the blood-brain barrier. The SNARE proteins include syntaxin, SNAP 25, and synaptobrevin, also known as VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 265.

questions.text: The vector shown in the figure transmits which of the following?
questions.solution:
Orientia tsutsugamushi, which is transmitted by the Trombiculid mite is shown in the picture, is an obligate intracellular bacteria. In humans, it results in scrub typhus disease.

Hard ticks have a chitinous shield, or scutum, covering their dorsal surface. They have an anterior end with a head or capitulum that can be seen from above.

Hard ticks can spread illnesses such hemorrhagic fever, tick typhus, and viral encephalitis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 415.

questions.text:
The image below shows a CSF gram stain from a child who was admitted with meningitis-like symptoms.
Which of the following best describes the bacteria's characteristics?
questions.solution:
Optochin test: S. pneumoniae can be distinguished from streptococci by their 1/500,000 sensitivity to optochin (ethyl hydrocupreip).The catalase test is used to identify the catalase enzyme that is produced by different Mycobacteria.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 225.

questions.text: Identify the location of lipid A in the provided gram-negative bacterial cell wall.
questions.solution:
Gram negative bacteria has certain special structures in their cell wall when compared to gram positive bacteria. They are : Outer membrane , Periplasmic space and Endotoxin/LPS.
Lipid A is a part of the structure of endotoxin, embedded in outer membrane and has the actual endotoxic activity.
https://images.app.goo.gl/R5Ae6ij5uemqvqp4A Image for explanation.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 16.

questions.text: Which of the following causes the attachment effacement lesion depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
E.coli is a gram negative bacteria which is the most common facultative anaerobe present in human GIT.

EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli) is an example of diarrheogenic E. coli. It is the most common cause of infantile bacterial diarrhea. It consists of enterocyte effacement plasmid which causes attachment - effacement effect leading to secretory diarrhea.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 285.

questions.text: A young man with painful sores as seen in the picture arrives at the STD clinic. What is the most likely microscopic finding of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The microscopic finding of herpes genitalis is multinucleated giant cells.

Pund cells ae seen in Granuloma inguinale.

Henderson Peterson bodies seen in Molluscum contagiosum.

Halberstaedler prowazek bodies  seen in Trachoma

Herpes genitalis is caused by HSV 2 > 1.

Features:
i. Multiple painful vesicles or ulcers with painless lymphadenopathy. 
ii. Non-suppurative
iii. Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells with margination and moulding. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 475.

questions.text: A patient in his 30s shows in with urethral discharge. Below is a photo of a gram stain. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Neisseria gonorrhoea is the probable cause of urethral discharge with the given histology as intracytoplasmic diplococci could be seen.

N. Gonorrhea features- 

i. Gram-negative aerobic,
ii. non-sporulating, non-motile
iii. oxidase-positive cocci arranged typically in pairs (diplococci).
iv. Cultured in Stuart's transport medium, chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar, Thayer-Martin medium.
v. Disease acquired by sexual contact.

Drug of choice for treatment of gonococcal urethritis is combination of azithromycin and ceftriaxone. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 234.

questions.text: 70% of the patient's body had burned. A sample that was taken from the burn site was tested for the presence of an obligate aerobe, which is thought to be the likely culprit. What exactly is the microbe?
questions.solution:
In burn patient care settings, invasive burn wound sepsis caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a substantial concern.
Typically a low invasiveness and pathogenicity organism, PSEUDOMONAS AERUGINOSA (Bacillus pyocyaneus) is usually observed as a local dweller of burns, surgical sites, and the genitourinary tract. Yet, this gram-negative, motile rod can act as a potentially fatal infection when the right host conditions are present.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 320.

questions.text: A little boy complained of abdominal ache and bloody stools. Identify the culture medium for the causal organism in the provided image.
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture suggests the diagnosis if Shigellosis which can be confirmed by using Selenite F broth for culture.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 294.

questions.text: Identify the virus using the provided cycle?
questions.solution:
The given lifecycle is of HIV virus. It has ssRNA and undergoes reverse transcription as shown in the image. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 570.

questions.text: A patient with end-stage renal disease secondary to polycystic kidney disease underwent a living donor kidney transplant 4 months ago. The patient is on immunosuppressive therapy (tacrolimus and mycophenolate mofetil).The patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of fever, fatigue, and a sore throat for the past week. She also mentions a decrease in appetite and unintentional weight loss of about 5 pounds. On further examination , the patient's histopathological examination shows as given below. What is the most likely the root of this  infection?
questions.solution:
CMV is the most reasonable option out of the given choices considering that it is the most common type of infection in renal transplant recipients.
  • Prophylaxis against CMV infection is possible with ganciclovir, valganciclovir, or valacyclovir.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 480.

questions.text: Choose the creature according to its life cycle:
questions.solution:
The given  life cycle of Influenza A virus. It  is divided into four distinct stages:

1. Attachment: Also known as the adsorption phase, this is the stage in which the influenza virus attaches to a suitable host cell. This is done through the influenza virus surface glycoproteins, haemagglutinin and neuraminidase.

2. Penetration: The virus then penetrates the host cell membrane and begins to uncoat, releasing its genetic material inside the host cell.

3. Replication: The virus then begins to express its enzymes, allowing it to replicate within the host cell and create daughter virus particles.

4. Release: In the final stage, the viral particles will spread and infect new cells, allowing the virus to continue to spread and accelerate infection.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 503.

questions.text: Mention the diagnosis of an HIV positive patient with a CD4 count of 300 cells/cumm presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the figure. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen.
questions.solution:
The given image is of Oral Thrush(Candidiasis) which can be scrapped off and microscopy showing pseudohyphae confirms the diagnosis. HIV patients are at an increased risk of developing Candidiasis due to lower levels of CD4+ cells and/or antiretroviral therapy (ARV) treatments, which can lead to an overgrowth of the Candida fungus. The fungi can either cause infection when it enters through openings in the skin, or due to a weakened immune system, penetrate through mucosal surfaces and enter the bloodstream.

 

Signs of Candidiasis in HIV patients: The most common signs of Candidiasis in HIV patients are oral thrush (discolored patches in the mouth), as well as skin infections such as red/irritated rashes and itchy skin. In addition, HIV patients can experience persistent coughs, mucus production, and chest discomfort. Candidiasis can also lead to more severe issues such as meningitis and esophagitis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 616.

questions.text: A patient with measles has these clustered white lesions on the buccal mucosa (opposite to the upper first and second molars). These are known as?
Identify which virus has the lifecycle listed below.
questions.solution:
The given lifecycle is that of Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV). Steps of HSV replication cycle— 1. Binding to cell surface. 2. Entry after fusion of the membranes. 3. Capsid transport to the nucleus. 4. Transcription and translation. 5. Replication followed by capsid assembly. 6. Glycosylation 7. Glycoprotein export to the cell surface 8. Glycoprotein - containing plasma membrane endocytosis. 9. Envelopment : Glycoproteins within early endosomes fare with capsids in the cytoplasm. 10. Viral release.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 437.

questions.text: The graphic depicts the organism that causes microcephaly being transmitted through the placenta. Identify the most likely organism.
questions.solution:
The organism responsible for microcephaly here is Zika virus. Other infections in which microcephaly me be seen: i. Rubella ii. CMV iii. Toxoplasmosis iv. Varicella

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 661.

questions.text: The potential cause of transplacental transmission , contractures and connected to the shown image is
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Zika Virus

The image indicates microcephaly which is seen  in congenital infection of the zika virus among the given options. Along with this transplacental transmission , white matter calcifications and contractures are seen.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 661.

questions.text: The patient had vesicular sores over his chest that were localized to one area on one side and complained of pain in he same side. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Herpes zoster (shingles) arises due to the reactivation of Varicella Zoster virus infection within the dorsal root ganglion. It is characterised by a painful, unilateral vesicular eruption, usually in a dermatomal distribution.

Treatment : Amitryptilline, Pregabalin, Gabapentin.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 447.

questions.text: Multiple discharge-producing cervical sinuses are seen in a 35-year-old farmer man. Which one of these stains will help with the diagnosis? Normally, where does this organism colonise the body?"
questions.solution:
Audio explanation of the above.


  

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 398.

questions.text: A patient arrived with a headache, projectile vomiting, and altered sensorium. The parasite that caused the India ink staining was shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An India Ink-stained cryptococcus capsule is depicted in the diagram above. Both nigrosin and mucicar­mine are alternative staining techniques.
Cryptococcus neoformans:
Causes Cryptococcal cryptococcosis.
