Encapsulated.
Not dimorphic.
Found in soil, pigeon droppings
Acquired through inhalation with hematogenous dissemination to meninges.
Culture on sabouraud agar.
Stains with India Ink and mucicarmine.
Latex agglutination test detects polysaccharide capsular
antigen and is more specific.
'Soap bubble' lesions in the brain.
C. neoformans grows as yeast (unicellular) and replicates by budding.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 617.

questions.text: A child had scaly plaques on his head, itching, minor discharge, and hair loss. What investigation should be carried out next?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: KOH mount

Scaly plaques on the head along with itching, minor discharge and hair loss are indicative of dermatophytosis. The investigation of choice, in this case, is KOH mount.
Other options – Gram stain is used for bacteria.
Slit skin preparation is used for Hansen’s disease.
Tzanck smear is used for viral infections and the pemphigus group of diseases.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 600.

choices.text: It cannot be grown in Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA)

questions.text:
A known seropositive patient presented with complaints of severe intractable diarrhea. He received care using the medication trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His stool examination revealed Isospora Belli. 
The fever remained, but the diarrhea stopped. Examination of the bone marrow revealed the following image of an intracellular fungus:
Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this fungus?
questions.solution:
It cannot be grown in Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA) is a wrong statement for this fungus.

An HIV positive patient's presence of intracellular fungus on bone marrow examination (in tissues) is strongly predictive of disseminated histoplasmosis brought on by Histoplasma capsulatum. Specimens are cultivated on rich media, such as SDA (Sabouraud Dextrose Agar) or IMA Inhibitory Mold Agar) at 25–30°C, and on glucose–cysteine blood agar at 37°C.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 610.

questions.text: Identify the following organism from the given image?
questions.solution:
The given shows septate hyphae, with acute angle branching suggestive of Aspergillus.

Aspergillus hyphae are hyaline, narrow, and septate, with branching at 45° (acute angle branching).

So, it is Acute angle branching aspergillus.

Note- Mucor will show broad ribbon like aseptate hyphae with obtuse angle branching. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 613.

questions.text:
A female from Himachal Pradesh who had experienced thorn pricks a year prior presented with verrucous lesions in the skin and the microscopic
results listed below. Identify the agent.
questions.solution:
History of thorn prick and the image showing sclerotic bodies also known as medlar bodies or copper penny bodies; is highly suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

The methods of conidiation are used to distinguish the chromoblastomycosis agents.

In tissue, they resemble one another and produce muriform or sclerotic bodies, which are spherical brown cells (4–12 um in diameter) that divide by transverse septation. A cluster of four to eight cells could form as a result of delayed separation and septation in several planes.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 605.

questions.text: With a fever, neck ache, and vomiting, a 40-year-old HIV-positive patient was brought to the emergency room. He eventually passed away, and the micrograph and autopsy image of his brain are displayed here along with staining. Which pathogen is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Audio explanation for the above.

Given clinical features are suggestive of meningitis  in HIV pt. The organism responsible is cryptococcus.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 617.

questions.text: The pap smear below reveals an infestation by:
questions.solution:
The given pap smear shows Actinomycetes.Identified cytologically as ball-like clusters of bacteria, with radiating filaments. • ‘Cotton-ball’ clusters: Tangled clump of filamentous organisms, with acute angle branching • Radial distribution of filaments or irregular ‘wooly body’ appearance (also known as “Gupta bodies”) • Inflammatory perinuclear halo may be seen. • Masses of leukocytes adherent to micro-colonies of the organisms with swollen filaments or ‘clubs’ at the periphery.

Other options: -
1. Candida- will show ger tube formation
2. HSV- Multinucleated giant cells mainly in Tzanck smear
3. Trichomonas- pear shaped cells with lancet nucleus seen.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 400.

questions.text: After a dental procedure, a patient exhibits swelling and lump formation in the submandibular region. There are yellow particles in the discharge. Below is a picture of gram stain. What pathogen is to blame for this disease
questions.solution:
The condition is a chronic granulomatous infection that affects both humans and animals. The growth of indurated swellings, mostly in the connective tissue, suppuration, and the ejection of "sulphur granules" are its defining features. The granules are actually bacterial colonies, and they have the appearance of sun rays due to their thick network of thin, Gram-positive filaments and peripheral zone of inflated, radiating, club-shaped structures. It is thought that the "clubs" are antigen-antibody complexes. Characteristics of Actinomyces species identification: Bacilli that are gram-positive. Bacilli that are nonmotile, non sporing, and acid-fast. Create colonies with molar-tooth shapes. The direct fluorescent antibody test and the gel immunodiffusion test are used to identify species. Microaerophilic or anaerobic conditions are preferable for facultative anaerobe growth with the addition of 5-10% CO2.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 604.

choices.text: Dichotomous branching at an acute angle; Aspergillus

questions.text:
A persistent smoker who also has pneumonitis and hypertension visits the OPD
He has a persistent cough, and fungal hyphae are visible when examining sputum after staining.
Which branching pattern is present and likely fungus?
questions.solution:
1. Aspergillus infection is the cause of the patient's condition. 

Aspergillus infection is characterized by typical dichotomous branching at acute angles. 

Several clinical syndromes can be brought on by Aspergillus species: 

  • Aspergillus bronchopulmonary allergy 
  • Aspergilloma
  • Invasive aspergillosis 
  • External ear superficial infections (otomycosis)
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 613.

questions.text: A patient complained of having trouble swallowing. The diagnosis of esophageal candidiasis was made during a UGI endoscopy. The organism that was collected from the sample was cultivated on a specific medium, and the culture's microscope revealed the findings listed below. The phenomenon depicted below is what?
questions.solution:
After incubating colonies of Candida albicans or Candida dubliniensis in serum at 37°C for between 60 to 90 minutes, the image demonstrates the Reynolds-Braude phenomenon occurring in the form of germ tube formation. This is a rapid way of identifying C. albicans.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 617.

questions.text: Following a work-related prick injury, a rose gardener had the following alterations to their skin. What might be the causing factor?
questions.solution:
The given image is showing nodulo - ulcerative lesions along the lymphatics suggestive of sporotrichosis( Rose gardener’s disease) caused by Sporothrix Schenkii. Infection arises following traumatic implantation of the fungus (rose prick). H & E shows cigar shaped yeast arranged in structures called asteroid bodies. Culture reveals hyaline septate molds at 25°C - 28°C, dimorphism can be proved by yeast conversion test.

Treatment : Itraconazole.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 606.

questions.text: As seen in the figure below, a patient presents with linear lesions and subcutaneous lymphatic spread. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most probable diagnosis is sporotrichosis.

The image shown is of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. At the site of cutaneous inoculation, generally in the distal upper extremities, the main lesion manifests.
After a few weeks, fresh lesions start to develop along the lymphatic pathways, resulting in the linear lesions as seen in the image.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 606.

questions.text: To which helminth does the egg seen in the following fecal examination belong?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Ancylostoma duodenale

Features of the egg of Ancylostoma duodenale include oval in size, and space between ovum and eggshell. It contains 4-8 blastomeres which can be easily made out.
Other options- Enterobius vermicularis- colourless, plano-convex, tadpole-shaped embryo.
Ascaris lumbricoides- Mostly round, golden brown colour with a large unsegmented ovum at the centre.
Trichuris trichura- Barrel-shaped with mucus plug at both ends.



Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 189.

questions.text: Identify the protozoa whose cell division and life cycle are shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:  Entamoeba histolytica

Entaemoeba histolytica’s infective form is the quadrinucleated cyst which on ingestion undergoes excystation and releases four meta cystic trophozoites. They undergo multiplication and transform into uniucleated followed by a binucleated and ultimately quadrinucleated cyst.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 17.

questions.text: Determine the helminth life cycle from the illustration below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Fasciola hepatica

Metacercaria is the infective form of F. hepatica which develops into adult worms which lays unembryonated eggs that are released in the feces. This develops into miracidium and which forms two generations of redia which gets encysted to form metacercaria that is taken up by the definitive host.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 152.

choices.text: Ingestion of food contaminated with the egg of larva

questions.text: A patient's stool examination reveals the following finding. What is the most likely way for this parasite to infect you?
questions.solution:
The polar "plugs" at each end of the long, barrel-shaped eggs that characterize trichuris, which transmits trichuriasis by feco-oral transmission, are seen here.
The given image shows the egg of Trichuris. Its lifecycle involves infection after eating contaminated food with eggs.



Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 176.

questions.text: The genital ulcer was used to prepare a smear. Pick out the responsible organism.
questions.solution:
The above image is of trichomonas vaginalis.
Women who are infected typically have a translucent "halo" surrounding their superficial cell nucleus on a cervical smear.
It is unreliably detected by studying a genital discharge or with a cervical smear because of their low sensitivity.
A wet mount was previously used to diagnose T. vaginalis, and "corkscrew" motility was noted.

Currently, overnight cultures, which have a sensitivity range of 75–95 percent, are the most popular method of diagnosis. Even more sensitive techniques exist, but they are not commonly used.
Two examples are transcription-mediated amplification and fast antigen testing. PCR can be used to detect T. vaginalis if GENBANK/L23861-specific primers are used.
 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 37.

questions.text: Which of these helminths' body structure is shown in this schematic diagram?
questions.solution:
Audio explanation for the above.

Two nuclei at the tip are characteristic of Brugia Malayi's microfilarae.

Wuchheria - No nuclei at tip of tail

Loa Loa - Nuclei till tip are present. 

Onchocerca - No sheath

  
Mnemonic trick: -
Love full- Loa Loa many nuclei at tail tip
Wedding nil- Wuchheria no nuclei at tail tip
Left is Brugia so it has 2 nuclei at tail tip


Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 209.

questions.text: A patient complains of progressive dyspnea. Chest X-ray indicated a cavitary lesion in lower lobe of right lung. The excision of the cavity had the following histological appearance. What is the most likely source of this condition, and how many layers can be seen in the parasite's wall?
questions.solution:
The following histopathological image represents a typical Hydatid cyst, which is caused  by the dog tapeworm Echinococcus.The larvae settle inside the capillaries of the various organs and first trigger an inflammatory response made up primarily of mononuclear leukocytes and eosinophils. Many of these larvae are killed, but some encyst.
An inner, nucleated, germinative layer and an outer, opaque, non-nucleated layer surround an opalescent fluid.
The characteristic outer non-nucleated layer features numerous thin laminations that give the impression that it is formed of multiple layers of gelatin.


Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 130.

questions.text: This  blood smear indicates the presence of which species?
questions.solution:
The Plasmodium species shown in the image is Plasmodium falciparum, identifiable by the characteristic crescent/Banana-shaped gametocytes.

Other Plasmodium species, such as Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium ovale, or Plasmodium malariae, do not typically produce gametocytes with this distinct crescent shape. Instead, their gametocytes are usually round or oval.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 77.

questions.text: What is the name of the disease that this vector transmits?
questions.solution:
The image displayed is of a sandfly.
Primary vectors of Leishmaniasis are sandflies.
The definitive hosts are man, dog, and other mammals and the vector/intermediate host is female sandfly. Promastigotes are infective forms to man. The rapid dipstick test is the method of choice for the diagnosis of kala azar.
Audio explanation for the above.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 55.

questions.text:
A patient who is suffering from diarrhea  had kidney transplantation in the past. The figure provided information on the worms' motility. Which of the following is the correct statement regarding the organism?

a. Monoecious and the organism is related with parthenogenesis
b. Transmitted by intake of contaminated food and water
c. Loffler’s pneumonia is not caused by the same organism
d. Body gets this infection through filariform larvae
questions.solution:
Body gets this infection through filariform larvae.
 
  • Strongyloides stercoralis rhabditiform larvae are seen in the video. S. stercoralis is a parthenogenetic organism that is dioecious.
  • Infectious form is filariform larva (Eggs give rise to larvae and develop into filariform larvae) that penetrate the skin.
  • Loffler's pneumonia is caused by hookworms and Ascaris.
Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 181.

questions.text: A fecal smear revealed the following findings.Determine the organism's identity.
questions.solution:
The organism is Balantidium coli.

In the given illustration, cilia are present all around the trophozoite. Balantidium coli is the only ciliate known to infest humans.

It exists in two morphological forms-

1. Trophozoites- Oval and shape and contain two nuclei. Cilia covers the entire surface of the organism. It has a narrow anterior end and a broader posterior end. 

2. Cysts- Small and round with a micronucleus, a macronucleus and contractile vacuoles. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 107.

questions.text: Identify the organism based on the stool microscopy provided.
questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates quadrinucleated cyst of Giardia lamblia. 

The organism exists in Infective form which is the quadrinucleate cyst and tennis racket shaped trophozoite which is the motile form. 

Both cysts and trophozoites can be found in the feces. These cysts are hardy and resistant to chlorination. Infection occurs by ingestion of cysts in contaminated water food or hands/fomites. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 33.

questions.text: A 32-year-old slum resident who has lost 2 kg over the past two months, complains of constipation and diarrhea. The patient showed low skin turgor and a dry mouth upon inspection. The following microscopic appearance was discovered during an endoscopic biopsy of the gut. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
The given biopsy suggests Giardiasis

In the biopsy : Sickle-shaped trophozoites that are tightly linked to the villus surface of the intestinal epithelial cells by the concave attachment disc can be seen suggestive of Giardiasis.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 34.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has had chills and a fever for three days. Upon testing, it was discovered that he had dry oral mucosa and a delayed skin pinch time. The results of a peripheral blood smear were as follows. What pathogen is at play here?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation given in the case is consistent with Malaria.

The given image shows ring form parasite in normal sized RBCs as seen in case of Plasmodium falciparum infection.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 73.

choices.text: Embryonated egg is the infectious stage for this worm
The adult worm usually lives in the small intestine

questions.text: Here are some pictures of an intestinal nematode. Which of the following statements regarding it are accurate?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of Trichuris trichiura. Infectious stage of the worm is its embryonated egg.

It is transmitted through oral route. The adult lives within the large intestine and appendix.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 176.

questions.text: A 23 years old male presented with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea of one-week duration. The following colonoscopic biopsy is diagnostic of infection with:
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this case is amebiasis. It is one of the most common agents causing bloody diarrhea (dysentery) and enterocolitis. It is caused by entamoeba histolytica.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 19.

choices.text: a. Transmission is through ingestion of infected pork
Both adult and larval stages are seen in humans
The helminth causes a transient self-resolving infection in humans
Drug of choice for this condition is albendazole

questions.text: A helminth's ovum is shown below. What is accurate about the helminth?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Both adult and larval stages are seen in humans

In H. nana infection, eggs are the infective form which hatch out and develop into larvae in 4-5 days. Thereafter, in the gut lumen, they transform into adult worms in 10-12 days.
Other options- Transmission is through food and water contaminated with eggs and autoinfection.
The infection isn’t self-resolving as the worm burden keeps increasing in untreated cases.
Praziquantel 25 mg/kg is the drug of choice.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 137.

choices.text: Transmitted through contaminated food and water usually

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV-positive male patient complains of watery diarrhoea and odynophagia. An endoscopy was done which revealed esophageal and gastric candidiasis. The patient's stool was wet, and the results are shown below. What is accurate regarding this?
questions.solution:
• The given stool mount is showing severe infestation with Strongyloides rhabditiform larvae.
  • The infective stage is filariform larvae only.
  • It is usually transmitted through skin.
  • Infection occurs in immunocompromised patient.
  • Females show parthenogenesis in human intestine.
  • Drug of choice is ivermectin.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 182.

questions.text: Identify the organism responsible for the blood smear.
questions.solution:
The blood smear shows multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of malaria caused by plasmodium falciparum.
Falciparum malaria infects both young and mature erythrocytes. Binucleate rings( double chromatin) seen in RBCs are common and they resemble stereo headphones in appearance. Hypnozoites are not present in plasmodium falciparum infection.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 73.

questions.text: Which of the following is a carrier agent for the disease with the specified polarised microscopy characteristic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Ixodes scapularis ticks .
The smear shows Borrelia burgdoferi which is seen as irregular spirals on microscopy.
It is transmitted by Ixodes scapularis tick.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 86.

questions.text: A known HIV patient using anti-retroviral medication reported having diarrhoea for six months. Kinyoun stain was positive after stool microscopy revealed 10–30 micrometre cysts. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Cystoisospora (Isospora) belli is the causative agent of malabsorption, fever, and chronic diarrhoea in human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) patients. Infections are characterized by sudden fever, abdominal pain, and watery (non-bloody) diarrhoea that lasts for weeks or months in those with severe immunosuppression. Diagnosis is usually made through detection of the large (~25-um) oocysts in stool with Kinyoun stain and modified acid-fast staining.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 96.

questions.text: A child who had been experiencing stomach pain for 10 days visited OPD. The results of stool microscopy are displayed. What medication is recommended for the illness brought on by the specified organism
questions.solution:
Praziquantel is the medication used to treat Hymenolepis nana. This parasite is characterized by its egg shape, which consists of a thin colorless outer membrane, an inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere, and polar filaments and knobs along with yolk granules found between the two membranes. The infection is usually transient in humans and the eggs are non-bile stained and unable to survive for more than 10 days in the external environment. Treatment with praziquantel is necessary to eliminate the infection. In the given image egg shows polar filaments which differentiates it from the egg of H. diminuta.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 139.

questions.text: HIV is diagnosed in a 35-year-old heterosexual patient who complaints of watery diarrhoea. Colonoscopic biopsy is displayed as follows. What is your most likely diagnosis out of the following
questions.solution:
Cryptosporidiosis is a common opportunistic infection in people living with HIV/ AIDS, and is usually experienced as a diarrheal illness. Diagnosis of cryptosporidiosis in an HIV patient typically requires laboratory testing as the symptoms can be quite similar to other conditions. A stool sample is usually collected and tested for the presence of parasites. Microscopy can reveal the presence of the parasite in stool samples, while molecular diagnostic methods such as PCR or antigen testing can offer greater accuracy. If a patient presents with symptoms suggestive of cryptosporidiosis, a doctor may also order blood tests and other imaging tests to rule out other potentially more serious conditions.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 98.

questions.text: What is indicated by the life cycle of this image?
questions.solution:
1. LIFE CYCLE OF TOXOPLASMA GONDII


Tachyzoites are seen in peripheral blood smear and Bradyzoites seen in tissue biopsy are key to identify the organism as Toxoplasma in such questions.
Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 92.

questions.text: A individual with fever and myalgia reported seeing a cutaneous lesion with erythema and a black necrotic centre. All of the following have this trait, except for
questions.solution:
Important differential diagnoses of Eschar forming illness are:
Spider bite
Post-trauma
Spotted fever Rickettsiosis
Scrub typhus
Tularaemia
Anthrax
Disseminated fungal infection

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 530.

questions.text:
A piece of the colon with worms buried in the mucosa was removed during emergency surgery for intestinal blockage.
Which of the following statements about the pathogen is true?
questions.solution:
The parasite Ascaris lumbricoides is depicted. Esophageal distal end bulb is present. In cestodes, proglottids are observed.Trematodes exhibit hooks. In flatworms, flame cells can be seen.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 193.

questions.text:
A person who travels extensively arrived with an unidentified fever.
The image of a bone marrow aspirate is shown below. What will be the next step?
questions.solution: Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 246.

questions.text:
Match the following with the correct option.
 
(a) Hymenolepsis nana (i)
(b) Ascaris (ii)
(c) Hookworm (iii)
(d) Taenia (iv)
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii

Hymenolepsis nana- Oval in shape with the presence of six hooklets. It is non-bile stained.



Taenia- Spherical thin hyaline embryonic membrane with the fully developed hexacanth embryo at the centre.



Hookworm- oval in size, space between ovum and eggshell and the presence of 4-8 blastomeres.



Ascaris- Mostly round, golden brown colour with a large unsegmented ovum at the centre.




Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 137.

questions.text: Which parasite is depicted in this image?
questions.solution:
The parasite shown in figure is ascaris.

a) Male worm: Is smaller in size, measures 15-30 cm in length and 2-4 mm in thickness. Its posterior end is curved ventrally to form a hook and carries two copulatory spicules

b) Female worm- Is larger, measuring 20-40 cm in length and 3-6 mm in thickness. Its posterior extremity is straight and conical.



Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 201.

questions.text:
A patient who has been receiving long-term steroids for recurring eczema and chronic urticaria is now visiting the clinic with itching and nocturnal cough.
Alveolar lavage for bronchospasm revealed several tiny larvae. What is your medical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's use of steroids, according to the query, suggests that his immune system is impaired. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis, a serious infection caused by Strongyloides stercoralis, is known to occur in immunocompromised persons. The larvae of this creature are found in many bodily organs, which defines it.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 183.

questions.text: The condition in the liver according to the given image is caused by:
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is Symmers Pipe-Stem Fibrosis or Bilharzial Clay Pipe Stem Fibrosis which is a form of periportal hepatic fibrosis caused by Schistosoma Mansoni infection.
 
In the image we see a longitudinal section showing large areas of fibrosis around the vessels and bile ducts.
The fibrosis is the result of granulomatous inflammation in the portal tracts caused by Schistosoma Mansoni eggs.

 S. japonicum: Leads to Katayama fever, liver fibrosis, liver cirrhosis, liver portal hypertension, splenomegaly, and ascites. 

S. haematobium schistosomiasis : includes hematuria, scarring, calcification, squamous cell carcinoma, and occasional embolic egg granulomas in brain or spinal cord.

 Clonorchis : C sinensis can live for years within the biliary system of humans and result in various symptoms, including cholecystitis, cholangitis, and cholangiocarcinoma. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 148.

questions.text: To explore the effects of medicines on intestinal contractility, a guinea pig is dissected and a piece of its intestine is fixed in the modified Dales chamber. Following the addition of material X to the soup, the graph appears as shown. Which of these compounds is most similar to Substance X
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Epinephrine

After receiving drug X, contractility is shown to have decreased on this graph. When acetylcholine acts on M3 receptors, intestinal muscles become more contractile, but epinephrine inhibits contraction. Therefore, it is likely that substance X is epinephrine, a sympathomimetic medication.

In isolated preparations of gut, activation of both α and β receptors produces relaxation. In intact animals and man peristalsis is reduced and sphincters are constricted, but the effects are brief.

Epinephrine interaction with adrenoceptors G-protein mediated stimulation of cell membrane bound adenylyl cyclase increased intracellular cyclic 3',5'AMP cardiac stimulation, hepatic glycogenolysis, hyperglycemia and gut relaxation etc.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 144.

choices.text: Both A and B are having same potency
B and C have the same efficacy
A and C have same binding site

questions.text: Pick the statement that is true about the following dose response.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) C is a noncompetitive antagonist

C is a noncompetitive antagonist as it shows less efficacy than A and B.

 
* Efficacy is measured by the maximal height of the curve.

Order of Efficacy: A=B>C

* Potency is measured by the distance of the curve from the Y-axis.

Order of potency - A>B>C

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page No 64.

questions.text: Select the drug from the given graph which has the highest potency.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Drug A

The Dose Response Curve (DRC) on the X axis defines the potency of a drug. The further left the DRC is positioned on the X axis, the more potent the drug is. In the graph provided, the DRC of Drug A is to the far left, indicating that Drug A is the most potent of the three drugs. This means that the potency of Drug A is greater than B and C.

The position of DRC on the dose axis is the index of drug potency which refers to the amount of drug needed to produce a certain response. 
The upper limit of DRC is the index of drug efficacy and refers to the maximal response that can be elicited by the drug.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 64.

choices.text: Action of C is antagonized by muscarinic blockers

questions.text: Three medicines were the subject of a pharmacological experiment to determine how they affected blood pressure and heart rate. The graphs below were acquired before and after the medication was administered. Which of the subsequent claims is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is 2: B is epinephrine
 
  • At higher concentrations of adrenaline, alpha action predominates and hence a rise in BP is seen.
  • Therefore an increase in BP is seen with IV administration of adrenaline.
  • Due to rapid metabolism and uptake, the concentration of adrenaline decreases, and the β2 action predominates. Hence a decrease in BP is seen.
  • This is referred to as the biphasic reaction. 
* [Extra Edge]: Anti cholinergic drugs




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.

questions.text: A man arrives at the OPD with a history of falling. He is hypertensive with a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently taking captopril, atenolol, aspirin, and amiodarone. As indicated in the graphic, he offers the following findings. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Amiodarone induced skin lesion   

  • The given image shows a bluish discoloration of skin of face. It is a common side effect associated with long term use of Amiodarone.
  • Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation.
  • The skin deposits result in a photodermatitis and a gray-blue skin discoloration in sun-exposed areas, the malar regions.
Option 1 Lupus pernio is a characteristic sign present in chronic Sarcoidosis. Rashes involved Raised skin lesions not maculopapular rashes.
Option 2 Captopril Toxicity may lead to allergic maculopapular skin rashes, but the malar gray blue skin discoloration described in the image is characteristic of Amiodarone.
Option 4 Silver toxicity also known as Argyria is a condition where deposits of silver build up in your body at toxic levels. This causes your skin and nails to turn bluish gray, but the Clinical scenario given in the above question has nothing to do with silver toxicity.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 244.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who had Grave's disease was pregnant and receiving medication for hyperthyroidism. She gave birth to a child who has congenital anomaly aplasia cutis congenita. Which medication is most likely to be responsible for this teratogenic effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Carbimazole
 
  • Most likely drug implicated for this teratogenic effect is carbimazole.
  • Aplasia cutis congenita (ACC) following is seen following utero exposure to antithyroid drugs such as methimazole or carbimazole. 
  • Aplasia cutis congenita (ACC) or aplasia cutis is a rare skin defect characterized by either a focal or extensive absence of the epidermis, dermis, and in some cases the subcutaneous tissue.
  • It may be unifocal or multifocal and involve underlying bone, intracranial, or vascular structures. Although ACC may affect any part of the body, the scalp is most commonly affected.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 952.
Online Reference: P. Bowman, N.J. Osborne, R. Sturley, B. Vaidya, Carbimazole embryopathy: implications for the choice of antithyroid drugs in pregnancy, QJM: An International Journal of Medicine, Volume 105, Issue 2, February 2012, Pages 189–193, https://doi.org/10.1093/qjmed/hcq248

questions.text: What is the most common drawback of the given device?
questions.solution:
Correct Anwer is (Option 1) Drug deposited in the oropharynx
 
  • The given device is pMDI (Pressurised metered dose inhaler).
  • Most common drawback of pMDI is drug deposition in oropharynx.
  • Gas used is HFA (Hydroxyfluoro-alkaline gas which propels the drug out.
  • Another disadvantage is difficulty in coordinating press with inspiration.
  • Hence, cannot be used in small children without use of spacer. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 9.

questions.text:
Some gram-negative bacteria develop an enzyme that prevents beta lactam antibiotics from acting in the periplasm.
Which arrow in the Penicillin G structural diagram represents the site of action of this enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) B
 
  • Beta-lactam is an amide bond found in the structure of Penicillin G, as represented by 'B' above.
  • Beta-lactamases are the enzymes produced by some bacteria which provide resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics like penicillins, cephamycins, and carbapenems by breaking the antibiotics' structure. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 766.

questions.text: What medication, as depicted, works via the following mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Vancomycin

* Mechanisms of action and Resistance Factors:
  • By tightly adhering to the d-Ala-d-Ala terminus of developing peptidoglycan pentapeptide, vancomycin prevents the formation of cell walls. 
  • The peptidoglycan is weakened as a result of this inhibition of transglycosylase, which prevents further elongation and cross-linking of the peptidoglycan and makes the cell more vulnerable to lysis. 
  • Resistance to vancomycin in enterococci is caused by change of the d-Ala-d-Ala binding site of the peptidoglycan building block in which the terminal d-Ala is replaced by d-lactate.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 806.

questions.text: An antibiotic was prescribed for a patient who had a fever and a sore throat. Two days later, he appeared with the rash as seen in the picture. Which of the following substances could have caused this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Amoxicillin

Amoxicillin is the antibiotic (β-lactam) causing the presented rash.
Most common side effects of penicillins include allergic reactions in the form of-
  1. Anaphylactic shock
  2. Urticaria, fever, swelling of joints
  3. Skin rashes.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1154.

questions.text:
A patient's right upper limb has linear wheals in addition to having pain and edoema in the finger.
Which of the following antibiotics is best for treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Amoxiclav

The given clinical vignette describes skin and soft tissue infection characterized by linear wheals along with pain and oedema of finger for which Amoxiclav is the best drug.

AMOXYCLAV= AMOXICILLIN + CLAVULINIC ACID

Amoxicillin (penicillinase sensitive penicillin) destroys the bacteria and clavulanic acid being a Beta lactamase inhibitor prevents the destruction of Amoxicillin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 774.

questions.text: Identify the drug responsible for the side effect in the given picture:

questions.text: In which of the following condition is the drug in the picture used topically?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Subglottic stenosis

EXPLANATIONS:-
  • Subglottic stenosis is defined as the narrowing of the upper airway, which lies between the vocal folds and the lower border of the cricoid cartilage.  
  • CAUSES: -
    • Congenital
    • Trauma
    • Infection   
  • MANAGEMENT: - Mitomycin is the drug of choice in post Subglottic Stenosis operation to prevent regrowth of fibroblasts and prevents restenosis.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 927.

questions.text: The following patient was brought in for an autopsy. What is cause of discolouration in in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hematoma formation
 
  • Image given is mostly suggestive of hematoma formation. 
  • If the bleeding is small and thin-layered, it is called haemorrhage. If it is large and space- occupying, it is called haematoma.
  • The application of a moderate force to the head may cause a severe intracranial haemorrhage, while a greater force may not produce haemorrhage. Injuries to the meninges may cause extradural, subdural or subarachnoid haemorrhage.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 242.

questions.text: How old are the bones expected to be based on the wrist radiograph shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. <17.5 years
 
  • In the given X-ray, Pisiform has appeared, while the lower ends of Radius and Ulna (Wrist joint) have not fused yet.
  • That places the age to be >12 years but <18-19 (Boys) or< 16-18 (Girls). Deciding between <15 or< 17.5 years is not possible with the given data. (Heads of Metacarpals were not seen in the given X-rays). It is safer to go with< 17.5 years.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 73.

questions.text: Which system corresponds to the following representation of 32 teeth?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Universal system


Universal numbering system—The uppercase letters (A through T) are used for primary teeth and the numbers 1 - 32 are used for permanent teeth.

Teeth are numbered 1 to 16 from upper right to upper left, and 17 to 32 from lower left to lower right. This follows the plan advocated by the American and International Society of Forensic Odontology.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 96.

questions.text: The medial end of the clavicle and the body segment of the sternum are fused in the X-ray image presented. What is the likely age of the person
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. > 25yrs
  • Approximate age of the person with fused medial end of clavicle and body of sternum will be most likely > 25 years. Medial end of clavicle is completely fused by 21-22 years of age. Medial end of clavicle fuses with sternum at 22 years in males and 20 in females.
  • The sternum is formed by fusion of manubirum, 4 sternebrae and xiphoid process. The fusion of sternebrae occurs from below upwards followed by its fusion to xiphoid process and then fusion of manubrium to the fused sternum. 1st and 2nd sternebrae- 25 years 2nd and 3rd sternebrae- 20 years 3rd and 4th sternebrae- 15 years Xiphoid process with body- 40-45 years Manubrium with rest of sternum- 60 years.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 77.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl who was allegedly kidnapped insists that she is not a juvenile and left her home with the person on her own accord when questioned. Her age was determined by the court. The pelvic, wrist, and bilateral elbow X-rays are provided below. What age do you think she is, based on these?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. 21-22 years
 
  • The age in the images can be determined by the level of ossification of the elbow.
  • In the first, all the ossification centers have fused together, so this subject must be around 16 years or older.
  • In the second, the lower end of the radius and ulna have fused, meaning their age must be at least 18 years.
  • The third image has an ossification of the ischial tuberosity, indicating a subject likely between 20 and 22 years old age. Therefore, the accurate age range would be 21 to 22 years.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 80.

questions.text: Identify the postmortem finding in the image shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2. Suggillation
 
  • The image is suggestive of post-mortem hypostasis, which is also known as suggillation.
  • Postmortem hypostasis is the bluish-purple or purplish red coloring (caused by deoxyhemoglobin) that develops in the dependent parts of the body after death in the dermis's most superficial layers, Also known as livor mortis, suggillation, vibices, postmortem staining, subcutaneous hypostasis, and darkening of death.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 155.

questions.text: Which fracture is shown in the photograph below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Hinge

The fracture in the given image is hinge fracture, which is also known as motorcyclist fracture.
 
  • The most common fatal injury to motorcyclists is due to second impact with the ground.
  • A very severe blow to one side of the head results in fractures across the pituitary fossa's middle fossa's floor.
  • At autopsy, the so-called "motorcyclist fracture" can be detected, which is the base of the skull split into two pieces that move independently of one another like hinges.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 281.

questions.text: What kind of damage is present in the left anterior chest region of the patient in the following?

Laceration is a disruption of the continuity of tissue caused by a blunt force. Here the full thickness of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, muscle and/ or the internal organs can get involved.

In laceration margins are not smooth and tissue bridges present whereas in incised wound margins are smooth and tissue margins are absent.

The post-mortem, "boxer like" body posture of flexed elbows and knees and clenched fists, caused by the shrinkage of body tissue and muscles due to dehydration and coagulation of proteins caused by high temperature resulting in stiffening and shortening of muscles. It can be caused in both ante-mortem and post-mortem burns.

questions.text: A swollen face was observed in a patient with tongue swelling, and the results are displayed in the image. What is the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Putrefaction
 
  • Putrefaction is the process by which complex organic body tissue breaks down into simpler inorganic compounds or elements due to the action of saprophytic microorganisms or due to autolysis (without bacterial involvement).
  • The first external sign of putrefaction is a greenish discoloration in the right iliac fossa. Internally, the first site of discoloration is the aortic intima and then the underside of the liver.
  • Marbling, a linear branching pattern on the skin, is most commonly noted on the shoulder, root of the limbs, thighs, sides of the abdomen, chest and neck region.
  • Tongue and other organ protrusion occurs due to gas accumulation and organ enlargement.


Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 166.

questions.text: What does the image show?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Marbling
 
  • The given image shows the phenomenon of marbling. The blood in the arterial walls and surrounding tissues gives rise to a marbled look in the postmortem change depicted above.
  • During summer, the marbling of the skin becomes noticeable in the superficial veins of the belly, shoulders, chest, and inguinal area  ~ 36 to 48 hours after death.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 165.

questions.text: Identify the image given below:

The given image shows Marbling.
Marbling of Skin refers to the mosaic like pattern on the skin which is seen at vein coverage due to production of H2S gas by the bacteria which combines with Hb present in the blood to form a greenish blue compound called Sulf-met-hemoglobin. It is usually seen ~ 36 hours since death.

choices.text: Seen in all cases of lightning burns

  • Caused by the rupture of capillaries beneath the skin due to electrical discharge.

questions.text:
Match the columns given below:
 A  
C
1. Adipocere                                          3. Mummification
 B  D
2. Liver mortis 4. Marbling
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is 4. A - 4, B - 3, C - 2, D - 1
  • Adipocere: Adipocere appears chalky and greasy, and is light grey in color.
  • Postmortem Hypostasis: Postmortem hypostasis appears as a purplish-red discoloration of the skin and is usually found on the parts of the body that have come in contact with the ground.
  • Mummification: Mummification is a process of natural desiccation where the skin of the body is dried out and tightens on the body, giving it a leathery appearance.
  • Marbling of Skin After Death: Marbling of the skin after death is often caused by severe dehydration and exposure to extreme temperatures. It appears as a striking discoloration of the skin, with distinct lines and patterns that are reminiscent of marble.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 166.

questions.text: The type of skull fracture shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Linear fissured
 
  • The fracture shown in the image is a linear fracture since a thin line of fracture can be seen without any depression of the bone.
  • In a depressed fracture the skull bone is depressed at the site of the fracture.
  • In a comminuted fracture multiple fracture lines are seen radiating from a single point. It is caused due to multiple blows.
  • In diastatic or sutural fracture, the fracture line is along the skull sutures.
  • Ring fracture is seen in the base of the skull which can be caused due to falling from a height.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 244.

questions.text: Identify the type of post mortem finding shown in the given figure.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Post-mortem staining

The above image shows PM staining/Livor Mortis/Suggillation 

Mechanism: Blood in capillaries and venules pools into dependent parts due to gravity leading to bluish purple discoloration 



Option 1: The stiffening of muscles sometime after death due to ATP depletion is known as Rigor Mortis.

Option 2: After death, bacteria in the blood vessels produces H2S. This H2S combines with Hb to form sulph-haemoglobin which stains the blood vessel walls giving an appearance called Marbling.



Option 4: In warm, humid climate body fat hydrolyses into soapy waxy substance and gives off ammoniacal odour which is called Adipocere formation. This process may take weeks to months.

Abrasion

    • Pressure abrasion – perpendicular force eg. Shoe bite

    • Patterned abrasion – similar to imprint abrasion but showing the pattern of the weapon.

questions.text: An autopsy was done on a woman who had been brought dead to the hospital. No distinct indicators were noticed. Only the chin mark depicted below was visible upon exterior inspection; nevertheless, during inside inspection, the following appearance was discovered. What's the most likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Throttling.

The first image is showing multiple bruises resembling the pulp of fingertips.
The second image is showing collection of blood due to rupture of artery which will present in the form of contusion. These are features of manual Strangulation also known as Throttling.

Option 1: Closing of mouth and nostrils together is known as smothering. Frenulum tear, perioral injuries will be the classical features present.



Option 3: Suspension of the body by a ligature is known as hanging. Death occurs due to Asphyxia and cerebral venous congestion. 

Option 4: Transverse and below thyroid ligature mark will be present. Bruises can be present around ligature mark.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 353.

questions.text:
A woman's body was discovered in her bedroom. The door to the room was not closed. 350 mg/dL of alcohol in the blood was shown along with images of the face,
open neck, and viscera. A picture was provided showing cyanosed lips and probable six-penny bruises on the neck. Soft tissue ecchymosis was visible in the
dissected neck. What is the most likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
Presence of bruises in the neck,cyanosed lip and Dissected neck showing soft tissue ecchymosis is highly suggestive of throttling.
 
  • Throttling, also known as manual strangulation:
  • Throttling is the asphyxia that results from the compression of the neck by human hands. Carotid artery blockage is the cause of death. Occlusion of the airway has a small impact.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 353.

questions.text:
An autopsy was done on a woman who had been brought dead to the hospital. No distinct indicators were noticed. Only the chin mark depicted below was visible
upon exterior inspection; nevertheless, during inside inspection, the following appearance was discovered: What's the most likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
The case appears to be of Throttling.

External inspection reveals a single abrasion, most likely the result of the attacker's fingers grabbing the neck. Additionally, neck bruising was observed. Internal examination reveals injured neck tissues with haemorrhage from the strap muscles. All of these characteristics imply throttling. In the absence of a ligature mark, hanging can be ruled out. Strangulation by ligature cannot exist if there is no ligature mark.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 353.

questions.text: What is the most likely reason for death for a 22-year-old female with bleeding in her eyes and neck bruising?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of death, based on the facts in the inquiry and the provided photographs, could be throttling.

There will be ligature marks in the neck region in the event of hanging or ligature strangling. There is no ligature mark visible in this instance.

Hemorrhage in eyes are associated with cases of throttling and not drowning.

Manual Strangulation/Throttling: It is a type of strangulation where bare hands are used to compress the neck and strangulate. Cause of death is Asphyxia.

questions.text: Regarding the displayed image, all of the following claims are true except one:
questions.solution:
The image shows Deadly Nightshade or Atropa Belladonna
The berries of the belladonna plant (Atropa belladonna), from which atropine is derived, are sweet, despite being highly toxic. Hence options 4 is false.

Other options 

  • Causes blindness due to mydriasis (Option 1) – True
    Atropine blocks muscarinic receptors, leading to pupil dilation (mydriasis) and cycloplegia, which can cause temporary blurred vision and photophobia. In severe poisoning, this can contribute to functional blindness.

  • Contains atropine (Option 2) – True
    Atropa belladonna is a major natural source of atropine, which inhibits muscarinic receptors, leading to effects like tachycardia, dry mouth, urinary retention, and hallucinations.

  • Physostigmine is the antidote (Option 3) – True
    Physostigmine, a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, is used to counteract the anticholinergic toxicity by increasing acetylcholine levels and reversing central and peripheral effects of atropine poisoning.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 600.

  • The seeds of opium are white in color (option 1)
  • The seeds of Abrus precatorius have a characteristic scarlet color with a black spot. (option 3).
Reference: Ahmad A, Husain A, Mujeeb M, Khan SA, Najmi AK, Siddique NA, Damanhouri ZA, Anwar F. A review on therapeutic potential of Nigella sativa: A miracle herb. Asian Pac J Trop Biomed. 2013 May;3(5):337-52. doi: 10.1016/S2221-1691(13)60075-1. PMID: 23646296; PMCID: PMC3642442.

questions.text: A dead body has been brought in for post mortem investigation in a possible poisoning case. The provided image depicts the actual image of the deceased person. Probably poisoning is through -
questions.solution:
• Correct option is 3: Carbon monoxide.
  • The image shows cherry red discoloration which is seen in carbon monoxide poisoning.
  • PM lividity appears 30 mins after death, Visible by 4 hours and Fixation occurs by 6-12 hours. 


Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 624.

questions.text: Identify the lateral semicircular canal?
questions.solution:
Lateral semi-circular canal in the given picture is marked as ‘C’.

Structures Marked in the Diagram:
A : Incus
B : Posterior semicircular canal
C : Lateral semicircular canal
D : Superior semicircular canal

The vestibule is positioned anteriorly to the three semicircular canals: anterior (superior), posterior, and lateral (horizontal). Each one is squeezed from side to side until it is about two-thirds of a circle in size.
Except for where they bear an ampulla, which is about twice as wide as the canal, they are unequal in length but similar in diameter along their lengths.
 

Reference : https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Gross-anatomy-the-structures-exposed-following-a-classical-mastoidectomy-LSCC-lateral_fig4_373287463

questions.text: Below is an audiogram of a 30-year-old female. The most likely medical condition is:
questions.solution:
Carhart's notch with dip in Bone conduction at 2000Hz can be seen and Air and Bone conduction gap. Hence the audiogram is of Otosclerosis.

questions.text:
What is the encircled structure in the middle-ear cavity called ?


1`. Fossa incudis
2. Sinus tympani
3. Facial recess
4. Pyramidal fossa
questions.solution:
The sinus tympani (ST) is a critical anatomic region of the temporal bone. It lies medial to the facial nerve, between the ponticulus and the subiculum. This is the most common and constant depression present in the retrotympanic area. It is the most inaccessible site in the middle ear and mastoid. Cholesteatoma which has extended upto it is very difficult to eradicate.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 7

questions.text: A patient complained of diminished hearing in the right ear. Interpret the audiometric trace that follows:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Conductive hearing loss of right ear Conductive hearing loss of the right ear Increased air bone conduction gap confirms the conductive deafness. There is no Air bone conduction gap in sensorineural hearing loss.
 

  • This patient is showing improved hearing in left hear with constant difference in air and bone conduction,
  • I.e. decreased air conduction with normal bone conduction.
  • This is seen typically in conductive hearing loss.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 25

questions.text:
Which of the following hearing aids is used for bilateral canal atresia?

 
1. 2.
3. 4.
questions.solution:
In case of bilateral external auditory canal atresia, the device used is bone - anchored hearing aid. (BAHA)

Other indications for BAHA—

Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment. Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment. Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 137

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man who complained of bilateral hearing loss and sporadic episodes of dizziness was examined; his HPE is displayed below.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
VESTIBULAR SCHWANNOMA HPE:

  • Unencapsulated but otherwise resembles schwannomas at other locations
  • Interlacing fascicles of cells with indistinct cytoplasmic borders, elongated and twisted nuclei
  • Biphasic with Antoni A (cellular) and B (hypocellular, myxoid) patterns and Verocay bodies (whorling or palisading of nuclei)
  • Hyalinization of vessels
  • Commonly have regressive ("ancient") changes (cellular pleomorphism with hyperchromasia, cystic degeneration, necrosis, calcification, hemorrhage)
  • May be highly cellular (cellular schwannoma)

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 125

questions.text: What is the star-marked structure and what does the angle depict?
questions.solution:
The star-marked structure is Incus and the angle is the incudostapedial joint. 

 
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 6

questions.text: Which of the following structures, when viewed through the ear, produces the phenomena 'A' shown in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Handle of malleus

The centre of pars tensa is dented by handle of the malleus called umbo which creates a cone of light in antero inferior quadrant.
Stapes is not visible in a normal tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of nasal discharge, stuffiness, congestion, and anosmia. The woman also suffers from Asthma. The results of a para-nasal sinus CT scan are displayed below. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The correct option and the most likely diagnosis is option (3) Allergic Fungal Sinusitis (AFS).

This condition often affects individuals with asthma or a history of allergies. It is characterized by the presence of fungal material in the sinuses. The fungal elements can lead to chronic inflammation, and patients often present with nasal congestion, discharge, and anosmia, which matches the symptoms described.

On imaging, sinuses show complete opacification. Non contrast enhanced CT, the sinuses are opacified by centrally hyperdense material and have outer peripheral rim of hypodense mucosa. Thinning and sometimes erosion of sinus wall is also seen. 


Reference: P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 504

questions.text: Frontal sinus X-ray is being given. Which view is this?
questions.solution:
The view in the given X-ray for assessment of frontal sinus is Caldwell’s view aka occipitofrontal view. 

Rhese view is done to assess the optic foramen

Water’s view taken with  mouth open is Pierre’s view, used for sphenoid sinus visualization.

Water’s view is occipitomental view with mouth closed, used for visualization of maxillary sinus.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 493

questions.text: A patient is experiencing DNS. Identify the marked part:
questions.solution:
The marked structure is Inferior turbinate identified by the groove present below.

The smooth curvature of a deviated nasal septum serves as a good indicator of septum.

The middle turbinate, which emerges from the lateral wall, is seen above the inferior turbinate.


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 151

questions.text: This skull radiograph was taken to evaluate the frontal sinuses. What is the name of this view?
questions.solution:
The view in the given X-ray for assessment of frontal sinus is Caldwell’s view, occipitofrontal view for frontal sinus mainly

Rhese view is done to assess the optic foramen

Water’s view taken with the mouth open is Pierre’s view, used for sphenoid sinus visualization.

Water’s view is occipitomental view with mouth closed, used for maxillary sinus.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 493

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given NCCT scan
questions.solution:
The given images shows an NCCT of sinuses (coronal view) with the marker showing a pneumatised superior turbinate. Hallar cell is a anterior group ethmoidal air sinus present on the floor of the orbital cavity. Concha bullosa refers to a pneumatised middle turbinate. Onodi cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell and is closely related to optic nerve

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 153

questions.text: A 76-year-old female patient who complained of persistent nasal discharge and sporadic epistaxis was seen in the ENT OPD. Here are the results of her CT scan. Which diagnosis is conceivable?
questions.solution:
Based on the history given, the most likely diagnosis is an inverted papilloma.

It is the most common tumour of nasal cavity, caused by HPV and arising from lateral wall of nose.

Clinical symptoms of nasal discharge, epistaxis are present and there is no evidence of bony erosion or intracramial extension.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 228

questions.text: Find the marked structure in the illustration.
questions.solution:
1. The anterior section is visible because the maxillary sinus and orbit are visible, ruling out the superior orbital fissure and the optic canal. 

The anterior ethmoidal canal is the marked structure.


Reference : https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1808869415308399

questions.text: Find the marked structure in the illustration.
questions.solution:
1. The anterior section is visible because the maxillary sinus and orbit are visible, ruling out the superior orbital fissure and the optic canal. The anterior ethmoidal canal is the marked structure.
