questions.text: The cell depicted in the image is:
questions.solution:
The air cell shown in the given image is the anteriormost cell of the ethmoidal sinus which is the Agger Nasi.
 
Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest ethmoidal air cell. Fovea ethmoidalis is a bony plate which separates the anterior ethmoidal sinus from the anterior cranial fossa and forms the roof of the ethmoid sinus. Concha bullosa refers to the condition where the turbinate gets filled with air and enlarges.


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 151

questions.text: An illustration of an injection near the medial canthus is shown. What steps are involved?
questions.solution:
The given image shows anterior ethmoidal nerve blockage procedure.
 
It can be done to prevent postoperative agitation which is a common complication of Ear, Nose and Throat surgeries. The procedure can also be carried during the treatment of nasal fractures.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 154

questions.text: The photograph depicts a 40-year-old individual with a polyploid tumor in the nose. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Rhinosporidiosis

Rhinosporiodosis is a chronic granulomatous conditios by causative agent a protozoa, Rhinosporidium seeberi. Commonly Water borne and affects immunocompromised individuals. Presenting with Leafy polypoidal highly vascular mass. Complete excision with cauterization is the treatment of choice. Dapsone can be given in recurrent conditions.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 177

questions.text: What is the treatment for the given case?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the patient is suffering from oropharyngeal candidiasis, which should be treated by antifungal agents such as Clotrimazole troches or Nystatin or fluconazole.
 
Oropharyngeal candidiasis, also known as thrush, is commonly caused by Candida albicans. It is commonly seen in neonates, immunocompromised patients (especially those suffering from AIDS. It is also seen in recipients of prolonged antibiotic or glucocorticoid therapy.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 245

questions.text:
A woman approaches with a history of experiencing burning after eating spicy meals. On inspection, the buccal mucosa has bilateral white lacy streaks.
Although the third molar is amalgamated, there is no history of tobacco addiction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
White lacy lines (Wickham's striae) with a history of amalgamated molar is suggestive of Lichen planus.
               
Lichen Planus
 

  • Cutaneous lesions of lichen planus consist of itchy, violaceous, flat-topped papules that may coalesce focally to form plaques
  • It is also referred to as pruritic, purple, polygonal papules
  • These papules are often highlighted by white dots or lines called 'Wickham striae', representing the clinical correlates of zones of hypergranulosis, that typify lesions histologically.
  • Multiple lesions are characteristic and are symmetrically distributed; particularly on the extremities, often about the wrists and elbow, and on the glans penis

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 247

questions.text: A 5 years old child presents with voice change and stridor. Identify the abnormality marked on the fiberoptic laryngoscopy:
questions.solution:
Respiratory papillomatosis is a recurrent condition, common in children and presents with respiratory polyps. Respiratory papillomas are caused by the human papilloma virus (HPV). JORRP (Juvenile-onset) is more common and more severe than AORRP (Adult onset). JORRP is caused by exposure to HPV during the peripartum period. They're usually benign (non-cancerous). These growths can lead to vocal cord damage and airway problems. Because the virus is in the tissue, respiratory papillomas tend to reoccur even after they are removed. Treatment is laser resection of tumours.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 346

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in a child who presented with fever and dysphagia with the following visualization.
questions.solution:
Peritonsillar Abscess is a common condition affecting the area around the tonsils. It occurs when bacteria or other infectious organisms, mostly GABHS, get trapped in the space between the tonsil and its covering membrane. It is frequently accompanied by fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and an asymmetric tonsillar bulge with displacement of the uvula away from the affected side. This clinical picture is highly diagnostic of Peritonsillar Abscess, which is treated with antibiotics and, in some cases, surgical drainage.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 299

questions.text: As shown in the barium image, mention the diagnosis on a patient with Halitosis and swelling in the lateral aspect of the neck which on pressing gives rise to a regurgitant air sound.
questions.solution:
Patient presented with halitosis and swelling over lateral aspect of neck, barium swallow suggested out pouching over cricopharyngeal region suggestive of zenker’s diverticulum

A particular kind of diverticulum called Zenker's diverticulum forms in the hypopharynx, usually in the space between the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle and the cricopharyngeus (CP) muscle. It is a false diverticulum since it only affects the mucosa and submucosal layers and not the muscle layer.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 310

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy who had crowded teeth and appeared to breathe through his mouth visited the opd.
Determine the condition based on the given image.
questions.solution:
1. nasopharyngeal tonsil- ADENOID FACE
  • caused by chronic nasal blockage and mouth breathing. 
  • An elongated face, a dull expression, an open mouth, noticeable upper teeth that are crowded and an upturned upper lip. 
  • As a result of the alaenasi's disuse atrophy, the nose seems constricted. 
  • As the tongue's molding effect on the palate is lost, the hard palate is extremely arched.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 276

questions.text:
6-year-old boy who underwent surgery for recurrent tonsillitis had an uneventful recovery period.
The following morning, he experienced some minor mouth bleeding. WHat is the most likely source of bleeding?
questions.solution:
complications of tonsillectomy 

Immediate complications 

  • Bleeding (2-4%): On the table, gauze pressure or ligation are used to control primary haemorrhage. Trauma to a paratonsillar vein or aberrant vessel can cause excessive bleeding, or due to an underlying infection, hypertension, or bleeding disease. 
  • Trauma: soft palate, uvula, tonsils, lips, and teeth. Rarely, cervical injuries could happen. 

Delayed complications 

1. Hemorrhage: 

Reactionary haemorrhage might happen within 48 hours (incidence: 0.5–1%). 

It results from: 

Postoperative increase in blood pressure; 

Dislodgement of clot. 

Secondary haemorrhage (incidence 1%).

It typically happens between days 5-7 due to infection. 

2. Otalgia 

3. granuloma of intubation 

4. nightmares 

5. Pulmonary complications 

6. Change of voice 

7. Chronic granular pharyngitis

8. Dislocation of the tympanic membrane (TM) joint.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy who had been having trouble swallowing for a few hours was taken to the emergency room by his mother.
He was seen playing unattended. An X-ray was obtained. Find the foreign body's location.
questions.solution:
The oesophagus may contain a spherical metallic foreign body that is located in the midline immediately above the aortic knob. However, the coin cannot fit inside the trachea because its diameter exceeds that of the trachea, and on the lateral view, the trachea appears anterior to the coin.

Trick: -
In oesophagus- in AP view coin diameter is seen
In trachea- in AP view lateral surface of coin is seen

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 500

questions.text: The structure shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a tracheo esophageal voice prosthesis.
 
This is surgically implanted in patients who have undergone laryngectomies in order to enable speech production. The prosthesis allows passage of air between the trachea and the oesophagus which enables voice production.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 353

questions.text: What is the purpose of the following instrument?
questions.solution:
The laryngoscope seen here has a curved blade and is used for direct laryngoscopy.
Most tracheal intubations are performed using a viewing device.
The most often used tool for this purpose has traditionally been the traditional laryngoscope. A set of interchangeable blades plus a handle with batteries and a light source make up the standard laryngoscope.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 481,521

questions.text: What is the eye finding seen in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Ptosis.
  • Ptosis refers to the drooping of the upper eyelid, which can partially or completely cover the eye which can be seen in the left eye in the given image.
  • It can occur due to various causes, including weakness or dysfunction of the muscles responsible for lifting the eyelid.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 395.

questions.text: Given below is the image of the patient who presented with diplopia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given images shows ptosis and down & out left eye ball in the primary gaze. There are defects in all eye movements with the exception of abduction (this shows maintained lateral rectus function). Such a presentation suggests oculomotor (third) nerve palsy. Down and out eye: 3rd nerve palsy.

Option 1: Lateral rectus palsy: Shows restriction in movement of abduction of ipsilateral eye. Occurs due to Abducens nerve palsy.

Option 2: Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia: Injury to MLF. Shows normal primary gaze. There is restriction of adduction and adducting saccades of the ipsilateral eye. On attempted lateral gaze, away from the side of the lesion, the abducting eye overshoots the target (dysmetria), giving the appearance of dissociated (disconjugate) nystagmus.

Option 4: Trochlear nerve palsy: Weakness of the superior oblique muscle allows unopposed action of its direct antagonist, the inferior oblique muscle, which results in an ipsilateral hypertropia and excyclotorsion. The classic sign of unilateral fourth nerve palsy is a contralateral head tilt (an ocular torticollis). 


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no: 927, 1228-1233.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve palsy is shown in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. VI nerve palsy

The image shows left eye in adduction, so there is an Abduction constraint which is seen on the left eye of the patient. The abducens nerve, which supplies the lateral rectus muscle, is the cause of lateral gaze palsy. 

Nerve supply of EOM: [MNEMONIC: LR6, SO4, Rest 3]
  • All extraocular muscles are supplied by oculomotor nerve except:
  • Lateral Rectus : Abducens Nerve
  • Superior Oblique : Trochlear Nerve.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no: 1233.

questions.text: Which nerve is affected when the movement is lost in the primary gaze?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Abducens Nerve palsy
  • Sixth nerve (Abducens) palsy results in paralysis of Lateral rectus muscle which is the principal abductor of eyeball.
  • Therefore, Abducens nerve palsy manifests as esotropia (adduction) which almost always affects the primary position.
  • The esotropia of a sixth nerve palsy initially exhibits the typical incomitance of a paralytic strabismus; the deviation is maximized in ipsilateral horizontal gaze and smallest in opposite gaze


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1233.

questions.text: Identify the given ophthalmologic finding:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Vossius ring.

  • It is commonly seen after blunt truma to the eye.
  • A circular ring of fainted or strippled opacity is seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule.
  • It is due to striking of contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens, which results in impression of the iris on the lens during trauma. The ring is always smaller than the size of the pupil.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 447.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with the following visual field deficiency. Which section of the visual pathway could be the source of his suffering?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Left occipital lobe

The image here shows visual field defect of Right sided congruous Homonymous Hemianopia with macular sparing which commonly occurs due to occlusion of Posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplying anterior part of visual cortex.

Therefore, the lesion is located at Left Occipital lobe.

VISUAL FIELD DEFECTS: 


If nasal fibres are effected temporal visual field is effected and vice versa. Left occipital lobe receives left temporal fibres and right nasal fibres and thus opposite visual field is effected (9).


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 325, 327.

questions.text: What can be determined about the condition from the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Left third nerve paralysis 
 
  • The patient is unable to adduct, raise, or depress the left eye and has complete left eye ptosis. 
  • The levator palpebrae superioris, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior rectus muscles, all of which are damaged in this patient, are innervated by the third cranial nerve.
  • Ptosis due to LPS muscular paralysis. 
  • Deviation- The action of lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles cause the eyeball to be turned down, out and slightly intorted. 
  • Ocular movements in all directions except outward are restricted.
  • Accommodation is completely lost due to ciliary muscle paralysis
  • Pupil is fixed and dilated due to sphincter pupillae muscle paralysis. 
  • Raising the eyelid induces crossed diplopia.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1228, 1229.

questions.text: The angle of deviation in the right eye for the given figure is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: 15°
 
  • The angle of deviation refers to the angle by which the eyes deviate from their normal alignment.
  • In the given figure, we can see the corneal reflex is visible at the pupillary margin. Therefore,  according to Hirschberg Corneal reflex test (HBCRT), the angle of deviation in the left eye is 15°.
  • This means that the left eye is deviated by 15° from its normal alignment.
  • The specific degree of deviation, in this case, is 15°.
Hirschberg test done for angle of deviation. If corneal reflex in:
  • Centre of cornea - 0 degree
  • At pupil margin- 15 degree
  • In between pupil margin and limbus - 30 degree
  • At limbus - 45 degree

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1199.

questions.text: These eyeglasses are worn for:
questions.solution:
The given image shows bifocal glasses. Bifocal glasses are most commonly used for presbyopic individuals who have difficulty in both near and far vision. Presbyopia is an age related defect of vision caused due to decreased power of accommodation.
  • Executive bifocals are used for pediatric pseudophakia.
  • It is rarely used in Aphakia.
  • The image shows straight bifocals which are used in presbyopia.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 45, 49.

questions.text: Identify the refractive error shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
In the given image, incident parallel rays come to a focus anterior to the light-sensitive layer of the retina, seen in myopia.

This phenomena occurs due to either increase in the power of the lens or due to lengthening of the eyeball.
Hence, the image is formed in front of the retina.
The defect is corrected by using a Concave lens.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 31, 32.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent conditions does the image in question represent?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia

The given case appears to be of Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia(INO), which is a  conjugate lateral gaze abnormality that causes adduction dysfunction in the afflicted eye.
  • INO occurs due to injury to the Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus (MLF), between the abducens nucleus and the contralateral medial rectus subnucleus of the oculomotor nerve, interrupts transmission of neural impulses to the ipsilateral medial rectus muscle 
  • The afflicted eye does not adduct when an attempt is made to stare contralaterally (relative to the affected eye). However, there is nystagmus as the contralateral eye abducts.
Additionally, horizontal diplopia is brought on by the eyes' divergence.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 927, 928.

questions.text: Name the following chart.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Hess chart. It is used in assessing diplopia; to asses the degree of paresis, measurement of deviation, udentify the paralysed muscle and differentiate between mechanical and neurogenic cause.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 370.

questions.text: Based on the patient's visual field investigation, determine the location of the lesion in the optic pathway.
questions.solution:
The given image shown an example of bitemporal hemianopia (loss of temporal eye field of both the eyes) due to injury at the optic chiasma. The most common intrinsic lesion is the pituitary adenoma which may promote compression of the optic chiasm causing visual disturbances. Other causes include third ventricular gliomas and craniopharyngioma.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 913, 914.

questions.text: Identify the condition show in the image given below
questions.solution:
A pterygium, or wing-shaped protrusion of conjunctiva over the cornea, is visible in the illustration.
  • Pterygium is a growth of fibrovascular tissue on the cornea and conjunctiva. It occurs in the palpebral fissure, much more often nasally than temporally, although either or both (“double” pterygium) occur.
  • Elevated whitish opacities (“islets of Vogt”) and an iron deposition line (“Stocker’s line”) may delineate the head of the pterygium on the cornea.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 206, 207.

questions.text:
A female comes with H/O contact lens use comes with following. What is the diagnosis?

1 .Trachoma
2. GPC
3. Spring Cataract
4. Acute follicular conjunctivitis
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: GPC.
 
  • The severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis is known as giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC).
  • It is most frequently encountered with contact lens (CL) wear; in such cases, it is termed contact lens-associated papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC). 
  • It may be caused by ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles, corneal surface irregularity, or filtering blebs.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 194.

questions.text: What is the cause of diplopia in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Astigmatism

 
  • Image above is showing a pterygium.  The Pterygium growing on the corneal causes irregular astigmatism and horizontal flattening of cornea leading to diplopia.
  • Pterygium is a wing-shaped, triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue that can encroach onto the cornea. It occurs as a response to prolonged exposure to ultraviolet rays, dry heat, etc.
  • A pterygium is a degenerative subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. It is most commonly seen on the nasal aspect of the eye. It is made up of three parts:
    • Cap (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge)
    • Head
    • Body
  • Patients may be asymptomatic or present with irritation, grittiness, or episodes of inflammation. As they enlarge, it may obstruct vision and lead to astigmatism. Diplopia is rare symptom if the pterygium involves the medial rectus.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 207.

questions.text: One year after having cataract surgery, a 63-year-old patient complains of having worse eyesight. The clinical image seen below was discovered. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: After cataract.
 
  • Posterior capsular opacification also called "after" or "secondary" cataract is the opacity that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. 
  • In this surgery, the posterior capsule and part of the anterior capsule are left in situ which almost always has remnants of the capsule. 
  • The rate of posterior capsule opacification following extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) and phacoemulsification varies with the age of the patient, the surgeon, the surgical technique, the type of intraocular lens used, and the duration after surgery.
 
Other options: 
  • UGH syndrome (B): A rare complication of cataract surgery, causing glare, blurred vision, and pigment dispersion.
  • Irvine-Gass syndrome (C): Also known as pseudophakic cystoid macular edema, it involves the accumulation of fluid in the macula after cataract surgery, leading to decreased vision and potential distortions.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 410, 411.

questions.text:
Five days after having cataract surgery, a patient with the clinical picture below presented to the eye OPD.
The management of this ailment should include everything except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and images point to a diagnosis of Post-operative endophthalmitis, a dreaded complication of cataract surgery. Antibiotics administered intravenously have no/minimal role in the treatment of endophthalmitis.
  • The preferred method of treatment involves injecting intravitreal antibiotics after removing 0.2–0.3 ml of vitreous tissue to prepare smears and collect cultures.
  • Intravitreal vancomycin provides broad coverage for over 99% of Gram-positive organisms, and ceftazadime is effective against 100% of Gram-negative bacteria observed in post-operative endophthalmitis.
  • Patients presenting with visual acuity at the level of light perception (PL +ve) compared with intravitreal antibiotics alone, pars plana vitrectomy with injection of intravitreal antibiotics appeared to improve the visual outcomes.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 727, 728.

questions.text:
Nowadays, lasers are used to conduct a range of eye procedures, including cataract surgeries, with minimal incisions, fewer postoperative problems, and quicker recovery times. What is the laser's pulse duration, as depicted below, used for cataract surgery?

1. 10-15 seconds
2. 10-12 seconds
3. 10-9 seconds
4. 10-6 seconds
questions.solution:
The image shown here shows Femtosecond laser. Femtosecond laser-assisted surgery (FLACS) represents a relatively new technology that some surgeons have adopted for cataract extraction. Pulse frequency of FLACS is 10^-15.

Advantages of Femtosecond laser:

  • Femtosecond lasers have a unique ability to create discrete photodisruption of tissue with minimal collateral effects.
  • This enables very precise cutting in ocular tissues, including the cornea, the lens capsule, and the crystalline lens.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 381, 382.

questions.text: What stage of cataract surgery is depicted in the picture?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the capsulorrhexis step of cataract surgery (Anterior capsulotomy).

Anterior Capsule is stained using Trypan blue and is opened up using 2 techniques—Continuous Curvilinear Capsulorrhexis (CCC) and  Can opener technique.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 380.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions causes the eye condition listed below?
questions.solution:
The image here shows brownish-yellow discoloration seen in the limbic region of the cornea, which points towards Kayser-Fleischer (KF) Ring usually seen in Wilson's disease.





Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 200.

questions.text:
The eye was photographed as shown below. It displays abrasion, foreign body, ulcer, and perforation of the cornea. All can cause hypotonic maculopathy,
with the exception of:
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1: Suprachoroidal hemorrhage.
 
  • Hypotonic maculopathy refers to the swelling and dysfunction of the macula due to chronic low intraocular pressure (IOP) less than 6 mm Hg.
  • It can occur as a complication of ocular conditions involving corneal abrasion, foreign body, ulcer, or perforation.
  • Suprachoroidal hemorrhage refers to bleeding between the choroid and the sclera, typically caused by trauma or surgical complications.
  • While suprachoroidal hemorrhage can lead to elevated intraocular pressure (hypertony), it does not directly cause hypotonic maculopathy.
 
Other options:
  • The most common cause is excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery (option D). 
  • Other causes include trauma such as cyclodialysis of uvea (option C), penetrating injury (option B), chronic uveitis, retinal detachment and other systemic causes such as dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes, uraemia and treatment with hyperosmotic agents. They usually cause bilateral hypotonic maculopathy.


Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page no 326, 327, 610.

choices.text: Topical natamycin only, no need to drain the hypopyon

questions.text: Following an eye stick injury, a farmer visited the ophthalmological emergency department with blurred vision, redness, tearing, photophobia, pain, and a feeling of a foreign body. A corneal ulcer with redness and fuzzy edges is discovered during examination. The image below depicts an eye. How are you going to handle this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case is of a Fungal Corneal Ulcer with immobile hypopyon.
  • Topical Natamycin is effective against yeasts and has a broad spectrum of activity against filamentous organisms.
  • There is no need to drain the hypopyon as white blood cells present in a hypopyon provide protection against an invading infection, thus one should never try to drain it.
  • However, a persistent hypopyon can lead to anterior synechiae and close-angle glaucoma.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 228, 229.

questions.text: Pick the most appropriate diagnostic approach for the clinical symptom shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Serum ceruloplasmin.
 
  • Kayser–Fleischer ring is a brownish-yellow area of copper deposition that is present in the peripheral Descemet membrane. 
  • This is seen in Wilson's disease (hepatolenticular degeneration) and occurs due to a deficiency of ceruloplasmin. 
  • Fleischer's rings seen in keratoconus are epithelial iron deposits that are best seen with a cobalt blue filter during slit-lamp examination.
  • Low serum ceruloplasmin level is diagnostic of Wilson's disease.



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3236.

questions.text: A diabetic man in his 60s who had previously experienced reading vision problem presented to the ophthalmology OPD for evaluation. What does the fluorescein angiogram reveal?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
 

  • Neovascularization: The hallmark feature of PDR is the growth of new, abnormal blood vessels (neovascularization), which occur in response to retinal ischemia (lack of oxygen). These vessels typically form on the optic disc (disc neovascularization) and along the retinal periphery.

  • Vitreous Hemorrhage: The newly formed blood vessels are fragile and prone to rupture, leading to bleeding into the vitreous cavity. This can cause sudden vision loss and the appearance of floaters in the visual field.

  • Retinal Detachment: The abnormal blood vessels can contract, causing the retina to detach from its underlying layers. This can lead to severe vision loss and is a common complication in PDR.

  • Fibrous Tissue Formation: In addition to blood vessels, fibrous tissue can form as a result of the neovascularization. This fibrous tissue can cause traction on the retina, further contributing to retinal detachment and other complications.

  • Macular Edema: Although more common in non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), macular edema can also occur in PDR. This involves the accumulation of fluid in the macula, leading to blurred central vision.




Severity classification of DR:

Stage 1: Mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.
  • Microaneurysm plus hard exudate
Stage 2: Moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.
  • Stage 1 + IRMA
Stage 3: Severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.
  • Retinal hemorrhage in 4 quadrants
  • Venous bleeding in 2 quadrants
Stage 4: Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Neovascularization

FA image of PDR showing Neovascularisation: 



Labelled FA image of various findings seen in Diabetic Retinopathy:


 
Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 545.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man who had suddenly lost vision in his left eye came to the emergency room. The fluorescein angiography produced the image that is displayed below. Below is an illustration of the optical coherence tomography image. Which layers of the retina experience fluid buildup?
questions.solution:
• The arrow in the given picture points towards Retinal Pigment epithelium.
  • The OCT and FFA in this case point to Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR), which is characterised by fluid buildup in the subretinal space and separation of retinal pigment epithelium from the neurosensory retina.


FFA shows the characteristic Mushroom/ Umbrella pattern or Smoke stack appearance.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 607-609.

questions.text: Identify the possibility in the given FFA picture.
questions.solution:
Macular ischemia is visible on the FFA picture, that is the central dark region.
 
These microaneurysms can be seen as pinpoint hyperfluorescent lesions on this fluorescein angiography image spread throughout the macula. Additionally, you can see a region of fluorescein leakage, which is brought on by neovascularization and leaky new blood vessels in that region. Additionally, the superior arcade of this picture exhibits intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs).



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 517-519.

questions.text: An elderly female with gradual painless DOV fundus findings image :
questions.solution:
The given picture shows hard exudates as seen in Diabetic Retinopathy.

A potentially dangerous side effect of macular edema in people with diabetes mellitus is the development of hard macular exudates. They develop in the Outer plexiform layer of the retina. Hard foveal exudate deposition, one of the most prevalent and early clinical indications of diabetic retinopathy, has been linked to visual impairment.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 544, 545.

questions.text: What is the pathology depicted in the below histopathology picture of the retina?
questions.solution:
Drusen are signs of harm to the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), a layer of cells that gives nourishment and protection to the retina. They appear as yellowish deposits beneath the retina and are typically considered one of the earliest stages of age-related macular degeneration (ARMD), a condition that can cause irreversible vision loss. Visual impairment can be caused by a generalized granularity and/or atrophy of the RPE, photoreceptors, and the choriocapillaris. 



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1323.
Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 586, 589.

questions.text: A patient who had cataract surgery a year prior is currently receiving medication for rheumatoid arthritis. The patient described an instantaneous, painless loss of vision. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient in question has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, cataract surgery and Fluorescein angiogram of the patient shows classic “petalloid” appearance of fluorescein leakage in the late phase of the angiogram, which is indicative of cystoid macular edema (CME).

CME is a frequent complication following cataract surgery and is also known as Irvine–Gass syndrome. CME is the most common cause of vision loss after cataract surgery.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 626, 627, 630.

questions.text: Which ophthalmological study is being conducted in this illustration?
questions.solution:
The image shows Applanation tonometry. The most popular applanation tonometer was designed by Goldmann (GAT) for use with the Haag-Streit slit lamp. 

GAT is based on the Imbert–Fick principle, which states that the force necessary to applanate a perfectly elastic, infinitely thin, dry sphere divided by the area flattened (P = F/A) equals the pressure inside the sphere.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1025.
Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 108.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought in with complaints of photophobia and bilateral proptosis along with eye watering. Which medical diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Watering of eyes along with bilateral proptosis and photophobia in a 2 year old child is suggestive of congenital glaucoma.

It is seen between birth and the age of 3-4 years.

Clinical features:

The affected eye is enlarged with a hazy cornea.
Increased size of eyeball (Buphthalmos).
Photophobia is the earliest symptoms due to corneal edema
It should be noted that the earliest sign is Corneal Haze (Ground glass appearance)
Watering of eyes
At a later stage, due to rupture of Descemet's membrane, more discrete corneal opacities are seen
Blue eyes due to scleral thinning.


 
Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1106, 1107.

questions.text: A one-month-old baby is diagnosed as having photophobia and watery eyes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Watering of eyes along with photophobia and blue sclera in a one-month old child is suggestive of congenital glaucoma. 

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG)/Buphthalmos is a rare condition caused by genetically defined defects in the trabecular meshwork and anterior chamber angle, which result in high intraocular pressure (IOP), but no other ocular or systemic developmental problems. It is seen between birth and the age of 3-4 years.

Clinical features:

The affected eye is enlarged with a hazy cornea.
Increased size of eyeball (Buphthalmos).
Photophobia is the earliest symptoms due to corneal edema
It should be noted that the earliest sign is Corneal Haze (Ground glass appearance)
Watering of eyes
At a later stage, due to rupture of Descemet's membrane, more discrete corneal opacities are seen
Blue eyes due to scleral thinning.


 
Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1106, 1107.

questions.text: Upper lid coloboma most likely complication ?
questions.solution:
Exposure keratitis will be seen in the given condition as the patient will not be able to close eyelids.
Because the eyelid is inadequate, the cornea is constantly exposed to the environment, which can lead to exposure keratitis and subsequent bacterial infections.



Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th edition, Page no 59, 60.

questions.text: The following tool is utilized for indirect ophthalmoscopy and is depicted in the figure. What magnification should be used along with it to see the retina?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is 2: +20D.

The instrument shown in the image is used for indirect ophthalmoscopy.
The principle of this procedure is to make the eye highly myopic. Light is transmitted from the headset to the fundus through a condensing lens held at the focal point of the eye, providing an inverted image that is observed through a stereoscopic viewing system.
A convex lens is used, commonly +20D.
The image formed is real, inverted, and magnified.
It is used for assessing and managing retinal detachment and other peripheral retinal lesions.





Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 113, 548.

questions.text: To identify a disease state, a new test(Test B) is shown in red line. Both healthy and ill populations are subjected to the test. Which is shown in the graph below. Which of the following statements about the test is accurate?
questions.solution:
Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Both sensitivity and specificity are lower in the test represented in red (Test B) compared to the test represented in black(Test A). 

Sensitivity is the proportion of all people with the disease who test positive. It is the probability of the test being positive when the disease is present. 
Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) or Sensitivity = 1 —false-negative rate. 

Specificity is the proportion of all people without the disease who test negative. It is the probability of the test being negative when the disease is absent. 
Specificity= TN / (TN + FP) or specificity= 1 —false-positive rate. 

Test B has an increased number of true positives and true negatives as well as increased number of false positives and negatives, compared to Test A. 
Hence, leading to decreased sensitivity and specificity. 



Hence, the 3rd  option is correct.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 155, 156, 157.

questions.text: The box plot below depicts the distribution of three sets of data around the mean. What is the correct order of inference from this box plot?
questions.solution:
The direction of the tail, or the direction of the values with the least frequency, designates whether a set of data is positively or negatively skewed.
  • The data set is divided into quartiles using a boxplot.
  • A "box" (hence the name) extending from the first quartile (Ql) to the third quartile (Q3) makes up the body of the boxplot.
  • A line is drawn inside the box at Q2, at the midpoint, designating the median of the data set.
  • The box has two whisker-like lines that protrude from the front and back. The back whisker extends from Q3 to the largest non-outlier, and the front whisker extends from Q1 to the smallest non-outlier in the data set.
  • If there are any outliers in the data set, they are shown as independent points.
On rotating clockwise, 
1st pic= normal distribution
2nd pic= negatively skewed as tailing or elongation is on left side.
3rd pic = positively skewed as tailing or elongation is on right side.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 7.

questions.text:
The scatter plot below depicts the association between weight and height in four separate samples.
What is the net correlation coefficient if all four samples have the same coefficient of correlation of 0.6?
questions.solution:
The slope of the graph provides the coefficient of correlation.
The net correlation coefficient will remain at 0.6 because the slopes of all four populations are the same, at 0.6.
  • Correlation coefficient is a linear link between two variables which can be measured by the value r, and is also known as the linear correlation coefficient or the Pearson product moment correlation coefficient.
  • If there is a “perfect” linear relationship between the two variables so that it is possible to know the exact value of one variable from knowledge of the other variable, the correlation coefficient r will be exactly ±1.00.
  • If there is absolutely no relationship between the two variables, so that it is impossible to know anything about one variable on the basis of knowledge of the other variable, then the coefficient will be zero.
  • Coefficients beyond ±0.5 are typically regarded as strong, whereas coefficients between 0 and ±0.5 are usually regarded as weak. 
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 36.

questions.text: What is the following data description called?
questions.solution:
• In a specific table called a "Stem and Leaf Plot," each data value is divided into a "stem" (the initial digit or digits) and a "leaf" (usually the last digit).
  • To help visualize the shape of a distribution, a stem-and-leaf display is a tool for presenting quantitative data in a graphical style, comparable to a histogram.
  • Two columns are divided by a vertical line in a straightforward stem-and-leaf layout. The stems are in the left column, and the leaves are in the right column.
In order to give the reader a fast overview of distribution, stem-and-leaf displays are helpful for illustrating the relative density and shape of the data. The majority of the original numerical data is retained, frequently in complete fidelity. They are helpful for identifying outliers and emphasizing data as well.


Online reference: https://statisticsbyjim.com/graphs/stem-and-leaf-plot/

questions.text: Except for____________,all of the following are associated with the image:
questions.solution:
This is called Box and Whisker plot.
  • It is a graphical representation of numerical data based on five-figure summary-minimum, 25th percentile, median (50th percentile), 75th percentile and maximum values.
  • The whisker represents the range of the data, while the box represents the interquartile range. That is from 25% to 75% of values (first to third quartile).
  • The median or second quartile is represented by a partition in the box. When most of observations are concentrated on lower end of scale, it is skewed right (positive) or vice versa. In the given image, most of observations are concentrated on higher end of scale, so it is positively skewed or skewed right.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 7.

questions.text: In the graph below, the biggest margin of error is listed in this order:
questions.solution:
The image displays three normal distribution curves with the same mean but different standard deviations.
As the sample size decreases, the curves become flatter and the peak decreases, indicating a wider confidence interval around the mean.
The narrower the base of the curve, the lower the margin of error.
Of the three given curves,
  • Curve 1 has the lowest margin of error, followed by Curve 2, with Curve 3 having the highest margin of error.
  • In other words, the order from highest margin of error to lowest is Curve 3, Curve 2, and Curve 1.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 30.

choices.text: 6 correlation coefficient between each group's weight and height.

questions.text:
Referring to the illustration, a homogenous sample was divided into 4 groups, with a 0.6 correlation coefficient between each group's weight and height.
What will be the combined overall correlation of the full group?
questions.solution:
The total will be equal to 0.6 because it comes from homogeneous samples.
 

Correlation coefficient is used to gauge how closely two variables relate to one another. 

The most common correlation coefficient is Pearson's correlation, aka Pearson's R, is frequently employed in linear regression.

  • If the correlation coefficient is 1, it means that there is a fixed proportional increase in the other variable for every increase in the positive variable. 
  • If the correlation coefficient is -1, it means that for every positive increase in one variable there is a negative decrease of fixed proportion in the other.
  • Zero indicates that there is neither a positive nor a negative rise for every increment. These two are not related.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 37.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is cured with the following treatment?
questions.solution:
For both multibacillary and paucibacillary leprosy, WHO has created blister pack medicine kits.
 
  • The single lesion paucibacillary leprosy blister pack medicine kit comes with everything needed to administer the three drugs just once. 
  • Any patient who has a positive skin smear must get the MDT multibacillary leprosy treatment regimen.
  • A patient with multibacillary leprosy should never get the paucibacillary leprosy treatment regimen.
  • As a result, if a patient's diagnosis is unclear, that patient should be treated with the MDT regimen for multibacillary leprosy.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 371.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses' life cycles is most similar to the one described below?
questions.solution:
The figure quite clearly depicts that the life cycle shown is that of the Japanese Encephalitis Virus.
  • In contrast to the other choices described above, humans are dead ends and incidental hosts in the life cycle of these viruses.
  • Humans, cattle and horses are dead-end hosts as the disease manifests as fatal encephalitis.
  • Swine play a crucial part in the epidemiology of the disease by acting as an amplifying host.
  • Infection in swine is usually asymptomatic.
  • The most significant vector is the Culex tritaeniorhynchus, which prefers to feed on cattle as compared to humans.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 332.

questions.text: The illustration below depicts the life cycle of:
questions.solution:
In the given life cycle, the hosts involved are humans, pigs and bats.
The disease is transmitted from pig to human, bat to human, human to human and consumption of bat bitten fruits.
Hence, the described cycle is of Nipah Virus.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 330.

questions.text: What is being treated with the kit in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image is of multibacillary adult blister pack, which is used in multibacillary leprosy.

WHO has designed blister pack medication kits for both paucibacillary leprosy and for multibacillary leprosy.
  • Each easy to use kit contains medication for 28 days.
  • The blister pack ,medication kit for single lesion paucibacillary leprosy contains the necessary medication for the one time administration of the 3 medications.
  • Any patient with a positive skin smear must be treated with the MDT regimen for multibacillary leprosy.
  • The regimen for paucibacillary leprosy should never be given to a patient with multibacillary leprosy.
  • Therefore, if the diagnosis in a particular patient is uncertain, treat that patient with the MDT regimen for multibacillary leprosy.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 371.

questions.text:
To whom does the following life cycle belong
   
a. Leptospirosis
b. Yersinia pestis
c. Hanta virus
d. Salmonella typhi
questions.solution:
Given life cycle belongs to Leptospirosis.
 
  • Transmission is through water or food contaminated with animal urine.
  • Life cycle shows transmission from rodent carrier with the organism being expelled in its urine, from where it contaminates the mud and soil present nearby. Then it gets consumed by Mammalian reservoirs, including cows and humans, which then excrete the free living leptospira which are then picked up by the rodents.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 338.

questions.text: The vector in the given disease cycle is:
questions.solution:
Vector in the given disease is hard tick.

Difference between hard and soft tick can be made by the help of following features:
  • Scutellum seen on the back is small in case of hard tick.
  • When seen from above head is visible in hard tick but not visible in case of soft tick.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 347.

questions.text: 4 vials of oral polio vaccine are given below —which one can be used from left to right with the left one being 1 and the right most being 4?
questions.solution:
• Vaccines 1 and 2 can be used.
  • Concept of VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor) - It measures the amount of heat that has been exposed to the vial of vaccine.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and should be discarded.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 122.

choices.text: Moderate malnutrition - Teach mother on how to feed
Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation center

questions.text: 8 kg is the weight of a 16-month-old male. Using the provided growth chart, gauge his development. What actions are required next?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is of Severe malnutrition in which the patient should be immediately referred to the nearest NRC.

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM)-
  • afflicted youngsters are admitted to and treated in the Nutrition Rehabilitation Center (NRC), which is a part of a medical centre.
  • Using MUAC tape, a consistent linkage with ICDS locates and referrals severely undernourished kids in the neighbourhood.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 623.

questions.text: What type of wastes are disposed of in the dustbin indicated below, according to the new biomedical waste disposal guidelines?
questions.solution:
Infectious plastic wastes are contaminated recyclable wastes hence, are thrown in red dustbin.
