questions.text: What does the illustration below represent?
questions.solution:
The given image represents the symbol of radiation hazard.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 920.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female with a history of fever, joint discomfort, and rash visited the OPD. NSAIDs had been recommended.
After a week, the patient's nose started to look reddish. This was caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Chikungunya

After using NSAIDs for one week, the patient developed a reddish discoloration across their nose, as shown in the image. It is known as Chik sign.
  • The mucocutaneous junction (lip, glans) is the most frequently affected region for fixed drug eruption, followed by the vaginal skin (glans). (Option 4)
  • Based on their medical history, which included chronic joint pain and rash, the most likely diagnosis was pigmentation brought on by Chikungunya. 
  • In cases of Chikungunya, the nose pigmentation is noticeable; this condition has not been noted in cases of any other viral exanthem.


Reference: Fitzpatrick's Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 1369.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of the below photograph: -
questions.solution:
In the image we can see swelling of Right limb compared to the left, as it's unilateral so it's a case of lymphedema. 
 
  • Lymphedema of the lower extremity initially involves the foot and gradually progresses up the leg so that the entire limb becomes edematous.
  • In the early stages, the edema is soft and pits easily with pressure.
  • Over time, subcutaneous adipose tissue accumulates, the limb enlarges further and loses its normal contour, and the toes appear square.
  • Thickening of the skin is detected by Stemmer’s sign, which is the inability to tent the skin at the base of the toes.
  • Peau d’orange is a term used to describe dimpling of the skin, resembling that of an orange peel, caused by lymphedema.
  • In the chronic stages, the edema no longer pits and the limb acquires a woody texture as the tissues become indurated and fibrotic.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2119.

questions.text: A leprosy patient who is multibacillary and receiving multiple medication therapies exhibits significant rashes on the lesions that are already present. He also displays neurological involvement. What comes next?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Continue ALT and start Steroids.
 
  • Rash or erythema in the existing lesion with nerve involvement suggest Type 1 Lepra reaction. It's a Type 4 Hypersensitivity reaction. ALT must be continue along with steroids as nerve involvement is present.
 
  • Type 1 lepra reactions involve inflammation of existing skin lesions, which become red, painful, and swollen, and may rarely ulcerate. Although new lesions can appear, they are uncommon. This reaction is associated with acute neuritis, including tenderness and loss of sensory and motor function.
 
  • For pain relief, NSAIDs can be added alongside oral steroids. Thalidomide is reserved for severe type 2 lepra reactions, or erythema nodosum leprosum, which involve systemic symptoms such as iritis, orchitis, and new skin lesion eruptions.




Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 28.5, 28,12, 28.16.

questions.text: Upon inspection, a red, painless rash was seen on the left side of the chest in a patient who had been experiencing fever for eight days and breathing difficulties for two days. Treatment entails:
questions.solution:
An eschar is black, necrotic and painless tissue, often observed on the chest and is usually linked to Rickettsial infections.
 
  • Doxycycline is usually the go-to drug for treating Rickettsial infections since the microbes lack cell wall components that makes beta-lactams and cephalosporins ineffective.
 
  • Patients are treated with oral doxycycline (100 mg twice daily for 7–15 days), azithromycin (500 mg for 3 days), or chloramphenicol (500 mg four times daily for 7–15 days).
 
  • Studies have shown Doxycycline in combination with Azithromycin to be more beneficial in reduction of mortality and complications due to Scrub typhus than monotherapy with either of the two drugs.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1436, 1437.

questions.text: The deformity shown in the given image occurs in which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Rheumatoid arthritis
 
  • The Swan neck deformity is a type of deformity that occurs in the hands and fingers in people with rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It is characterized by flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joints and extension of the metacarpophalangeal joints, giving the fingers a curved, “swan-like” appearance.
  • The deformity can cause difficulty with activities that require finger movement and strength, such as grasping and pinching. The picture shows this deformity in its classic form.

Hand deformities in RA:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2751, 2752.

choices.text: Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints
Post traumatic dystrophy with Complex regional pain syndrome

questions.text: A woman presents with pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand. There were associated complaints of morning stiffness with problem in squatting. The swelling spared the DIP joints. The image of the patient's hands is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This individual is likely suffering from Rheumatoid arthritis due to the presence of pain, swelling, and redness in both the knee and hand joints, as well as early morning stiffness and difficulty squatting that does not affect the DIP joints.
 
  • The presenting symptoms of RA typically result from inflammation of the joints, tendons, and bursae. Patients often complain of early morning joint stiffness lasting >1 hour that eases with physical activity.
  • The wrists and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints stand out as the most frequently involved joints
  • Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint involvement may occur in RA, but it is rare and usually is a manifestation of coexistent osteoarthritis.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2751, 2752.

questions.text:
A young child has an itchy, hyperpigmented plaque with exudation on the back of the knee and elbow flexural, as illustrated.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Atopic dermatitis
 
  • Psoriasis primarily affects the extensor side, whereas hyperpigmented plaque with exudation covering flexural aspects of the elbow and knee in a youngster indicates Atopic dermatitis. 
  • A chronic, excruciatingly itchy skin disorder with blisters called dermatitis herpetiformis is linked to gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Erythematous papules and vesicles collected together at extensor locations are characteristic lesions. 
  • Pemphigus - Initial lesions are easily ruptured superficial vesicles and bullae that leave shallow erosions covered with crust and dried serum.




Reference: Fitzpatrick's Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 364, 365.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman was seen with a history of dysphonia, dysphagia, impaired vision, and growing limb weakening. The patient's chest X-ray displays the following picture. The most likely finding is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Thymoma.
 
  • The chest X-ray shows a mass in the anterior mediastinum, which is the area of the chest between the lungs. This is a common finding in thymomas, which are tumors that arise from the thymus gland.
  • Thymomas can cause various symptoms such as dysphonia, dysphagia, impaired vision, and limb weakness.





Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 70, 71.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 992.

questions.text: To identify distinct heart sounds, an ECG is captured with a phonocardiogram. In the following diagram, where will the second heart sound appear?
questions.solution:
• The phonocardiogram displays the heart sounds, with S2 being the second sound heard during each cardiac cycle.
  • The ECG waveform normally indicates the electrical activity of the heart, with distinct segments and peaks reflecting different phases of the cardiac cycle.
  • Usually, the ECG's T wave is followed immediately by the second heart sound (S2). So, Point C corresponds to Second heart sound.
  • Ventricular repolarization is represented by the T wave, and S2 happens at the conclusion of ventricular systole, immediately following the closing of the aortic and pulmonic valves.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1817.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency room. His pulse is not palpable and his ECG is shown below. What will be the immediate management?
questions.solution:
This a case of Pulseless Ventricular Tachycardia (pVT). Patient came to Emergency with unstable vitals, therefore TOC- Defibrillation.

Cardiac arrhythmias requiring Defibrillation are:
  1. Ventricular fibrillation
  2. Pulseless Ventricular Tachycardia




Reference: Adult Cardiac Arrest Algorithm (ACLS), American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines 2020. URL: https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient comes into your clinic complaining of chest pain that has lasted the last 24 hours and has been accompanied by perspiration and diaphoresis. The ECG results are as follows. It is 150/90 mm Hg. Which of the following is not recommended for this patient's management?
questions.solution:
This is a typical case of ST-elevation MI (STEMI).
Since the patient has come to the hospital 24 hours after the onset of symptoms, there will be no benefit from thrombolysis.

Treatment algorithm for STEMI (ACC/AHA):





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2058.

questions.text: A patient who was presented to the emergency department had the following ECG recorded: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Atrial fibrillation
 
  • AF is diagnosed by electrocardiogram (ECG), either by 12-lead standard ECG or limited lead ambulatory monitor ECG, with findings of lack of organized atrial activity (no P wave), with an irregular ventricular response.
 
  • Characterized by no observable P waves and a fluctuating RR interval, erratic QRS response.
 
  • The lack of coordinated atrial activity and the irregularly irregular ventricular response define the ECG in AF.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1903, 1904.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is not recommended for the treatment of the disease seen in the ECG below?
questions.solution:
• The ECG displays baseline variation and no P waves. Atrial Fibrillation exhibits this.
  • Except for adenosine, which is used in PSVT, Rest all of these medications are utilized in AF. 
  • Acute rate control can be achieved with beta blockers and/or the calcium channel blockers verapamil and diltiazem administered either intravenously or orally, as warranted by the urgency of the clinical situation.
  • Digoxin has been used for many years for rate control, particularly in patients susceptible to congestive heart failure, because it lacks the negative inotropic effect seen in calcium channel blockers and beta blockers.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1905.

questions.text: ECG is conducted after the patient reports having recent onset breathlessness. The electrocardiogram (ECG) is presented below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• ECG shows- narrow complex tachycardia with irregular rhythm. Since P waves are seen, it rules out AF.
 
  • Different morphologies of P waves in ECG rules out sinus arrhythmia. All the above said features confirm MAT.
 
  • Absence of chest pain and significant ST elevations rules out acute myocardial infarction.
 
  • Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is a cardiac arrhythmia caused by multiple sites of competing atrial activity. It is characterized by an irregular atrial rate greater than 100 beats per minute (bpm). Atrial activity is well organized, with at least 3 morphologically distinct P waves, irregular P-P intervals, and an isoelectric baseline between the P waves.
 
  • MAT is commonly seen in COPD patients. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1901, 1902.

questions.text: What is the following ECG's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This is a classical ECG showing Ventricular Bigeminy as distinct 2 morphologies of QRS complex could be seen.
     
  • In Ventricular bigeminy, every alternate QRS is a PVC.
  • It is seen in digoxin toxicity.

Electrical alternans would have variable amplitude of qRS but not as distinct 2 morphologies. Here's an image given below:




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1917.

questions.text: Determine the diagnosis based on the ECG below:
questions.solution:
• The ECG seen above is often observed in a 2:1 heart block, a kind of second-degree "fixed ratio" AV nodal block.
 
  • It develops when every other P wave is NOT followed by a QRS complex because the P wave is not passed by the AV node to reach the ventricles.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1881, 1883, 1924.

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic man with palpitations arrives at the AIIMS emergency department. Systolic blood pressure was 70 mm Hg at the time of assessment. His ECG was recorded in an emergency and is shown below. What is the management's next most important step?
questions.solution:
• The ECG is showing narrow complex tachycardia with absent P-waves with regular R-R interval. The patient is likely to be having paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).
 
  • Since the patient is in shock with hypotension, electrical cardioversion is the immediate treatment of choice.
 
  • Drug of choice for PSVT is Adenosine but it is to be used in hemodynamically stable patients.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1898, 1899.

questions.text: A 76-year-old male patient who has been experiencing retrosternal chest pain for six hours comes to the AIIMS emergency room. The next EKG was recorded. What is going to be your main line of management?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows STEMI and onset of symptom is 6 hours so PCI is the best possible intervention.
PCI could be done upto 24 hours. Ideal door to balloon time is 90 minutes.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2058, 2059.

questions.text: Following waves in ECG are seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hypokalemia
 
  • U waves are small deflections that can appear on an electrocardiogram (ECG) following the T wave and before the next P wave.
  • U waves are often prominent and can be seen in leads V2 to V4 on the ECG.
  • U waves can be seen in certain conditions such as hypokalemia (low potassium levels), which is the most common cause.
  • Hyponatremia (low sodium levels) and hypercalcemia (high calcium levels), do not typically cause U waves in an ECG.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1830, 1831.

questions.text: Water-hammer pulse is seen in:
questions.solution:
Water hammer pulse is a characteristic of aortic regurgitation (AR) which is a condition that occurs when the aortic valve does not close completely.

  • This allows for blood to leak backwards from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole. This abnormality in the flow of blood is what causes the water hammer pulse in aortic regurgitation.
  • The pulse may be observed as a rapid alternating rise and fall of the arterial waveform in response to each heart beat. It has a snapping or palpable nature to it and is most often seen in the carotid artery.
  • It is typically accompanied by a loud radiated sound (“machinery murmur”) heard over the lower left sternal border during systole.
  • Water hammer pulse occurs due to a sudden and dramatic increase in diastolic blood pressure- caused by the regurgitated blood.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1988.

questions.text: Name the machine.
questions.solution:
The given machine is an Automated external defibrillator (AED).
  • This specialised medical tool is frequently used to determine if ventricular fibrillation or fast ventricular tachycardia is present or absent.
  • It decides whether to deliver an electrical shock directly to the heart without the need for operator interaction (fibrillation).


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no 2877, 3186.

questions.text: Name the cause for A 20 years old man with hypertension has following CXR finding with aortic shadow as below.
questions.solution:
• The image shows the figure of 3 sign which is seen in the Coarctation of the aorta. It is formed by pre-stenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian, indentation at the coarctation site, and post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.
 
  • Coarctation of the aorta refers to the luminal narrowing of a short section of the aorta typically at the site of insertion of the ductus arteriosus. The narrowing of the aorta is thought to occur due to the presence of excessive integrations of ductal tissue around the aortic isthmus.
  • This condition typically presents in teenage or adult patients with seemingly unexplained hypertension and they are at increased risk of additional micro- and macrovascular complications.
  • Individuals with coarctation of the aorta may display symptoms including headaches, nosebleeds, pale skin, tiredness, fainting, and chest pain.
  • Treatment options for Coarctation of the aorta may include medical therapy, balloon angioplasty, or even open surgical aortic reconstruction.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2015.
Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 428, 429.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady presented with abdominal pain and was treated with some medication. 3 hours post-treatment with this medication - the lady developed palpitations and respiratory distress. Vitals were stable and ECG is shown below. Treatment?
questions.solution:
Torsade de pointes is the suspected diagnosis based on the patients' ECG.
 
Long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that result in Torsade de pointes can be effectively treated and prevented with IV MgSO4.
 
  • Defibrillation should be started right away if the patient is unstable.

    The ECG presented indicates wide QRS complex tachycardia with varying QRS amplitudes, suggesting torsades de pointes. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, the preferred treatment is intravenous MgSO.

  • Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) is characterized by continuously changing QRS morphology. When it occurs in individuals with congenital or acquired QT interval prolongation, it is known as torsades de pointes. Patients may experience near-syncope, syncope, or cardiac arrest.
  • IV MgSO is very effective for both treating and preventing recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that can trigger torsades de pointes.
  • If magnesium treatment is ineffective, an infusion of isoproterenol or pacing at a rate of 100-120 depolarizations per minute generally suppresses VT recurrences. In cases where the patient is hemodynamically unstable, immediate defibrillation is necessary.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1911, 1923, 1924.

questions.text: As per the ECG shown below, what will be the next step in the case of A 34-year-old with h/o of palpitations who came to emergency with a pulse rate of 156/min and with a BP=70/40 mm Hg. Emergency has tried initial vagal manoeuvre and adenosine to which the rhythm is refractory. ?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows narrow QRS complex regular tachycardia with absent p waves which is suggestive of AVRT. 

Since the patient in the given question is hemodynamically unstable, the next step of management would be to deliver synchronized DC cardioversion.  


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1895, 1898.

questions.text: What is the next step in management for a 70-year-old unstable male with h/o HTN and DM who acquired the following rhythm with a B.P. of 90/60 mmHg and a weak pulse
questions.solution:
ECG shows uniform narrow QRS complex tachycardia suggestive of PSVT.
 
  • DC cardioversion is a procedure used to treat abnormal heart rhythms. It involves the application of a direct electrical current to the heart through paddles or electrodes placed on the chest wall.
  • This electrical current causes the heart to reset its rhythm to normal, which is why it is used in the case of wide QRS monomorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Since the patient is clinically unstable, with a blood pressure (BP) of 90/60 mmHg, it is imperative that the immediate treatment is DC cardioversion to restore normal rhythm and prevent further harm.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1919.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the ECG shown below. The patient complains of palpitation and dizziness
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows narrow QRS complex tachycardia with absent p waves and irregularly spaced R-R intervals, diagnostic of Atrial fibrillation.
 
  • Option 2- PSVT will have regularly spaced R-R interval with narrow QRS complex tachycardia and absent p waves.
  • Option 3- 2nd degree heart block will be characterized by progressively increasing PR interval followed by missing of a QRS complex.
  • Option 4- MI will produce significant elevation of ST segment with reciprocal changes in opposite leads.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1903, 1904.

questions.text: A 60 year old man was brought to ER in unconscious state. He is a known case of COPD with fever for last 3 days. Based on the ECG provided below, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presence of narrow QRS tachycardia, P-waves of different morphologies along with history of COPD suggests it to be Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia (MAT).
 
  • When an ECG shows a narrow complex tachycardia with an irregular rhythm, this suggests that the heart is beating faster than normal, with a characteristically altered electrical pattern. The presence of P waves, however, indicates that this is not atrial fibrillation, as P waves are not seen in atrial fibrillation.
 
  • Morphological variations in the P waves are highly suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) which is characterized by multiple P wave morphologies (>= 3 types) rather than one consistent morphology.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1901, 1902.

questions.text: Symptoms of a 50-year-old male patient include palpitations, dizziness, and weariness. The ECG strip displays the image below. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Ventricular premature complex.

The ECG strip displays a premature ventricular beat (VPC), originating from the ventricles.
VPCs are frequent and typically not harmful, but they may indicate underlying heart conditions like heart disease or cardiomyopathy.

Criteria of ECG for ventricular premature complex (VPC):
  • Premature beat that originates in the ventricles.
  • QRS complex is wider than 0.12 seconds.
  • There is no P wave preceding the QRS complex.
  • The QRS complex is usually bizarre in appearance.
  • The T wave is usually inverted.
  • The VPC may be followed by a compensatory pause


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1915-1917.

questions.text: A patient with palpitations is brought to the emergency room. The following image can be seen on the ECG recording. What medication is preferred to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Lignocaine
 
  • The ECG shows a regular rhythm with a wide QRS complex, indicating ventricular tachycardia (VT).
  • VT is a serious arrhythmia requiring immediate treatment.
  • In a hemodynamically stable patient amiodarone, lidocaine, and procainamide can be used to treat the condition
  • Preferred medication: Lignocaine
  • In hemodynamically unstable patients, electrical cardioversion is done.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1913.

questions.text: A patient has syncope, palpitations, and hypotension all of a sudden. The patient's ECG displays the picture below. What medical intervention does the patient require?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: DC cardioversion.
 
  • In the given ECG, the presence of narrow-complex regular tachycardia and P-waves occurring after QRS complexes, known as retro P waves or pseudo-r' waves, (especially prominent in lead V1) point to a diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).
  • Electrical cardioversion is done if the patient is hemodynamically unstable (as in this case scenairo where the patient has hypotension and syncope) or if PSVT does not response to any of the other methods mentioned above.
Management includes:
  • Vagal maneuvers    
  • Intravenous Adenosine
  • Intravenous β blockers (esmolol, metoprolol)
  • Intravenous non-DHP calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem)
  • Electrical cardioversion (if hemodynamically unstable or unresponsive to other methods)



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1898, 1899.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient reports postural changes along with dyspnea and a productive cough. The patient had smoked for 20 pack-years in the past. Additionally, the patient has a recent history of binge drinking. The chest X-ray is displayed below. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Clinical features with history of smoking & binge drinking (increases risk of aspiration) and chest X-ray findings showing cavitation & necrosis are suggestive of lung abscess.

Most common cause of primary lung abscess is anaerobes. So, Next step in management is Intravenous clindamycin and fluids.
 
  • Primary lung abscesses is thought to originate when chiefly anaerobic bacteria (as well as microaerophilic streptococci) in the gingival crevices are aspirated into the lung parenchyma in a susceptible host.
  • Thus, patients who develop primary lung abscesses usually carry an overwhelming burden of aspirated material or are unable to clear the bacterial load.
  • Pneumonitis develops initially (exacerbated in part by tissue damage caused by gastric acid); then, over a period of 7–14 days, the anaerobic bacteria produce parenchymal necrosis and cavitation whose extent depends on the host–pathogen interaction. Anaerobes are thought to produce more extensive tissue necrosis in polymicrobial infections in which virulence factors of the various bacteria can act synergistically to cause more significant tissue destruction.

For primary lung abscesses, the recommended regimens are:

(1) Clindamycin (600 mg IV three times daily; then, with the disappearance of fever and clinical improvement, 300 mg PO four times daily) or
(2) an IV-administered β-lactam/β- lactamase combination, followed—once the patient’s condition is stable—by orally administered amoxicillin-clavulanate. 

This therapy should be continued until imaging demonstrates that the lung abscess has cleared or regressed to a small scar. Treatment duration may range from 3–4 weeks to as long as 14 weeks



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1020-1022.

choices.text: Flail chest due to fracture of ribs 5, 6, 7 & 8

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy who was injured in a bike accident is brought to the emergency room complaining of coughing, dyspnea, and chest pain. At the time of evaluation, the patient's blood pressure was 130/80 mm Hg, his heart rate was 88 beats per minute, and his respiration rate was 22 beats per minute. On auscultation, there was less air entry and no breath sounds on one side. An oximeter reading of 98% indicates saturation. Below is an X-ray of the chest. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
In the image above, we can see Hyperlucent left lung field with collapsed lung near the left heart border.

  • Pneumothorax is suspected because the surrounding hemithorax is found to be more translucent than usual with absence of broncho-vascular markings.
  • The central, non deviated location of the trachea is another indication that there is a pneumothorax with collapse.
  • When air leaves from the lung, it collapses. The area between the lung and the chest wall that is external to the lung is then filled with air.
  • The diagnosis is made by physical examination showing an enlarged hemithorax with no breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, and shift of the mediastinum to the contralateral side.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2200.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 373, 374.

questions.text: A CT chest scan was performed on a 45-year-old patient who had a two-year history of mucopurulent cough. The CT scan is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the information given in the question and CT scan finding, most probable diagnosis is Bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis is  irreversible dilatation of the bronchial tree.

Signs of Bronchiectasis on CT:
 
  • Tram Track sign: Thickened and parallel walls of cylindrical bronchiectasis
  • Signet ring sign :Dilated bronchus and accompanying pulmonary artery
  • String of pearls sign: Intermittent narrowed and dilated segment to the affected bronchus when viewed in long axis
  • Bunch of grapes sign: Closely apposed dilated bronchi may look like multiple adjacent thin walled cysts which mimic the appearance of a bunch of grapes.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2174, 2175.

questions.text: 40-year-old smoker presents with chronic cough, dyspnea, and chest pain for the past two years. His HRCT chest is displayed below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given image Water Lily sign is seen. The diagnosis is lung hydatid cyst. Hydatid cysts are caused by the parasite Echinococcus granulosus (EG) possessing cystic lesions. Echinococcal cysts most frequently develop in the liver, then in the lungs.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1793, 1794.

questions.text: Having a fever and severe abdominal pain for the previous four days, a 35-year-old man arrived at the emergency department. The abdomen's X-ray is shown below. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
The given x ray shows Gas Under Diaphragm. It is seen in the following conditions:

1. Hollow viscous perforation
2. Penetrating injury in abdomen
3. Pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries 


The gut wall's integrity is lost in perforated hollow viscus, which leads to enteric contents leaking out. Gastrointestinal wall perforation and full-thickness disruption are caused by direct trauma or tissue ischemia and necrosis.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 137.

Correct option: 3. Fixed Central airway obstruction

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with abdominal pain, a binge drinking episode, shock, and a blood pressure of 70/50 mm Hg and a heart rate of 115 beats per minute arrives at the emergency room. The patient has an oxygen saturation level of 70 mm Hg. The amount of serum creatinine was 2.4 mg/dl and BUN 30 mg/dl. The patient's transaminases were elevated. Based on the CT scan below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Alcohol binge is a common cause of acute pancreatitis. Here the CT scan showing blurry margins of the pancreas is confirming the diagnosis.

Since vitals are unstable and end organ damage is developing as S. Cr is 2.4mg/dL and BUN is 30 mg/dl, therefore it is Severe Acute Pancreatitis. 

Markers for Severe acute Pancreatitis: 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2661.

questions.text: What conditions are related to these two images?
questions.solution:
The lower leg's anterior and lateral surfaces were found to have an inflammatory, indurated plaque with a deep pink or purple color and a "orange skin" appearance.

This may point to the presence of pretibial myxedema, a condition that is seen in patients with Grave's disease (hyperthyroidism).
 
  • In 5% of Graves' disease patients, thyroid dermopathy develops, nearly invariably alongside moderate or severe ophthalmopathy.
 
  • Skin alterations can occur at other areas as well, especially following trauma, despite the fact that they are most common over the anterior and lateral portions of the lower leg (hence the term pretibial myxedema).
 
  • The typical lesion is an indurated, non-inflamed plaque with a "orange skin" look and a deep pink or purple tint. The illness can occasionally spread across the entire lower leg and foot, imitating elephantiasis, and nodules may become involved.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2939.

questions.text: Which of the following results in the following skin changes?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Diabetes mellitus

The presented lesions are indurated, annular, yellowish brown plaques on the shin that are very suggestive of necrosis lipoidica diabeticorum.
 
  • They have an atrophic center and ectatic blood vessels that are visible through the thinner skin (seen in diabetes mellitus).
  • Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is a rare disorder that primarily affects young women with diabetes.
  • This typically starts as an erythematous plaque or papule in the pretibial region and progresses to larger, darker lesions with uneven edges, atrophic cores, and central ulceration. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3128.

choices.text: Normal person after waking up in morning cortical awakening response

questions.text: Select from the options, where there is elevated ACTH and cortisol levels in the morning in comparison the levels of those hormones in the evening in a human being
questions.solution:
• Corticotropin releasing hormone (CRH) is a hormone naturally produced by the hypothalamus in higher levels of CNS control. This hormone has the ability to stimulate the production of ACTH in the pituitary gland. ACTH is secreted from the pituitary in irregular bursts throughout the day, and the plasma cortisol level varies accordingly.
  • The circadian rhythm is controlled by the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus which causes the highest levels of ACTH secretion to occur before waking up in the morning and diminish late in the afternoon and early evening.
  • Stressors such as physical trauma, exercise, and mental stress can increase ACTH and cortisol secretion in response to the stressor.

Other options:-
 
  • Option 1: In Addison's disease, there is a deficiency of mineralocorticoids and glucocorticoids Cushing's syndrome is characterized by an overproduction of cortisol.
  • Option 2: In normal person after giving dexamethasone the ACTH will be supressed that will lead to decrease in cortisol level.
  • Option 4: Cushing's syndrome is characterized by an overproduction of cortisol. Excess ACTH secretion is the primary cause of Cushing's syndrome and is characterized by an increase of both ACTH and cortisol in the blood. But the diurnal variation won't be there.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2959-2962.
Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th edition, page no 977, 979, 980.

questions.text: What does this crystal from a urine analysis stand for?
questions.solution:
Calcium oxalate crystals have a distinctive 'X' mark and are square in shape. They are typically described as “Envelope shaped” stones.
  • Struvite stones resemble the lid of a coffin.
  • Uric acid crystals can form rosettes and are frequently needle-shaped.
  • Hexagonal crystals make up cystine.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2370.

questions.text: A patient with renal failure and anemia comes. Serum Protein Electrophoresis is shown below. What's the diagnosis
questions.solution:
The large spike in the gamma region (M Spike) points toward a diagnosis of Multiple Myeloma.

Renal Failure and anemia are a part of end-organ damage (CRAB criteria of Multiple Myeloma).
In nephrotic syndrome, alpha-2 region spike is seen.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 868, 871.

questions.text: A 51-year-old patient arrived at the clinic complaining of hematuria. He was found to have normal blood pressure and pedal edema. Investigations showed the patient had a creatinine level of 9 mg% and no glycosuria. The electron microscopy is shown below. Which of the following investigations should be carried out in order to determine the cause of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Anti GBM Antibodies
 

  • Anti-GBM antibodies specifically targets the alpha 3 chain of type IV collagen found in the glomerular basement membrane (GBM).
  • In Goodpasture disease, these antibodies cause inflammation in the lungs and kidneys, resulting in a condition known as Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN). This can lead to pulmonary hemorrhage in the lungs, as well as to a particular appearance of the kidneys which is called “flea bitten kidneys” upon physical examination.
 
  • Under a microscope, cells called crescents are found in the kidney tissue. Immunofluorescence shows linear patterns of GBM fluorescence for IgG and complement, and electron microscopy reveals ruptures in the GBM.
 
  • Treatment typically involves a combination of plasmapheresis and immunosuppression.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2338, 2339.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with dull agonising back discomfort and sterile pyuria. A radiograph is displayed. What cause is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Often seen on plain radiography, a putty kidney is a pattern of renal calcification linked to renal TB.
  • The calcification, which represents calcified caseous tissue, is typically very uniform and ground glass-like.
  • A lobar pattern of calcification, in which dense calcific rims outline the margin of deformed renal lobes, must be distinguished from putty calcification.
  • When it comes to autonephrectomy, lobar calcification is an end-stage look.
  • A patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, with the given x-ray showing diffuse alveolar calcification in the right renal region point towards a diagnosis of a putty kidney. 
  • The putty kidney is a characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB), specifically renal TB. The given image shows a homogenous and ground-glass-like calcification of the kidney appearing like putty.
  • It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is thus always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB. 
  • Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with a tuberculin test, or at least 3 consecutive early-morning specimens of urine are examined for acid-fast bacilli. They are stained with a Ziehl-Neelsen stain and subsequently cultured. 
  • CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications.
CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB and its manifestations, which are as follows: 

Early:
• Papillary necrosis
Progressive:
• Multifocal strictures
• Generalized or focal hydronephrosis
• Mural thickening and enhancement
• Poorly enhancing renal parenchyma
End-stage:
• Progressive hydronephrosis
• Amorphous dystrophic calcification that involves the entire kidney - putty kidney 

 
  • Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and rifampicin. Partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery is often done. 



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1045, 1046.
Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 748.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man with a recent history of CVA is hospitalized. He is drowsy and not responding to commands. The CT image is displayed as in the figure.
What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has low GCS  and NCCT of the head shows a large wedge shaped infarct in left MCA territory with significant midline shift. In such a scenario,  decompressive neurosurgery will be the next best step of management in order to prevent impending brain herniation. 
 
  • Decompressive craniectomy is a neurosurgical procedure that reduces increased intracranial pressure in the presence of space-occupying brain lesions or brain swelling due to stroke.
  • Cerebral edema is a potential complication in 5-10% of patients with strokes, leading to obtundation and brain herniation. The severity of edema is highest on the second or third day after the stroke and can last for around 10 days.
  • Medical management may not be successful in case of significant edema or infarcts involving the cerebellum.

 
  • Decompressive surgery is recommended for patients who are less than 60 years old and experience deterioration within 48 hours, despite receiving medical therapy.
  • Hypodensity on head CT within the first 6 hours of stroke onset, involving > one-third of the MCA territory, early midline shift, and a diffusion-weighted imaging volume on MRI within 6 hours >80 mL are predictors of severe cerebral edema. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3337.

questions.text: A patient has hypotonia and unilateral ptosis in the same eye. After receiving an IV shot, his symptoms vanished for a breif duration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical findings of unilateral ptosis and hypotonia in the eye with improvement after an IV injection (most probably
edrophonium) indicates Myasthenia gravis.

Clinical features of Myasthenia Gravis:

Muscle weakness and fatiguability are its defining characteristics.

• Weakness may worsen late in the day or after prolonged use (fatigue), although it may also become better after rest or sleep.
• There is a recognizable pattern to how muscular weakness is distributed.

Early on in the course of MG, the cranial muscles (lids and extraocular muscles) are frequently affected.
Ptosis and diplopia are frequent early complaints.

• The patient's attempt to grin is met with a "snarling" face due to facial weakness.
• Chewing weakness is most obvious after exerting a lot of effort, like when chewing meat.

Speech timbre: nasal (due to weakness of palate) Dissonant "mushy" quality (due ot tongue weakness)
• Difficulty swallowing due to pharyngeal, tongue, or palate paralysis, resulting in aspiration or nasal regurgitation.

The edrophonium (Tensilon) test is sometimes of value in distinguishing botulism (usually a negative result) from myasthenia gravis (usually a positive result), which was performed in the question.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1275.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3510, 3511.

questions.text: A and B were instructed to create a square from the empty and filled circles, respectively. A drew a square that isn't really a square. What could be the potential reason?
questions.solution:
Image A shows the phenomenon of past-pointing and intentional tremor while joining the empty and filled circles, seen in case of cerebellar lesions. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3280, 3400.

questions.text: A 25-year-old develops focal seizures and a sudden onset of fever. The frontal lobe and temporal lobe of the brain are enhanced and hyperintense in the MRI image. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Herpes simplex encephalitis
 
  • Herpes simplex encephalitis (HSE) is a viral infection of the brain caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV).
  • It typically presents with focal neurological symptoms, such as seizures, altered mental status, and fever.
  • The involvement of the frontal and temporal lobes is characteristic of HSE and can be observed in MRI imaging as enhanced and hyperintense regions.
  • IOC- PCR of CSF for HSV 
 
  • Meningococcal meningitis (option 1) is a bacterial infection caused by Neisseria meningitidis and primarily affects the meninges. While it can cause neurological symptoms, the MRI findings described in the scenario are not typically associated with this condition.
  • Japanese encephalitis (option 3) is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes and primarily affects the brain. However, the MRI findings mentioned in the scenario are not consistent with Japanese encephalitis.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV, option 4) is a common viral infection that can affect various organs, including the brain. However, the specific MRI findings described in the scenario are not commonly associated with CMV encephalitis.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1095, 1096.

questions.text: Pick the cause when there is no h/o trauma involved in a 45 years old female with sudden onset headache and neck rigidity.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: SAH , as in the CT scan hemorrhage is seen in the fissures that is the subarachnoid space. 
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is a medical emergency that occurs due to bleeding into the subarachnoid space, characterized by a sudden and severe headache, sometimes described as "the worst headache of life."
  • Neck rigidity (stiff neck) is a common symptom of SAH, as the bleeding can irritate the meninges, the protective membranes around the brain and spinal cord.
  • SAH can occur spontaneously, and in many cases, there may be no history of trauma or injury involved.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3355.

questions.text:
Ergotamine is taken by an ART-treated HIV patient for migraine. After a few hours, her limbs feel cold, and her lower limbs' distal pulses are absent.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Ergotism is the result of chronic ergot poisoning, which is traditionally brought on by consuming the alkaloids made by the fungus Claviceps purpurea.
  • The fungus's ergotamine-ergocristine alkaloids cause vasoconstriction, which leads to dry gangrene.
  • It affects the distal structures that have less blood flow, like the fingers and toes.
  • Desquamation or peeling, weak peripheral pulses, loss of peripheral feeling, edema, and eventually the death and loss of affected tissues are some of the symptoms.
  • Vasodilators are used to treat vasoconstriction.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3584, 3590.

questions.text: A 7 year old girl with falling grades and complaints by a teacher that she is inattentive in class to her parents and has bad school performance. On hyperventilation, her symptoms increased and showed the following EEG findings. Diagnosis is (graph is given):
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is Typical absence seizures.
 
  • The electrophysiologic hallmark of typical absence seizures is a burst of generalized, symmetric, 3-Hz, spike-and-slow-wave discharges that begins and ends suddenly, superimposed on a normal EEG background.
 
  • Periods of spike-and-slow-wave discharges lasting more than a few seconds usually correlate with clinical signs

Some features of absence seizures are:
 
  • do not have an aura
  • starts at 5-8 years of age
  • usually last for few seconds
  • hyperventilation for 3-5 mins can precipitate the seizure
  • accompanied by flutter or upward rolling of eye



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3306, 3315.

questions.text:
After receiving treatment for the infection following a laparotomy, a woman arrives with a ruptured abdomen. The doctor decides to suture again. What kind of suture material should be utilized out of the following?
1. 

2. 

3. 

4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 

The above Clinical Picture is of Acute Wound dehiscence or Brust Abdomen.

It is disruption of a laparotomy wound, occurring usually between 5th and 8th postoperative day.
At around 7–10 days postoperatively, leakage of clear or serosanguineous fluid from the wound is the first ominous sign of incipient dehiscence.


Fig: Abdominal wound dehiscence in a transverse incision with evisceration of bowel

* [Extra Edge]: Burst Abdomen

  • Usually sutures opposing the deep layers, i.e. peritoneum and rectus sheath tear through, causing burst abdomen-Acute wound failure.
  • It is a mechanical wound failure due to various factors causing separation of the closed abdominal wound often with evisceration of the contents.
  • Modified Smead-Jones closure mainly used to prevent burst abdomen-it is interrupted specialised suture used in the closure of abdomen as single layer excluding the skin. Number one polyethylene or PDS suture material is used. 
  • Nonabsorbable monofilament suture material is used for the closure even though evidence says that there is no difference between synthetic absorbable like polyglactic acid and nonabsorbable monofilament suture. Nonabsorbable suture causes prolonged wound pain but is preferred in risk category patients.
  • Suture bite interval should be 1 cm but not more; suture length and wound length ratio should be 4:1 or more but not less.

* Audio Explanation:

* [Extra Edge]: Management of Burst Abdomen
 
  • Primary deep fascial closure-deep tension/retention sutures
  • Delayed closure with initial mesh wrap or pack/opposite or Bogota bag 
  • Topical negative (vacuum) pressure closure
  • Delayed skin closure or skin graft over the dehiscence wound once it granulates well.
  • Component separation technique with primary fascial closure
  • Placing drain in subcutaneous plane
  • Suitable antibiotic therapy; fluid management
  • Prevention of abdominal compartment syndrome, hematoma or intra-abdominal abscess formation or sepsis
  • Blood or blood product transfusion; nutrition supplementation

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 732.

questions.text:
After a laparoscopic hernia operation, the attending surgeon requests that you use 3-0 nylon to stitch the skin wound. Which set of tools are the ones you should use for suturing?


1. 


2. 


3.


 
4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 

A basic suturing kit includes the following:

  • A needle holder.
  • Toothed forceps, with a hook to handle tissue.
  • Fine suturing scissors.
  • The appropriate suturing material.

It’s very important to consider the suturing material that is used when performing the operation. In turn, choosing the right suturing material is made easy by considering the location and tension of the wound. Other equally important factors to consider about are the tensile and knot strength, handling of the wound, and tissue reactivity.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 1150.

questions.text:
For a patient with breast cancer, a surgical attending has finished a modified radical mastectomy. Subcuticular sutures are required to be used to close the wound. Which suture will you pick from this list?
1. 

2. 


3. 

4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 

Monocryl Sutures 3-0 or 4-0 with cutting needle are used in closure of MRM wounds by subcuticular suturing.
Option 2 showing Vicryl is showing round bodied needle , hence not correct.

* [Extra Edge]: Subcuticular suture
 
  • This technique is used in skin where a cosmetic appearance is important and where the skin edges may be approximated easily. The suture material used may be either absorbable or non-absorbable. For non-absorbable sutures, the ends may be secured using a collar and bead, or tied loosely over the wound. When absorbable sutures are used, the ends may be secured using a buried knot.
  • Small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound and then gently pulled together, thus approximating the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.
  • Monocryl Sutures 3-0 or 4-0 with cutting needle are mostly used in Subcuticular suture technique.
     

Fig: Subcuticular suture technique

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 108.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the image's suture material is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Degraded by enzymatic degradation
 
  • Catgut suture undergoes enzymatic degradation by proteolytic enzymes present in the body, allowing for gradual absorption and breakdown of the suture material over time.
  • This degradation process is important for minimizing tissue reaction and promoting wound healing.
  • Catgut is made from sheep submucosa .
  • Frequent Use of Catgut is: To Ligate superficial vessels, suture subcutaneous tissues. Stomas and other tissues that heal rapidly.
* [Extra Edge]:



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 106.

questions.text: How is the below pressure sore graded
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Grade 4

If underlying bone or muscle is visible as shown in this image, it becomes grade 4 bed sore.

* [Extra Edge]: Stages of Pressure Sores

+ Common sites for pressure injuries and ulcers-

Ischium, Greater trochanter, Sacrum, Heel, Malleolus, Occiput.


Fig: Stages of Pressure Sores

+ Management of Pressure Ulcers:
 

Non-operative management is generally considered for patients who have a stage 1 or 2 ulcer. No conservative treatment option has proved superior to other options.

This management is quite similar to preventative management and it involved:

  • Pressure Offloading
  • Enzymatic Wound debridement
  • Wound cover using adequate dressings. No dressings has been proven to be superior than other wound dressings
  • Antibiotic cover

Non-operative debridement includes autolytic, enzymatic, larval, mechanical. These types should be considered when there is no urgent clinical need for drainage or removal of devitalized tissue. The current evidence for this is mixed.

Patients with a stage 3 and stage 4 pressure ulcer should be considered for operative management.

Absolute indications for surgical debridement include necrosis, advancing cellulitis, crepitus, fluctuance, and/or sepsis secondary to ulcer-related infection. There should be a high index of suspicion of biofilm if present >4 weeks and lacks signs of any healing in the previous 2 weeks.

The choice of reconstruction depends on location, size, and depth of the pressure sore. Each choice has benefits and limitations, as discussed below.

  • Skin Grafting: often lack sufficient bulk and strength, which results in a high failure rate.
  • Fascio cutaneous Flaps: durable, well-vascularised but limited bulk may not be sufficient for deeper wounds. For example, a rotation flap or rhomboid flap.
  • Musculocutaneous flaps: provide more depth of coverage, higher bacterial resistance.
  • Free Tissue Transfer: This has been described by is less commonly utilised.

In these cases, patients may require a bladder and/or bowel diversion.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 35.

questions.text: In the image below, the patient is in the following position:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Reverse Trendelenburg position

The image given in the question is that of the Reverse Trendelenburg position as head is elevated.
Reverse Trendelenburg position: Used in Upper Abdominal surgeries like Lap Cholecystectomy, surgeries of head and neck. 

+ Objectives of correct surgical positioning:

Facilitate safe anaesthesia and surgery
Reduce adverse physiological insults
Optimise surgical exposure and ergonomics
Maintain patient’s dignity by avoiding unnecessary exposure

* [Extra Edge]: Supine position in OT table


This is the most common position for general surgical procedures. The patient’s arms may be placed by their side or extended to afford access to intravenous and arterial cannula. This is a versatile position and can be modified as follows:

Rose’s position: slight neck extension for head and neck surgery.
Shoulder and arm extended: to assist in axillary and breast surgery.
Trendelenburg position: the head end of the table is tilted down on an incline with the patient’s knees slightly flexed. This is often used in pelvic procedures and when resuscitating a patient in shock.
Reverse Trendelenburg position: the head end of the table is tilted up, thereby placing the head higher than the feet.

+ In advanced laparoscopic surgery, exaggerated and frequent position changes during the course of the operation are used to enhance surgical exposure. An excellent example would be in laparoscopic resection of the rectum, wherein the table is tilted to the right to aid in left colon mobilisation; a neutral or reverse Trendelenburg position is used to mobilise the transverse colon; and pelvic dissection is completed with a steep Trendelenburg position. This can only be achieved if the patient is well positioned and secured.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 96.
