questions.text: What is the flow rate through the specified cannula?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 96 ml/min

The given cannula is a green cannula which typically has flow rates of 90-105 ml/min.
Highly controversial question but mark 96ml/min if asked in INI-CET since the cannula given below is from AIIMS, Delhi itself. 

      

In a patient with massive bleeding, there is always a risk of the patient going into shock and the widest bore cannula available showed be used for cannulation.
The ATLS guidelines recommend securing intravenous access with two large-bore cannulas (14-16G) in a patient needing resuscitation. 


Mnemonic for Colour coding of Cannula-
Oh Great God Please Bless Your People
Oh- Orange- 14G
Great- Grey- 16G
God- Green- 18G
Please- Pink- 20G
Bless- Blue- 22G
Your- Yellow- 24G
People- Purple- 26G



Reference: ATLS® Advanced Trauma Life Support®, American College of Surgeons, 10th Edition, Page No 52.

questions.text: A drain as shown in the given image was placed in operative bed post right sided modified radicle mastectomy. What type of drain is it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Closed

A surgical drain is a tube used to remove pus, blood or other fluids from a wound. The given image shows a Romovac drain which is a closed type of drain. There are 3 types of drains :

Closed drains : Utilise suction action for drainage. 

Semi - Open drain : Utilise the principle of capillary action. 

Open drain : Utilise the effect of gravity for drainage.

* [Extra Edge]: Current role of drain placement in gastrointestinal surgery


+ Avoid routine drain placement following

Colonic surgery

Small bowel resections
Hepatic resections
Cholecystectomy

+ Consider routine drain placement following

Oesophageal surgery

Major pancreatic resection

+ Selective use of drains following


Rectal surgery
Gastric resections


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 115.

questions.text: Methylene blue is injected in the peritumoral area as seen in the provided image. Which of the following procedures is being carried out?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Sentinel lymph node biopsy

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is a surgical procedure in which a single lymph node or a small group of lymph nodes are identified and removed to determine whether the cancer has spread beyond the primary tumor to involve regional lymph nodes. 

The procedure utilizes methylene blue, which is injected near the primary tumor. The dye reaches the sentinel node (the first node in the chain that receives the lymphatic drainage from the tumor) which can then be precisely identified and removed through lymphatic mapping.

The sentinel lymph node is then examined microscopically for the presence of cancer cells; if none are found, then it is assumed that the cancer has not spread to the lymph nodes and further surgery may not be necessary.


Fig: fluorescein dye – the fluorescent sentinel lymph node is seen with blue light


Fig: blue dye (methylene blue) – blue sentinel lymph nodes and lymphatics are seen in the axilla. Sentinel lymph nodes are marked with an arrow

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 937.

questions.text: What is the technique illustrated in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Sentinel lymph node biopsy

The technique depicted in the image is sentinel lymph node biopsy using methylene blue dye technique. 

Sentinel LN: First LN which receives lymph directly from tumor.

Sentinel node biopsy identifies the first few lymph nodes into which a tumor drains. The surgeon uses a harmless dye as in this image.  The nodes are removed and tested for signs of cancer. Sentinel node biopsy is a procedure to see if cancer has spread.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 936.

questions.text: You were contacted by a 56-year-old woman who had been diagnosed with breast cancer. The immunohistochemical staining of her tissue revealed the following. Her2 Neu is negative. What can you say about the patient's prognosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Poor prognosis
 
  • The IHC profile depicts a triple negative breast cancer, i.e. a Basal like profile as ER,PR and Her 2 are all negative.
  • Positive staining is seen as brownish dots over the slide.
  • These negative results mean that the growth of the cancer is not supported by the hormones estrogen and progesterone, nor by the presence of too many HER2 receptors.
  • Therefore, triple-negative breast cancer does not respond to hormonal therapy (such as tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors) or therapies that target HER2 receptors, such as Herceptin (trastuzumab). In general, survival rates tend to be lower with TNBC compared to other forms of breast cancer.

Fig: Molecular classification of breast cancer

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 931.

choices.text: TRAM flap base on superior epigastric vessels
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery
TRAM free flap based on superior and inferior epigastric vessels
Lower Abdominal Fat based inferior epigastric vessels

questions.text: What flap is used in breast reconstruction
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery



When comparing satisfaction rates among different autologous techniques, deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap reconstruction seems to provide the highest rates of well-being.
Cost-effective analyses have been performed to compare autologous and implant-based techniques.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 858.

questions.text:
After 3 months, the patient's upper limbs were still swollen from the mastectomy for cancer breast.
What exactly is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Upper limb lymphedema
 
  • In this case upper limb lymphedema develops after 3 months post mastectomy.
  • Upper limb lymphangiosarcoma develops in a chronically edematous limb which usually takes around 10 years to develop. It is known as stewart-treves syndrome.
  • Lymphedema-associated angiosarcoma (Stewart-Treves) develops on an extremity ipsilateral to an axillary lymphadenectomy. It appears on the upper, medial arm as a violaceous plaque in an individual with nonpitting edema and has a poor survival.
  • Radiation-induced angiosarcoma occurs 4 to 25 years after radiation therapy for benign and malignant conditions.

Fig: StewartTreves Syndrome Involving Chronic Lymphedema after Mastectomy of Breast Cancer

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 535.

questions.text: A female patient in her 60s complains of burning & itching in one breast. The following image is visible following a clinical evaluation. The following statements about the ailment are all accurate, with the exception of which one:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) S-100 antigen positive on immunostaining
 
  • The clinical evaluation and the image suggest Paget's disease of the breast, a rare form of breast cancer that affects the nipple and areola.
  • While Paget's disease of the breast is associated with underlying invasive breast cancer in most cases, immunostaining for S-100 antigen is typically negative in Paget's cells. Paget's disease shows positive immunostaining with carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), while superficial spreading melanoma is positive for S-100 antigen.
  • Other accurate statements include external signs if underlying invasive cancer, presentation with a mass in more than 50% of cases.
  • Depending on the type and extent of underlying malignancy, it can be treated with lumpectomy or mastectomy.

Fig: Nipple erosion in early Paget’s disease

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 924.

questions.text: A young woman came in with a bulge in the middle of her neck, as can be seen below, which movements with swallowing and tongue protrusion. Its size has remained unchanged throughout the last year. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thyroglossal cyst

Thyroglossal cyst is the only cause of midline neck swelling which moves with both swallowing and tongue protrusion.

Thyroglossal Cyst
It is a fibrous cyst that presents as a regular neck mass or a lump.
They are the most common cause of midline neck masses and are generally Subhyoid in location.
The mass on the neck moves during swallowing or on protrusion of the tongue because of its attachment to the tongue (foramen of cecum) via the tract of thyroid descent.

* [Extra Edge]: Treatment Of Thyroglossal Cyst

Treatment must include excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, which involves removal of the body of the hyoid bone and the suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum, together with a core of tissue on either side. This operation is known as Sistrunk’s operation and minimises recurrence, most notably from small side branches of the thyroglossal tract.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 806.

questions.text: The method for thyroid examination is shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lahey's method

Lahey's technique for palpating the thyroid is demonstrated in the image above.
The lobes are pushed to one side for palpation according to Lahey's method. The left hand should be used to push the left lobe laterally while the right hand is used to palpate the lobe.
CRILE'S METHOD- This method involves placing the thumb on the thyroid gland and asking the patient to swallow. Small thyroid nodules within the thyroid gland can be palpated by this method.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 454.

questions.text:
A young boy who had been experiencing stomach pain, vomiting, and a fever arrived at the emergency room. On examination, he was febrile with a pulse rate
of 104 beats per minute. The resident was eliciting the sign shown below. Can you identify the sign?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) McBurney’s point tenderness

The point over the right side of the abdomen that is one-third of the way between the anterior superior iliac spine and the umbilicus is known as McBurney's point. This is close to where the appendix is most frequently found.

* Audio Explanation:
 


1- Mcburney Point
2- Umblicus
3- ASIS



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1339.

questions.text: A patient with abdominal pain for 2 hours arrives to the casualty, and the following X-ray is obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Pneumoperitoneum
 
  • The X-ray shows air under the diaphragm, which indicates the presence of free air within the peritoneal cavity, known as the pneumoperitoneum.
  • Pneumoperitoneum is most commonly caused by a perforated viscus, such as a ruptured hollow organ (e.g., stomach, intestine) or iatrogenic injury during surgery.

Fig: Pneumoperitoneum on upright chest X-ray in patient with perforated ulcer



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1127.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis of the given gross specimen:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Polyps in gallbladder

The diagnosis of the given gross specimen is gallbladder polyp.

Polypoid lesions of the gallbladder include:
 
  1. Cholesterol polyps : Have a characteristic echogenic pedunculated appearance on USG.
  1. Adenomatous polyp : May lead to malignancy. Lack of transmural invasion on USG.

Cholesterosis of GB

Strawberry gallbladder 



Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 650.

questions.text: Mention the diagnosis of the following Barium X-ray.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2. CA esophagus
 
  • The barium swallow has shown an irregular filling defect and narrowing with shouldered margins which may indicate the presence of either squamous cell carcinoma in the upper two-thirds of the esophagus, or adenocarcinoma in the lower third.
  • A further upper GI endoscopy and biopsy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. If found to be suitable for potentially curative therapies, staging investigations should be done to ensure that the cancer has not spread to other parts of the body (CT scan).
  • If the cancer is localized, further staging tests should be performed to assess the loco-regional stage (endoscopic ultrasonography, endoscopic ultrasound +/- laparoscopy). These tests will allow for appropriate treatment planning and management of the cancer.
  • In Achalasia cardia- Bird's beak deformity is seen. 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1136.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is admitted with intussusception and stomach pain. Intestinal polyps were discovered during the endoscopy. Below is a histopathological image from a biopsy that was collected. What kind of polyp is that
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. Hamartomatous
 
  • The most common type of polyp in children is a hamartoma or juvenile polyp accounting for more than 95% of polyps found.
  • Juvenile polyps are typically found in 2 to 6 year old boys and girls but can be found in younger and older children up to about 10 years of age.
  • Hammartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract are rare compared to other types of GI polyps, yet they are the most common type of polyp in children.
  • The symptoms are usually rectal bleeding, abdominal pain, obstipation, anaemia, and/or small bowel obstruction.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1310.

questions.text: An abdominal ache had been present for several days in a 45-year-old patient with known peptic ulcer disease. He has been complaining of abdominal distension and escalating pain for the past two hours. This image was obtained using an X-ray. What is the next course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. IV fluids and emergency laparotomy
 
  • The given history along with the presence of air under the diaphragm as seen in the X-Ray are suggestive of perforation causing pneumoperitoneum which might have occurred as a complication of peptic ulcer causing perforation in the gastric wall.
  • The next step in management should be iv fluids and emergency laparotomy.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 137.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who is having increasing trouble swallowing both food and liquids is put through a barium study. The image is seen here. What is the next stage in the patient's care?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  is 1. Upper G.I Endoscopy + Manometry

Taking into consideration the age, symptoms, history and the X-ray which shows Bird-Beak appearance, the most probable diagnosis is Achalasia Cardia.

It is characterized by failure of organized esophageal peristalsis, which results in food stasis and frequently noticeable esophageal dilatation and poor relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter due to damage to the Auerbach plexus and vagus nerve. 

To look for constrictions and other causes of Achalasia cardia plus for confirming the diagnosis, we do upper GI endoscopy with Manometry (which shows pressure at the level of Gastro-esophageal junction).

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1122.

questions.text:
In order to stop esophageal varicose haemorrhage, which of the following is used?
A.
B.
C.
D.
questions.solution:
The given tubes are :
  • Sengstaken Blakemore Tube
  • Minnesota Tube
  • OGD Scope
  • Gastro Fiber Endoscope
All of the above are used for controlling variceal bleed.
Sengstaken blake more tube has 2 ballons and 3 channels 1 for gastric aspiration &other for for inflating balloons, Minnesota has 4 channels one for gastric and esophageal aspiration, through scope we can ligate the vessel and stop the bleeding.


Fig: Oesophageal and gastric balloon tamponade with a Sengstaken–Blakemore or Minnesota tube.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1205.

questions.text: Which surgery is depicted in the picture?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. Thiersch wiring

The Thiersch surgery (anal encirclement) is usually carried out on individuals who are elderly or who are at high risk for rectal prolapse.
It is a straightforward operation that narrows the Anus using a suture or prosthetic.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1399.

choices.text: Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection is seen

questions.text: The image depicts a male patient. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection is seen
 
  • This is a case of Necrotizing fasciitis which involves the perineal region.
  • Synergistic gangrene (aerobic + anaerobic) is seen
  • Testes are not involved in this condition due to the presence of dual blood supply.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1416.

choices.text: Patey's surgery is done for the treatment

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with a slowly expanding, painless swelling above the mandibular angle. Swelling moves about and has variable consistency. Regarding the swelling, all of the following are accurate, except :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Has uniphasic cellular pattern
 
  • The given clinical scenario and image depict a likely case of parotid tumor (option A), likely to be a pleomorphic adenoma.
  • The parotid tail is the most common site (Option B) for parotid gland tumors to occur. It is the portion of the parotid gland that extends backward and wraps around the mandible.
  • However, the swelling in this case does not exhibit a uniphasic cellular pattern.
  • A uniphasic cellular pattern refers to the appearance of cells in the tumor, and it is not observed in this scenario.
  • Surgery is the mainstay of treatment - Superficial parotidectomy (Patey's operation) (option C).
  • Radiotherapy is considered in high-grade malignancies demonstrating extra-glandular disease, perineural invasion, direct invasion of surrounding tissue, or regional metastases.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: Which of the following is represented by the colon's appearance on the barium study, as seen in the illustration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ulcerative colitis
 
  • The barium enema shows the lead pipe appearance seen in ulcerative colitis.
  • Ulcerative colitis diffusely involves the mucosa and submucosa of the colon.
  • There is a complete loss of haustral markings in the diseased section of the colon, and the organ appears smooth-walled and cylindrical; giving it the appearance of a lead pipe.

* Barium Enema Appearance: 


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1163.

questions.text: Identify the region marked in the picture that represents zone 4 of retroperitoneal hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Marked region ‘A’ represents the zone 4 of retroperitoneal hemorrhage.
The retroperitoneum is usually divided into three parts based on site of injury. Some authors also describe a 4th zone, i.e. the portal and retro hepatic area.
Zone 1 (central) extends from the esophageal hiatus to the sacral promontory.
Zone 2 (lateral) extends from the lateral diaphragm to the iliac crest.
Zone 3 (pelvic) is confined to the retroperitoneal space of the pelvic bowl.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 382.

choices.text: Damage control surgery and mesh closure of abdomen

questions.text: A 30-year-old male who was injured in a car accident arrived at the trauma centre. His BP is 90/56 mm Hg, his pulse is 150/min, his oxygen saturation is 86%, and he has a Glasgow Coma Scale of 8. The patient had several wounds upon examination, and FAST shows haemorrhage in every quadrant. He underwent surgery, and the photos from the recovery are displayed here. Which of the following statements best sums up the two images?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Damage control surgery and mesh closure of abdomen
 
  • The images show an open abdomen with the use of a temporary abdominal closure (TAC) device, such as a vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) system.
  • This technique is often employed in damage control surgery, which involves controlling bleeding and contamination rapidly to stabilize the patient.
  • The TAC device helps prevent abdominal compartment syndrome and allows for subsequent definitive closure of the abdomen using a mesh.

Indications for temporary abdominal closure include:
  • Damage control (severe hemorrhage, hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis).
  • Abdominal compartment syndrome
  • Planned re-look laparotomy
  • Severe intra-abdominal sepsis
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 385.

choices.text: Immediately shift the patient to OT for thoracotomy.
Put a large bore needle in the 5th ICS and followed by ICD in 5th ICS

questions.text: After an RTA, a 24-year-old male patient arrives at the emergency room. He can't speak complete sentences. On auscultation, a hyper resonant note can be heard on the right side of the chest. This image is of a chest X-ray. What is the patient's initial course of treatment
questions.solution:
According to the information provided and the provided X-ray, there is right-sided hyperlucency and a mediastinal shift to the left.
The diagnosis of tension pneumothorax is most likely.
It is an emergency, in which needle thoracotomy needs to be done in the 5th intercostal space, followed by ICD, inserted in the triangle of safety.
Pneumothorax: Refers to collapse of lung due to entry of air in the space between chest wall and lung. Causes: Trauma to the chest ,Ruptured bullae, Lung disease ,Mechanical ventilation

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 374.

questions.text: A female patient aged 28, who also had dysmenorrhea, appeared with lower abdomen pain. Laparoscopic examination revealed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Chocolate cyst
  • It is brought on by endometriosis and develops when a microscopic patch of endometrial tissue, which is the mucous membrane that lines the interior of the uterine wall, bleeds, sheds, gets transplanted, and grows and enlarges inside the ovaries.
  • Over the course of months and years, the blood thickens and turns brown. When it ruptures, the substance leaks onto the surface of the uterus, bladder, intestine, and the corresponding gaps between them, as well as into the pelvis.
  • In other cases given in option there would be bulky ovaries. 

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1802.

questions.text: A patient's complex kidney cyst was unintentionally discovered on ultrasound, and as a result, he received a CT for an insurance workup. What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Because most angiomyolipomas contain substantial amounts of adipose tissue, therefore it appears hypodense in the CECT image.

US shows a bright echogenic mass lesion on account of the high fat content. CT scan shows an intralesional fat density of –15 to –20 Hounsfield units (HU) within the mass, which is the hallmark of an angiomyolipoma radiological diagnosis. Management depends upon the size of the tumour, the risk of haemorrhage (Wonderlich syndrome) and the symptoms.

Angiomyolipomas are seen in Tuberous Sclerosis complex. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1481.

questions.text: An ultrasound was requested by a 65-year-old male banker in order to renew his health insurance. A complicated cyst was discovered in the right kidney, and hence underwent a CT. The CT scan image is shown below. The most likely possibility is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Renal cell carcinoma
 
  • The CT scan image shows a solid mass with irregular borders in the right kidney, which is highly suspicious for renal cell carcinoma.
  • Renal cell carcinoma is the most common type of kidney cancer, accounting for approximately 85% of all cases.
  • Contrast-enhanced CT is the investigation of choice for RCC. On CT, small lesions enhance homogeneously, whereas larger lesions have irregular enhancement due to areas of necrosis.
  • The clear cell subtype may show much stronger enhancement is a differential for angiomyolipoma. Below is the CT of Angiomyolipoma.




Other options:
 
  • Oncocytoma and angiomyolipoma are benign renal tumors that usually have well-defined borders and a characteristic appearance on imaging.
  • Perinephric cysts are fluid-filled sacs located adjacent to the kidney and appear as simple cystic lesions on imaging.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1482.

questions.text: A Kasai portoenterostomy was performed on a toddler to treat extra-hepatic biliary atresia. Which of the following is not related to this condition in addition to the relationships shown in the provided image?
questions.solution:
• Biliary atresia, a rare disease affecting newborns is characterized by inflammatory obturation of intra- and extra-hepatic bile ducts. This affliction is estimated to occur in 1 in 5000 to 12,000 infants in various regions.
  • It is often associated with congenital malformations such as a double spleen and/or asplenia, absence of the inferior vena cava, and intestinal malformation.
  • In some cases, patients have additional malformations including polysplenia, preduodenal portal vein, and intrahepatic vena cava. Without treatment, progressive cirrhosis and death may occur by two years of age. 
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 383.

questions.text:
Which of the following four types of figures can be found most frequently?
1. 
2. 
3. 
4.
questions.solution:
Correct option 1:Vaginal hydrocoele
  • Congenital Vaginal hydrocoele is the most common type of hydrocoele.
  • Vaginal hydrocoele results when the processus vaginalis remains patent, allowing fluid from the peritoneum to accumulate in the scrotum. 
Other options given :
1-Vaginal hydrocoele (very common)
2-Infantile hydrocoele
3-Communicating hydrocoele
4-Encysted hydrocoele of the cord

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 257.

choices.text: Pneumatic compression stocking to prevent the DVT

questions.text: What is the device listed below:
questions.solution:
The given device is pneumatic compression stocking, used to prevent DVT.

Intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) devices are used to help prevent blood clots in the deep veins of the legs. The devices use cuffs around the legs that fill with air and squeeze your legs. This increases blood flow through the veins of your legs and helps prevent blood clots.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 998.

questions.text: Which type of ulcer is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows a punch out ulcer on the plantar aspect of foot along pressure points which is seen in neuropathic ulcer. 
  • callosity can be seen surrounding the ulcer margin.
  • Arterial ulcer will also have punched out appearance, but is seen in dorsum of foot. 
  • Venous ulcer has sloping edges with peripheral bluish discoloration, commonly seen in Gaiter's area above medial malleolus. 
  • Tubercular ulcer is characterized by undermined edges. 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 577.

questions.text: A patient appears with dilated veins while having no complaints. What CEAP staging corresponds to the picture below?
questions.solution:
CEAP classification:
  • C0 - No visible or palpable varicose veins
  • C1 - Telangectasia Thread veins / Spider veins / Broken veins
  • C2A - Varicose veins without any symptoms (Asymptomatic)
  • C2S - Varicose veins with symptoms
  • C3 - Swollen ankle (oedema) due to varicose veins
  • C4A - Eczema
  • C4B- Atrophe blanche or lipodermatosclerosis
  • C4C- Corona phlebactesia 
  • C5 - Healed venous leg ulcer
  • C6 - Venous leg ulcer
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1030.

questions.text:
Right-leg claudication discomfort is reported by a male smoker.
This angiography is displayed. What comes after this in terms of management?
questions.solution:
As per the reconstructed plates, part of right SFA is completely occluded as compared to Left side.
If it is getting filled by collaterals and there is absence of any thrombus in detailed review of angiography then patient is a candidate for endo vascular stenting.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1004.

questions.text: Chronic venous insufficiency has been documented in a patient over the age of 65. The patient is presenting the following leg lesion. what is the CEAP classification's clinical stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: C6
 
  • The CEAP classification system is used to describe the clinical severity of chronic venous insufficiency.
  • Stage C6 indicates the presence of venous ulcers, which are non-healing wounds associated with chronic venous hypertension and impaired venous return.
  • Other stages in the CEAP classification include C0 (no visible or palpable signs of venous disease) to C5 (advanced skin changes without ulceration).



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1030.

questions.text: Which flap was used to accomplish chest wall closure in the patient depicted below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap
 
  • Based on the provided image, the chest wall closure was achieved using a pectoralis major myocutaneous flap (Option C).
  • The pectoralis major myocutaneous flap is a versatile reconstructive option commonly used for chest wall defects, particularly following tumor resection or trauma.
  • The other options mentioned, such as transversely oriented rectus abdominis muscle flap (Option A), vertically oriented rectus abdominis muscle flap (Option B), and serratus anterior muscle flap (Option D), are different types of muscle flaps that can be used for various reconstructive purposes but are not specifically indicated for chest wall closure.


Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 651.

questions.text:
Lymphadenopathy and dermatitis in a 7-year-old child. Skull X-ray below

Which of the following medications is most frequently used in this situation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the X-ray image showing punched out lytic lesion is s/o LCH. 

The current standard of care for patients with high-risk LCH is 1 year of therapy with vinblastine/prednisone/mercaptopurine, based on the LCH-III study.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presented to the OPD complaining of a mildly uncomfortable swelling on his scalp for the past three months.
She keeps a dog for a pet. What diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• A fungal ringworm infection of the scalp's hair follicles (and occasionally the beard) that may be accompanied by a subsequent bacterial infection can cause kerion, an acute inflammatory condition.
  • It is caused by Trichophyton verrucosum and Microsporum canis. 
  • Mainly caused by fungus infecting animals, in the question pet dog is also mentioned. 
  • It typically affects children and manifests as elevated, spongy lesions.
  • This honeycomb-shaped inflammatory reaction causes excruciating agony and causes deep suppurative sores on the scalp. Pupillating follicles may be noticed.
Reference: Nakagawa H, Nishihara M, Nakamura T. Kerion and tinea capitis. IDCases. 2018 Jun 28;14:e00418. doi: 10.1016/j.idcr.2018.e00418. PMID: 29988774; PMCID: PMC6031098.

questions.text: What procedure makes use of the instrument indicated in the diagram?
questions.solution:
Different kinds of bone marrow biopsy needles are depicted in the diagram.

Reference: Rindy LJ, Chambers AR. Bone Marrow Aspiration and Biopsy. [Updated 2023 May 29]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559232/

questions.text: What is the name of the given instrument is used for harvesting the graft from healthy area in split thickness skin graft?
questions.solution:
• The name of the given instrument is Humby knife, which is used for harvesting the graft from healthy area in split thickness skin graft.
  • The Humby – Braithwaite Dermatome (Skin Graft Knife) is used to collect a slice of healthy skin from donor site to perform a skin graft on a site with tissue loss.
  • Donor sites for the harvest of skin graft include the lumbar and gluteal regions (thick skin), the thighs, and the arms (thin skin).

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 317.

questions.text: What is the name of the given instrument?
questions.solution:
Name of the given instrument is chemoport, which is an implantable venous access device used to facilitate chemotherapy administration.

Chemoport is an implantable vascular access device lo provide repeated access to the vascular system for the delivery of medications, intravenous fluids, parenteral nutrition solutions and blood products.

Reference: Mittal GS, Sundriyal D, Naik NB, Sehrawat A. Totally Implantable Venous Access Device (Chemoport) in Oncology: Study of 168 Polyurethane Chemoport Catheter System. South Asian J Cancer. 2021 Dec 31;10(4):261-264. doi: 10.1055/s-0041-1739041. PMID: 34984207; PMCID: PMC8719977.

questions.text: What is the given instrument used for?
questions.solution:
It is a  procedure in which a thin, hollow needle is inserted into the lower part of the spine to collect a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

questions.text: Which of these is not true about the procedure in which this needle is used?
questions.solution:
• This is Bone marrow aspiration needle / Jamshedi's needle. So, PC < 40k is not a contraindication for this procedure. All other options are correct about BMA.
  • Absolute contraindications to bone marrow biopsy and aspiration include severe bleeding diatheses such as severe hemophilia or severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy.
  • Thrombocytopenia is not a contraindication, and platelet transfusion can be performed if clinically warranted prior to the procedure, commonly performed if platelet counts are below 20,000 cells/microliter.
  • Thrombocytopenia is rather in indication for performing bone marrow biopsy. *  CONTRAINDICATIONS FOR BM BIOPSY:
  • Hemorrhagic disorders such DIC, concurrent anticoagulant usage, and congenital coagulation factor deficits (such as hemophilia).
  • The most frequent and dangerous occurrence is bleeding, especially in thrombocytopenic patients and those taking aspirin, warfarin, or heparin.
  • In these patients, a BMA or BMTB should only be performed if it is absolutely necessary. If this is the case, factor replacement or stopping anticoagulation should be considered before the surgery, and the patient should be thoroughly watched for 24 hours afterward. BMA is not contraindicated in cases of severe thrombocytopenia as long as the site is kept under pressure for an extended period of time to stop bleeding.
  •  When a bone marrow biopsy is recommended for obese individuals with severe thrombocytopenia, it is better to administer a platelet transfusion to increase the platelet count to > 15 x 10^9/L.
  • Other potential issues include persistent discomfort, a fracture (related to osteoporosis), and damage to nearby structures (such as damage to arteries).
  • At the sampling site, there may be skin infections or recent radiation therapy.
Reference: 
Rindy LJ, Chambers AR. Bone Marrow Aspiration and Biopsy. [Updated 2023 May 29]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559232/

questions.text: A woman who is 36 weeks pregnant is admitted to your ward. She is depicted in the illustration lying supine during the morning rounds. She complains of faintness and lightheadedness. Which syndrome is pictured below?
questions.solution:
• Supine hypotensive syndrome/Supine vena cava syndrome (also referred to as inferior vena cava compression syndrome) is caused when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava when a pregnant woman is in a supine position, leading to decreased venous return centrally.
  • That's why pregnant women are advised to lie in left lateral position.
 

Supine Hypotension Syndrome is a condition that can occur during pregnancy, particularly in the later stages, when the heavy uterus compresses the inferior vena cava (IVC) while the woman is lying flat on her back. This compression reduces venous return to the heart, leading to decreased cardiac output and hypotension.

  • Symptoms: Dizziness, lightheadedness, weakness, nausea, palpitations, and in severe cases, fainting (syncope).
  • Mechanism: Lying supine compresses the IVC, impairing blood flow back to the heart.
  • Risk Factors: More common after 20 weeks of pregnancy; overweight women may be at higher risk.
  • Management: Shift to a left lateral position or elevate the right hip to relieve pressure on the IVC.
  • Prevention: Pregnant women should avoid lying flat on their backs for prolonged periods, especially in the third trimester.
 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 64.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Vulval Hematoma
The picture is self explanatory and depicts a Vulval Hematoma.
 
  • A tense, tender swelling of varying size rapidly develops, encroaches on the vaginal lumen, and causes overlying skin or epithelium to become ecchymotic. However, symptoms of pelvic pressure, pain, or inability to void should prompt evaluation.
  • Vulvovaginal hematomas are managed according to their size, location, duration since delivery, and expansion. If bleeding ceases, then small- to moderate-sized hematomas may be treated expectantly until absorbed. Cool packs and analgesics are supportive care, and an inability to void merits catheter drainage. But, if pain is severe or if the hematoma continues to enlarge, surgical exploration is preferable.
  • For repair, an incision is made at the point of maximal distention, blood and clots are evacuated, and bleeding points ligated.


Bartholin gland cysts  are cysts of the Bartholin gland, found in the posterolateral inferior third of the vagina and are associated with the labia majora.

questions.text: Name the  HSG finding displayed below:
questions.solution:
This is a HSG picture showing single Uterine horn suggestive of Unicornuate Uterus.

Mullerian abnormalities :- 
Type 1 :- MRHK or Mullerian agenesis 
Type 2 :- Unicornuate uterus -1 sided mullerian duct develops - never leads to transverse lie (PYQ)
Type 3 :- Didelphic uterus - lack of fusion of both the mullerian ducts 
Type 4:- Bicornuate uterus - incomplete fusion 
-angle b/w 2 horns more than 75 degrees 
Type 5:- Septate uterus - septa which forms after fusion fails to resolve 
- mc type 
- mc type causing infertility 
-angle less than 75 degress 
- Treatment - metroplasty ,hysteroscopic septal resection(PYQ)
Type 6 :- Arcuate uterus - flat topped 
- no anatomical abnormality 
Type 7:- DES related anomalies - hypoplastic uterus ,T shaped uterus

Diagnosis :- 
1. Hysterosalpingography 
2. IOC = 3D USG 
3. Gold Standard - MRI 
4. BEST - Laparoscopy + Hysteroscopy(PYQ)

questions.text: Name the function of the instrument:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. laparoscopic sterilization
 
  • A Falope ring (or Y-ligation) is a ligature that is applied to the fallopian tubes during laparoscopic sterilization, a type of birth control. The laparoscopic ring applicator is a device used to quickly and accurately apply a Falope ring onto the fallopian tubes.
  • The applicator helps to ensure that each Falope ring is placed exactly in the correct location.
  • The device is made up of a long handle and the actual applicator, which consists of two arms that hold the Falope ring in its central chamber. The arms of the applicator are inserted into the fallopian tubes and then the Falope ring is released from the central chamber, applying the ligature to the fallopian tubes.
  • The device is designed in such a way that it can be used in any standard laparoscopy procedure.




Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 635.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman complains of vaginal discharge and localised itching. The results of a Pap test revealed the following image. What might be the cause of this infection?
questions.solution:
Gardenella vaginalis
The history of vaginal itching with presence of CLUE CELLS indicate Bacterial vaginosis causes by Gardenella vaginalis.
Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by adherent gram-negative rods, observed in vaginal smears from women with bacterial vaginosis.
AMSEL CRITERIA IS USED FOR DIAGNOSIS OF BV

Amsel Criteria for Diagnosis of BV: Three of the following four criteria must be met. Establishes accurate diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis in 90% of affected women.

1) Homogeneous, non-clumping vaginal discharge (color and amount may vary)

2) Amine (fishy) odor when potassium hydroxide solution is added to vaginal secretions (commonly) called the "whiff test")

3) Presence of clue cells (greater than 20%) on microscopy

4) Vaginal pH greater than 4.5

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 330, 331.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who has been married for two years goes to an infertility clinic. She received HMG. She had dyspnea and stomach pain during treatment. The image below appears in her USG reports. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a condition that can occur in women undergoing fertility treatments, particularly those involving hormone medications to stimulate the ovaries, such as in vitro fertilization (IVF) or ovulation induction. Here’s an overview of the condition:

Causes:
- Hormonal Treatments: OHSS is primarily caused by the use of injectable hormones (like gonadotropins) to stimulate the ovaries, leading to the development of multiple follicles.
- Individual Factors: Some women may be more susceptible due to factors like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or previous episodes of OHSS.

Symptoms:
OHSS symptoms can range from mild to severe and typically manifest as follows:
- Mild Symptoms
  - Abdominal bloating
  - Mild abdominal pain
  - Nausea
  - Vomiting
  - Diarrhea

Moderate to Severe Symptoms:
  - Severe abdominal pain
  - Rapid weight gain (more than 2.2 kg or 5 lbs in a few days)
  - Shortness of breath
  - Oliguria 
  - Swelling in the abdomen or legs
  - Thrombosis 

Diagnosis:
Diagnosis is usually made based on clinical symptoms and may be confirmed with imaging tests (such as ultrasound) to assess ovarian size and fluid accumulation in the abdomen.

Treatment:
Treatment depends on the severity of OHSS:
- Mild Cases: Often managed with rest, hydration, and over-the-counter pain relief.
- Moderate to Severe Cases: May require hospitalization, intravenous (IV) fluids, and monitoring. In severe cases, procedures to remove excess fluid from the abdomen (paracentesis) may be necessary.

Prevention:
- Careful Monitoring: Monitoring hormone levels and ovarian response during fertility treatments can help prevent OHSS.
- Adjusting Treatment Protocols: Using lower doses of hormones or alternative medications may reduce the risk.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 223.
Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 223, 454-457.

  • Management if tubes are normal: To assess the male factors and ovarian factors for infertility.
Causes of tubal block:
  • Physiological spasm
  • Genital TB
  • Salpingitis
  • Salpingitis isthmica nodosa
  • Benign polyps within the tubal lumen
  • tubal endometriosis and intratubal mucous debris.

questions.text: An operation was performed on a patient who had an adnexal mass, and the subsequent tumour was excised. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Mature teratoma
 
  • The image shows hair with debacle material suggestive of a Dermoid cyst ( mature teratoma)
  • It is a type of germ cell tumor that is usually made up of several different types of tissue, such as hair, muscle, and bone.

MATURE CYSTIC TERATOMA (DERMOID CYSTS): 

• Most common germ cell neoplasm
• Well-differentiated derivations from at least two of the three germ cell layers
• Younger age group (mean patient age, 30 years)
• Asymptomatic
• Grow slowly
• Bilateral in about 10% of cases



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 445, 446.

questions.text: In an endoscopic examination of the uterus, the woman who had complained of AUB had the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Leiomyoma
This picture represents a case of multiple uterine fibroids.

Gross/Endoscopic appearance of Fibroid: 
 
  • The uterus is enlarged; the shape is distorted by multiple nodular growth of varying sizes. Occasionally, there may be uniform enlargement of the uterus by a single fibroid. The feel is firm.
  • Cut surface of the tumor is smooth and whitish. The cut section, in the absence of degenerative changes, shows features of whorled appearance and trabeculation. These are due to the intermingling of fibrous tissues with the muscle bundles.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 156, 157.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of the HPE given below?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Malignant teratoma
 
  • Malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary composed of cells from the three germ layers, containing variable amounts of mature and immature tissue
  • Affects mostly young females < 20 years old
  • Grossly solid ovarian tumor mass with necrosis and hemorrhage on cut sections
  • Grading is performed based on the amount of immature neuroepithelium
  • Can have associated nodal or peritoneal gliomatosis (presence of mature neural tissue), which increases risk of recurrence
  • Grading and stage are the most important factors for prognosis, greatly improved after chemotherapy
Histopathological findings in Malignant Teratoma:
 
  • Immature Tissue Elements: Presence of primitive neuroectodermal tissue (neuroblasts, rosettes) and immature mesenchymal or epithelial tissue.
  • Malignant Components: Somatic malignancies such as squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, or sarcomas within the teratoma.
  • High-Grade Features: Cellular pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, increased mitotic activity.
  • Necrosis and Hemorrhage: Common in malignant areas, reflecting the aggressive nature of the tumor.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 461.

questions.text: Which is the instrument shown?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Esophageal temperature probe
 
  • Esophageal temperature probes are used to monitor core body temperatures in patients receiving anesthesia. The probe is advanced either through the nasal passage or oral cavity, before following a similar path to a nasogastric tube.
  • Other images: Pulmonary artery catheter, also known as a Swan-Ganz catheter or right heart catheter, is a balloon-tipped catheter that is inserted into a pulmonary artery in a procedure known as pulmonary artery catheterization or right heart catheterization.

   

  • NAVA catheter – Neurally adjusted ventilatory assist is a mode of mechanical ventilation. NAVA delivers assistance in proportion to and in synchrony with the patient's respiratory efforts, as reflected by an electrical signal. This signal represents the electrical activity of the diaphragm, the body's principal breathing muscle.


   



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1094.

Er A, Qureshi P, Knipe H, Esophageal temperature probe. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 18 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-94366. URL: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/oesophageal-temperature-probe?lang=us

questions.text: Identify this tool used in PAP smears:
questions.solution:
The image shown is of Ayre's spatula.
 
  • Ayre's spatula is a medical instrument used primarily for collecting cervical cell samples during a Pap smear (Papanicolaou test). It is a flat, wooden or plastic spatula with a curved, elongated shape, designed to gently scrape cells from the ectocervix (the outer part of the cervix) to screen for cervical cancer, precancerous conditions, and other abnormalities.
 
  • In practice, it is often used in combination with a cytobrush to collect samples from the endocervix (the canal within the cervix).

questions.text: Name the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
The instrument in the picture can be easily identified as an episiotomy scissor due to its angulated blades. 
 
  • Episiotomy scissors are specialized surgical scissors used during childbirth to perform an episiotomy, which is a surgical incision made in the perineum (the area between the vagina and the anus) to enlarge the vaginal opening and facilitate delivery. These scissors typically have an angled or curved blade to make the cut easier and more controlled, minimizing trauma to surrounding tissues.
 
  • The curved design allows the healthcare provider to cut at the correct angle, usually mediolateral or midline, reducing the risk of tearing during childbirth and aiding in a cleaner, controlled incision.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 531, 620.

questions.text: What is the given procedure done in the labor room?
questions.solution:
The most common procedure done in a labor room is the Non-stress Test.
 
  • A non-stress test (NST) is a fetal monitoring method used to assess the baby's well-being by measuring the fetal heart rate in response to movement. It is typically performed in the third trimester, especially in high-risk pregnancies.
 
  • A reactive result, where the heart rate increases appropriately, indicates good fetal health, while a non-reactive result may require further testing. The NST is safe, non-invasive, and helps ensure the fetus is receiving adequate oxygen.
 
  • This test looks at the fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movement as a measure of fetal health.
 
  • It involves the use of Doppler to detect the fetal heart rate accelerating when the mother perceives fetal movement. 


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 123, 693, 694.
Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, page no 448, 450.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the following instrument?
questions.solution:
Examiner of vagina and cervix is done post delivery to look for any cervical and vaginal tears using Sims posterior vaginal wall speculum.

Uses of Sim's speculum are: 
 
  • Gynecological Examinations: It is used during routine pelvic exams to visualize the vaginal walls and cervix.
  • Procedures: Sim's speculum can be employed in procedures such as Pap smears, biopsies, or the insertion of intrauterine devices (IUDs).
  • Labor and Delivery: It may also be used during labor to assess the progress of cervical dilation.

Sim's speculum is valued for its ability to provide a clear view of the vaginal and cervical areas, facilitating various gynecological assessments and procedures.






Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 528.

questions.text: The birth defect exhibited in the infant below was likely caused due to the use of which of the following medications during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The cleft lip given in the image above is typical of Isotretinoin's teratogenic effects.This medication should never be taken in a female of reproductive age without first ruling out pregnancy as it is often used to treat acne. Isotretinoin should be stopped atleast/minimum 1 month before pregnancy.


Retinoid Syndrome in Foetuses

Retinoids, which are synthetic vitamin A derivatives, if used by pregnant women and cause a distinctive pattern of birth abnormalities.

  • Craniofacial abnormalities: These may include small or malformed ears, cleft palate(as given , or facial asymmetry.
  • Central nervous system defects: Hydrocephalus or microcephaly
  • Cardiac abnormalities:  Ventricular septal defects/transposition of the great arteries 
  • Visual system abnormalities:  small or absent eyes (microphthalmia), cataracts, or optic nerve abnormalities.

Other options
Ferrous Sulphate(iron) and Folate are not teratogenic, infact given in pregnancy as supplements to reduce anemia/neural tube defect risk. Metaclopramide is non-teratogenic and a safe anti-emetic in pregnancy. 


Reference- Katzung Basic and Clinical Pharmacology 14th Edition Page no 527

questions.text: Determine the pedigree's inheritance pattern.
questions.solution:
The given inheritance pattern is X-linked recessive.
 
  • Only Males are affected - females are carriers as seen in the above pedigree suggesting X-linked recessive inheritance. 
  • A few well-identified clinical disorders like Hemophilia/ Color Blindness have X-linked recessive inheritance.
  • The Y chromosome is not homologous to the X, hence mutant X chromosome genes do not have matching Y chromosome alleles.
  • The male is said to be hemizygous for X-linked mutant genes as a result, and as a result, the male manifests these illnesses. 
  • Females are hemizygous - hence - act as carriers, and do not manifest the disease. 
The following table summarises identification points for various modes of inheritance:

questions.text: A 25-year-old man goes for a routine examination and finds to have an early diastolic murmur ( family pedigree mentioned ). Name the pattern of inheritance of the disease in this patient.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: AD
If we study the following pedigree.
  • All 3 successive generations are affected which suggests Dominant disease.
  • Both male and female offspring are affected suggesting Autosomal inheritance
  • Male to male transmission is also present thus it cannot be an X-linked disease.
An autosomal dominant disease presenting with an early diastolic murmur in a young individual is most likely to be Aortic regurgitation.
The following table summarises identification points for various modes of inheritance:

questions.text: The karyogram below demonstrates a chromosomal defect. Location of the chromosome where the mutation has occurred is
questions.solution:
• Chromosome 13 is normally acrocentric, but in the given image - the arrow is pointed at the centromere located at the center of the chromosome showing a metacentric translocation defect. Hence, option(2) is the correct answer, not option(1).
  • Classification of chromosomes Depending on the position of the centromere, chromosomes are classified as—
  1. Metacentric: Both p and q are of equal size (p = q).
  2. Submetacentric: The q arm is slightly longer than the p arm (p < q).
  3. Acrocentric: The p arm is very small compared to the q arm (p <<< q).
  4. Telocentric: The p arm is completely absent. This type does not exist in humans.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 631

questions.text: The picture of a patients karyotype is shown below. Which of the following features can be seen in this karyotype?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Gynaecomastia and long arms

The above karyotypic study is showing 2 X chromosomes and one Y chromosome. This 47 XXY karyotypic abnormality is known as Klinefelter syndrome.
 
  • It is the most common sex chromosome aneuploidy
  • It is the most common genetic cause of infertility in males
  • Clinical features –
  1. Tall
  2. Absence of facial and body hair
  3. Small penis and testis
  4. Crypto-orchidism
  5. Gynaecomastia
  6. Male breast cancer
  7. Low IQ
  8. Increased risk of extragonadal GCT
All the other options like short wended neck, polydactyly and flat occiput are seen in Down’s syndrome.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 638

questions.text: Given below is a pedigree chart, What is the inheritance pattern seen?

Correct Option is 3: Mitochondrial inheritance

From the given pedigree we can interpret that in every generation the disease is only getting transmitted from a diseased female to her offspring. The disease is not getting transmitted from a diseased male to his offspring. Therefore, this pedigree describes Mitochondrial inheritance.

questions.text:
As seen in the image, a 25-year-old woman arrived with erythematous papules on her face. Excessive perspiration, exposure to the sun,
and emotional distress all made the lesions worse. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis of this 25-year-old girl with erythematous papules on the face as seen in the picture with exacerbated lesions on excessive sweating, sun exposure and emotional disturbance is acne rosacea.
  • Acne rosacea is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that affects the face, particularly the cheeks, nose, chin, and forehead.
  • It is characterized by redness, flushing, and the appearance of papules and pustules. The condition is often worsened by triggers such as sun exposure, emotional stress, and alcohol consumption.
  • Photodermatitis is a skin reaction that occurs after exposure to sunlight and is characterized by redness, itching, and blisters, but it does not usually present with papules.
  • SLE is close differential , but it has other systemic features with sparing of Nasolabial folds.
  • Below is an image of Lupus Rash vs  Rosacea. Note the sparing of the nasolabial folds.




Reference- Illustrated Synopsis of Dermatology and Sexually Transmitted Diseases, Neena Khanna, 4th edition, page number 121, 122.

questions.text: A patient arrived with a 7-day history of bullae covering more than 30% of the body's surface area as well as erosions of the lips and other mucosae. What is the likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
• The above picture shows a forearm with extensive reddish bullae involving >30% body surface area and the description is typical of the spectrum of Steven-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), is a rare, life-threatening skin condition that is usually caused by a reaction to drugs.
  • SJS/TEN is a rare, but potentially life-threatening, hypersensitivity reaction to certain medications and less commonly infections more commonly viral infections 
  • It is characterized by the formation of painful bullae, erosions, and ulcerations of the skin and mucous membranes.
  • The condition typically presents within the first few weeks of starting a new medication, although it can occur at any time during treatment. Many medications have been associated with SJS, including antibiotics (e.g., sulfonamides), anticonvulsants (e.g., phenytoin), and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (e.g., ibuprofen).
  • The exact mechanism of SJS is not fully understood, but it is thought to be a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which involves activation of T-cells and subsequent release of cytokines.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 119.13

questions.text: As shown in the picture, a patient presented with itchy, tight blisters on both healthy skin and over urticarial plaques. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis in this patient with tense blisters on normal-looking skin-associated urticaria/ plaques as seen in the figure points towards a diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid.
  • The blisters can occur on healthy skin or over urticarial plaques, which are raised, itchy patches of skin. The blisters are typically itchy and can be painful.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris typically affects the mucous membranes rather than the skin.
  • Linear IgA disease typically affects the skin around the mouth, eyes, and genitals.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis causes itchy, blistering rashes, but it is typically associated with gluten sensitivity or celiac disease.



PV- Pemphigus vulgaris
PF- Pemphigus foliaceus 
EBA-Epidermolysis bullosa Acquisita
Pveg- Pemphigus Vegetans 







Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.10

questions.text: The figure depicts a 65-year-old man who has tense blisters and itching on otherwise normal-appearing skin with urticarial plaques. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• The above clinical description fits with that of Bullous pemphigoid.
  • Bullous pemphigoid is an subepidermal immunobullous disorder that affects older age groups leading to blisters/ bullae on urticated as well as normal looking skin and associated pruritus.
  • Antibodies are formed against hemidesmosomal proteins [ BP antigen 230 (BPAG1) & BP antigen 180 (BPAG2 Or Type XVII Collagen)]
  • These antibodies cause damage to dermo-epidermal junction leading to a sub-epidermal split in the skin.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.10

questions.text: A middle-aged woman went to the emergency department with severe blisters on her skin and oral mucosa. The following is an example of direct immunofluorescence. All the following are accurate regarding the disease pathogenesis except
questions.solution:
• The given image shows Fishnet Immunofluorescence seen in Pemphigus Vulgaris.
  • Antibodies against desmogleins 1 and 3 found in desmosomes are the cause of Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Anti-Desmoglein 3 levels are thought to be closely correlated with the disease severity and the presence of mucosal lesions.
  • Pemphigus in its milder variants is more anti-desmoglein 1 heavy.
  • Anti-hemidesmosome antibodies are seen in Bullous Pemphigoid. 
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.8

questions.text: The following histological picture of a patient's skin sample suggests:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Pemphigus Vulgaris
  • The image shows the suprabasal acantholysis seen in Pemphigus Vulgaris
  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune skin disorder with IgG antibodies against desmoglein (a component of desmosomes, which connect keratinocytes in the stratum spinosum).
  • Flaccid intraepidermal bullae can be caused by acantholysis (separation of keratinocytes, resembling a “row of tombstones”).
  • It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Immunofluorescence reveals antibodies around epidermal cells in a reticular (fishnet-like) pattern
  • Nikolsky sign will be positive. (separation of epidermis upon manual stroking of skin).


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.6

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with uncomfortable blisters over her vaginal and oral mucosa. She described the prior occurrences of corresponding lesions. On histology, a biopsy taken from the lesion revealed a suprabasal split. Intercellular IgG deposits were discovered using immunofluorescence microscopy, as seen below. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• The figure shows a direct immunofluorescence image revealing fishnet pattern with intercellular deposition of IgG against Desmoglein 1 & 3, classically seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • The clinico-immunofluorescence co-relation in the above patient confirms the diagnosis of Pemphigus vulgaris.


AIBD- Autoimmune Blistering Disorder
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.8

questions.text: The limbs of a 68-year-old patient had itchy, tense skin blisters on the extensor aspect, as depicted below. What would the diagnosis be?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows tense bullae on urticarial red base which are most likely due to bullous pemphigoid.
  • It is an immunobullous disorder where antibodies are directed against BPAG - 2 and BPAG - 1 present in hemidesmosomes.
    There is sub - epidermal split in the skin resulting in formation of tense bullae which have red, urticarial bases. Histopathology shows sub - epidermal bullae with eosinophils.
  • Direct immunofluorescence study shows a linear pattern of IgG, C3 deposition in the basement membrane zone.

Treatment— steroids.
