questions.text:
Skin lesion are present on the patient. A biopsy was performed, and the lesion's histopathology is displayed.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. From the provided histology image we can observe there is a suprabasilar blister, a portion of the epidermis, including the stratum corneum, forms the roof which is normally seen in Pemphigus vulgaris
  2. The various hpe features of Pemphigus Vulgaris include 
  • Acantholysis: Loss of cell-to-cell adhesion between keratinocytes.
  • Suprabasal blister: Separation just above the basal layer of the epidermis.
  • Tombstone appearance: Basal keratinocytes remain attached to the basement membrane, resembling tombstones. 
  • Direct immunofluorescence (DIF): IgG and C3 deposits in a “fishnet” or “chicken wire” pattern between keratinocytes.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2

questions.text: A 50 y patient has an oral ulcers and skin bullae that are taking their time to heal. Where exactly is the lesion?
questions.solution:
• The lesion is suprabasal.
  • A 50-year-old patient with bulla on his body and oral mucosa with the given image likely has pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Bulla in pemphigus vulgaris is intra-epidermal and the split is suprabasal.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2

questions.text: A woman complained of a bluish lesion across the left side of the forehead and left eye when she arrived. An irregular bluish lesion is detected in the left superior conjunctiva and forehead. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given picture shows an irregular bluish lesion in the left superior maxillary and ophthalmic region of trigeminal nerve in a female patient. The most probable diagnosis is Nevus of Ota.
  • It is caused by the accumulation of melanocytes in the area and is more commonly seen in women of Asian descent. The lesion is usually present at birth or appears in early childhood, but can also develop later in life.
  • Nevus of Ito is a similar condition, but the pigmentation is located on the shoulder and upper arm.
  • Becker's nevus is a hairy patch of skin that appears on the shoulder or upper chest.
  •  Mongolian spot is a common birthmark that appears as a blue-gray patch on the lower back or buttocks.



Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/nevus-of-ota

questions.text: A woman arrived with unilateral leukotrichia and white skin lesions, as shown in the picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A lady came with unilateral white skin lesions with leukotrichia as shown in the picture. Most likely diagnosis is segmental vitiligo.
  • Segmental Vitiligo:Occurs along a nerve segment
  • Common on face along the branches of trigeminal nerve
  • Stable course, i.e., lesions increase initially (6-12 months) and then remain static.
  • Leukotrichia on the depigmented areas as well as away from vitiliginous areas frequently seen. Margins are feathery.
  • Piebaldism, is a genetic condition that is present from birth and results in a white forelock of hair and depigmented patches on the skin, but it usually affects both sides of the body.
  • Focal vitiligo is a type of vitiligo that affects only a few small areas of the body
  • Waardenburg syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects hearing, pigmentation, and eye color.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 88.37

questions.text: As seen in the image, a male patient has a hypopigmented patch on his back. What further research would be most beneficial in this situation?
questions.solution:
The image shows a patient suffering from Pityriasis versicolor.
 
Pityriasis Versicolor
  1. Pityriasis Versicolor is a disease caused by Malassezia furfur(a fungus)
  2. It shows hypopigmented, scaly, and perifollicular macules in the upper trunk, neck, and upper arms. Hypopigmentation occurs due to synthesis of azealic acid by fungus which is a tyrosinase inhibitors and reduces formation of melanin. Hyperpigmentation also occurs sometimes due to formation of large melanosomes. 
  3. KOH mount shows Short branched hyphae with spores as spaghetti and meatballs appearance


Hence, KOH mount would be the best investigation among the given options.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.11

questions.text: Which of the following facial congenital lesions is present?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Congenital melanocytic nevus
 
  • The given image showing a black, heterogeneous, hairy palpable lesion in a child is suggestive of congenital melanocytic nevus. 
  • Congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) are benign, pigmented, melanocytic nevi present at birth.
  • They are most commonly brown, black, purplish, or red, usually a palpable lesion with heterogeneous color and texture.
  • CMN often have thick hair at birth, which grows at a significantly greater rate than the surrounding scalp hair.
  • Melanoacanthoma is a benign skin growth that typically appears as a dark, raised patch on the skin, but it is not typically present at birth.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 75.9

questions.text:
An 18-year-old female patient arrives with a hypopigmented patch and feathery edge on the medial part of her foot. The rest of the physical exam goes as expected.
Which medication from the list below should be avoided when treating this patient?
questions.solution:
• This individual suffers from localized vitiligo. Isotretinoin is used to treat acne, however, because of its teratogenic risk, it should never be administered to a young girl.
  • The remaining alternatives are suitable vitiligo treatment techniques

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 88.37

questions.text: A man arrives with facial rashes and also reports feeling less mentally sharp. On his skin, he also has a few macular lesions. Intracranial calcification was discovered during a CT scan. His spouse is normal. While his 10-year-old daughter seems well, his 6-year-old son similarly exhibits the same skin blemishes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In the question posed, the patient has facial angiofibromas as well as an ash leaf macule, mental retardation, seizures, and a positive family history in a child. These features strongly indicate a diagnosis of tuberous sclerosis, which is characterised by autosomal dominant inheritance. Therefore, the answer is option D.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 80.9

questions.text: In the image provided, identify the following lesion.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Becker nevus
 
  • Becker nevus is a hyperpigmented hairy patch. 
The shoulder, back, and proximal portion of the upper limb are the most common site involved. Mostly seen in males before puberty. 





Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 89.62

questions.text: Which of the following is a likely diagnosis based on the image given below?
questions.solution:
• Acute Cutaneous LE refers to any cutaneous (skin) manifestation of lupus that appears suddenly and typically is inflammatory in nature (red, itchy, swollen, etc.).
  • These lesions often appear as patches, plaques, and/or lesions, which can be widespread or localized.
  • Subacute Cutaneous LE refers to a form of cutaneous LE that may appear as red patches, plaques, scaly or ulcerative lesions that can have an inflammatory, noninflammatory, or mixed presentation.
  • Chronic Cutaneous LE refers to a type of Cutaneous LE that has been present for a long period of time and can cause disfigurement of the skin.
  • DLE (Discoid Lupus Erythematosus) is the most common form of cutaneous LE and presents as erythematous to depigmented discoid plaque with adherent scaling usually occurring over face, scalp, neck and 'V' area of chest.
Skin manifestations in SLE


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 51.2

questions.text:
The face and neck of a patient from Bihar who had a history of persistent fever as a youngster were affected by nodular, hypopigmented lesions.
Both hypoaesthesia and nerve thickening were absent. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given history (h/o prolonged fever in childhood, living in Bihar) and clinical findings are suggestive of post - Kala Azar dermal leishmaniasis. Leishmaniasis is transmitted by sandfly (Phlebotomus Argentipes).

  • PKDL is a complication of Kala Azar following complete/incomplete/irregular treatment of Kala-azar.
  • It presents as macular/papular/nodular skin rash.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 33.50

questions.text: A male patient with a history of feverish joints and back discomfort experiences hyperpigmentation across the nose.  He then takes NSAIDs for relief of pain. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct option is (4) Chikungunya.
  • Based on the clinical history of fever, joint pain, a rash, and the development of brownish hyperpigmentation over the nose, the most likely diagnosis is pigmentation due to Chikungunya, a condition where the pigmentation of the nose area is quite noticeable.
  • This is also known as thr Chik sign
  • This pigmentation is not usually seen in other viral exanthems.(option 3)
  • In contrast, in the case of a fixed drug eruption, the mucocutaneous junction and genital skin, in particular the glans is most often affected, not the nose. (hence, option (2) is incorrect)
Reference Cutaneous manifestations of chikungunya during a recent epidemic in Calicut, north Kerala, south India, IJDVL 2010. 
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.75

questions.text: A young man complained of having strangely shaped lesions all over face. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis in this particular case is Dermatitis artefacta.
  • Dermatitis artefacta or factitious dermatitis is a psychocutaneous disorder 
  • Patients by themselves create lesions on their skin/mucosa/hair or nails to either get attention or evade responsibility or sometimes to satisfy some psychological need. They also hide responsibility for this from their doctors.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 86.24

questions.text:
A 13-year-old kid presents to the OPD with segmented patches of patchy depigmented skin on the chest and belly.
A year ago, depigmentation began, and during the past few months, there has been no change. Mother recalls using topical steroids in the past, but they weren't very helpful. Which medical diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
• Clinically speaking, vitiligo is marked by well-defined milky-white macules that may also involve white hairs or poliosis. Vitiligo is an acquired skin disease with progressive melanocyte loss. 
  • The vitiligo segmental variant: One continuous segment is often affected, while two or more segments with ipsilateral or contralateral distribution have been observed. It is distinguished by a unilateral and segmental, or block-shaped, distribution of the lesions. 
  • Little, discrete lesions make focal vitiligo. 
  • Piebaldism: A triangular-shaped white patch on the forehead, sporadic hypopigmented macules, and a congenitally white forelock are involved. 
  • Common areas for involvement include the forehead, chest, abdomen, and extremities. 
  • A well-defined hypopigmented patch called Nerve Depigmentosus is present from birth; it may occasionally become more noticeable in the first year of life as the background skin.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 88.37

questions.text: As seen in the picture, a 9-year-old boy has skin blemishes. Lesions have a long history of spontaneously disappearing and reappearing. What is the effective diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Pityriasis alba
 
  • The above scenario of a hypopigmented patches is suggestive of pityriasis alba.
  • It is a pattern of dermatitis in which hypopigmentation is the most conspicuous feature. It is seen in the age group of 3-16 years. 
  • Lesions have scaling and are usually not well marginated. In children, the lesions are often confined to the face and are most common on the cheeks and around the mouth and chin.
  • It is often a manifestation of atopic eczema but it is not confined to atopic individuals.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 39.25

questions.text: As seen in the illustration below, an 11-year-old boy had plaques in his cubital and popliteal fossa that were itchy and hyperpigmented. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Atopic dermatitis
 
  • The given clinical history of plaques over the popliteal and cubital fossae suggests the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis.
  • Atopic dermatitis is the cutaneous expression of the atopic state, characterized by a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema.
  • The epidermal barrier is impaired due to a mutation in the gene encoding filaggrin (a structural protein in the stratum corneum).
  • The site of lesions shifts to elbow and knee flexures when the child is 18 months to 2 years.
  • There is also a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper- and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification seen on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles. 
  • Below are the differences between Atopic dermatitis and Psoriasis.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 41.1

questions.text: 34y old patient comes to your OPD with the following complaint of having severe acne causing discomfort. Below is an image of the patient. What would be the best line of management?
questions.solution:
• In the given image, the patient is suffering from severe nodulocystic acne with pus filled lesions.
  • Oral therapy with Isotretinoin is indicated in such a patient.
  • High dose anti-androgens can be given to females in reproductive age group as alternative therapy.
Below is a treatment approach in patients with Acne

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 90.39

questions.text: The image depicts a child who has a rash. His family has a history of asthma. What is the most likely medical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Atopic dermatitis
 
  • Atopic dermatitis is the cutaneous expression of the atopic state, characterized by a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema.
  • In infants, it presents as erythema and edematous papule in the face and extensor aspect of the knees and elbows. The papules are intensely itchy and may become exudative and crusted as a result of rubbing.
  • The epidermal barrier is impaired due to a mutation in the gene encoding filaggrin (a structural protein in the stratum corneum).
  • The site of lesions shifts to elbow and knee flexures when the child is 18 months to 2 years.
  • There is also a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper- and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification seen on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles. 
Other features of atopic dermatitis include xerosis (dry skin), ichthyosis (fish-like scaly skin), and headlight sign (facial eczema sparing periorbital, perinasal, and perioral area).



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 41.16

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis in the case of a psoriatic patient who showed good response to oral steroids but on stopping of these drugs he developed the lesions?
questions.solution:
The image shows pustular psoriasis.

Pustular psoriasis may be precipitated by :

1. Rapid tapering of corticosteroids (or other systemic therapies) / Sudden corticosteroid withdrawal
2. Pregnancy,
3. Hypocalcemia
4. Infections
5. Topical Irritants

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 35.32

questions.text: 30y old male came to your OPD with the following  lesion. What is the best description for the given lesion?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an annular lesion.

Annular lesion:
  • Circular lesion with central clearing.
  • Infectious Causes:
    • Dermatophyte
    • Impetigo
    • Syphilis
    • Leprosy
  • May be inflammatory
  • May occur due to psoriasis

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 4.9

questions.text: A young woman complained of having strangely shaped lesions all over her face and arms, as seen in the picture. What is the most likely Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Dermatitis artefacta
 
  • Symmetrical distribution of lesions on face and arms in easy to reach areas.
  • Moreover, the lesions seem to be in varying stages of healing, like as in an abrasion.
  • This is a psychocutaneus condition
  • This points out to the diagnosis of dermatitis artefacta
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 86.24

questions.text: A child was brought in with lesions over the elbows and penis shaft that were similar to those in the picture. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• Grouped pin/read lesions on elbow, abdomen, penis and dorsum of hand in a child as shown in the picture is highly suggestive of lichen nitidus.
  • Lichen nitidus appears as small, shiny, flat-topped bumps that are skin-colored, yellow, red-brown, or violet. They can be 1–3 mm in diameter and are often round or polygonal in shape.
  • It  can be localized or generalized, and  can cluster together to form plaques.
 

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.10

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man from Bihar arrives with papules  which are hypopigmented and normal sensation over his face and the back of his neck.
A prolonged fever episode in childhood was documented while taking  history. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL) is based on:
  • History of kala-azar in the past (1-5 years ago) or living in endemic area.
  • Presence of "juicy'' erythematous nodules on the central part of the face.
  • Hypopigmented macules on the central part of the trunk.
  • No nerve involvement
  • PKDL can appear weeks, months, or even years after successful treatment of visceral leishmaniasis, often occurring in endemic regions.
  • Diagnosis is typically made based on clinical examination and history of previous leishmaniasis infection, with possible confirmation through skin biopsies or serological test

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 33.50

questions.text: The following lesions are present across the body, primarily on the trunk, in a 7-month-old  pregnant woman. Which of these medications is most suitable for the treatment?
questions.solution:
• The image given is of Pustular Psoriasis of Pregnancy.
  • Usually seen in third trimester
  • Recur in subsequent pregnancy
  • Presents with scaling on trunk/abdomen/legs.
  • DOC- Oral steroids ( only type of psoriasis where oral steroids are used)


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 35.28

questions.text:
A man with leprosy arrived with the shin lesion shown in the image below.
Which spectrum of Leprosy does this patient fall under?
questions.solution:
• Inverted saucer-shaped lesions are characteristic features of borderline Borderline (BB) leprosy.



 




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.10

questions.text: Using histopathology, determine the disease as displayed in the figure:
questions.solution:
The biopsy reveals a suprabasal split, the basal epidermis has a row-of-tombstones, and acantholytic cells are seen within the split. These findings are suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.
 
  • A basal split caused by necrotic basal keratinocytes is seen in TEN.
  • Mycosis fungoides and lepromatous leprosy have an almost normal epidermis without any splits.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2, 50.4, 50.7

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman has had two months with asymptomatic dome-shaped tiny lesions on her forehead. She has a daughter, age 2, who has comparable lesions.
What is the cause of the lesion?
questions.solution:
• The lesions in the given picture on the forehead are pearly white papules and with a history of transmission to her daughter, the most likely diagnosis is Molluscum contagiosum, which is caused by the poxvirus.
  • In molluscum contagiosum, typical lesions which are pink or skin coloured in the form of an umbilicated papule containing a greyish central plug. It is seen commonly in children.
  • The face and genitals are commonly involved and the face is most commonly involved in children, in whom the groin and genitals are not affected, which are usually involved in sexually active adults.

 
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.13

questions.text: What is your diagnosis for a young patient who presents to the OPD with a history of black central arch rashes on his body?
questions.solution:
• The image shows characteristic meningococcal rashes having black central arch and surrounding ring or erythema.
  • Non blanching rashes develop in more than 80% of meningococcal diseases.
  • The causative organism is Neisseria meningitidis.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 26.49

questions.text: For one month, a young male has had the following itchy lesion: Which of the following genera cannot cause this kind of lesion?
questions.solution:
• The above lesions are suggestive of Tinea cruris, also known as crotch itch which is a dermatophyte fungal infection of the groin region.
  • Causes: usually Trichophyton rubrum
Dermatophytes
  •      Microsporum
  •     Epidermophyton
  •      Trichophyton.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.46

questions.text:
As shown in the picture, a young boy with greasy skin exhibits acne.
What is the proper course of treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
• The diagram shows severe nodulocystic acne with pus filled lesions.
  • Oral therapy with Isotretinoin is indicated is such a patient.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 90.37

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman has had asymptomatic dome-shaped, tiny lesions on her forehead for two months. Her 2-year-old daughter suffers from comparable lesions.
Which is the lesion's causative agent?
questions.solution:
• The pearly white papule lesions on the forehead are most likely Molluscum contagiosum, which is brought on by the poxvirus and has a history of being passed down to daughters:
  • Molluscum contagiosum (MC), often known as water warts, is a viral infection of the skin or mucous membranes that is brought on by the molluscum virus, a DNA poxvirus (MCV)
  • The lesions of molluscum contagiosum have a flesh-colored, dome-shaped, and pearly look. 
  • They are often 1-5 mm in diameter, with an umbilicated center.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.12, 25.13

questions.text:
A young man with an anesthetic patch on his right forearm arrived.
On examination, a thicker nerve was palpable.
This image comes from a skin biopsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient has presented with a single anesthetic patch and single enlarged nerve, and a well defined granuloma can be seen on the skin biopsy.
  • These findings are typical of Tuberculoid Leprosy.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.7, 28.8

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man came in with itchiness on his fingertips.
Below is a clinical description of the lesion and its etiological agent. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The history of itching across the fingers and the presence of lesions in the finger webs as seen in the picture strongly suggest scabies.
  • Scabies is characterized by intractable itchiness, which is typically worse at night.
  • The lesions first develop on the web gaps, then spread to the sides of the fingers, the flexor surfaces of the wrists and elbows, and the anterior axillary folds.
  • The areolae in women, the buttocks, the sacrum and periumbilical regions, as well as the penis and scrotum, are other common locations for lesions.
  • Eczematous and frequently excoriated lesions are possible, but the burrow—a brief, wavy, dark line—is the hallmark lesion.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 34.41, 34.40

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The given picture is of hand-foot-mouth disease caused by Coxsackie virus.
  • Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease (HFMD): After an incubation period of 4-6 days, patients with HFMD present with fever, anorexia, and malaise; these manifestations are followed by the development of sore throat and vesicles on the buccal mucosa and frequently on the tongue; these lesions are then followed by the appearance of tender vesicular lesions on the dorsum of the hands, occasionally involving the palms.
  • The vesicles may become bullae and ulcerate very soon.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 117.6,117.7

questions.text:
The patient, a 42-year-old man, had lesions as depicted below.
Which of these is the best course of action for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows Leonines facies (thickened nodular lesions on foreheard, ears, eyebrows, and cheeks) seen in and classically described for Lepromatous leprosy.
  • Hence, the patient should be started on MDT for leprosy.
  • In Lepromatous leprosy, the skin and soft tissues of the face can thicken, leading to a lion-like appearance, which is where the term "leonine" comes from.
  • This change is due to the effects of the disease on the skin and underlying tissues, including loss of eyebrows and changes in the nose's structure.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.9

questions.text: A patient comes to your OPD with the following lesion which was associated with itching. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Tinea corporis, also known as ringworm, is a fungal skin infection typically caused by a type of fungus known as dermatophytes.
  • It typically presents as an itchy, annular (ring-shaped) plaque with well-defined borders, peripheral papulopustular, scaling, and central clearing.
  • The most common organism responsible for this infection is a type of dermatophyte named Trichophyton rubrum.
Trick: -
Annular lesion with central clearing- Tinea
Annular lesion with central scarring- Lupus vulgaris
Annular lesion with central crusting- Cutaneous leishmaniasis 

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.35, 32.36, 31.26

questions.text: A young patient comes to your OPD with the following lesions over the lips. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis of herpes labialis is primarily made by visual inspection of the affected area.
  • The most typical presentation is a cluster of small, round, painful vesicles or blisters on a reddened base, often accompanied by painful sores on or near the lips or near the nose.
  • However, diagnosis of herpes labialis can be confirmed more definitively by laboratory tests such as the PCR (polymerase chain reaction) test, the Tzanck test, or a viral culture of lesions.
  • PCR testing is the most accurate, and it can detect the virus even in people who do not have obvious symptoms.
  • The given image shows blisters which indicate herpes labialis but in impetigo yellowish brown crusts would be seen


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.18

questions.text: A farmer appeared with the following symptoms: swelling on the foot and discharge from the sinuses. What  is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis, based on the information provided in the inquiry and the photograph, which depicts many discharging sinuses, is mycetoma.
  • Mycetoma : Chronic granulomatous subcutaneous inflammatory disease caused by filamentous bacteria ( actinomycetoma ) or true fungi ( eumycetoma ).
  • Triad of Progressive subcutaneous swelling with sinus tracts that discharge grains is seen in cases of mycetoma.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.74,32.75

questions.text:
A migrant worker arrived with complaints of burning urination and urethral discharge following a week of unprotected sex.
Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
• The given picture suggests gonorrhea infection.
  • Many gonorrhoea cases in men are asymptomatic.
  • When present, dysuria or a white, yellow, or green urethral discharge that typically emerges one to fourteen days after infection are among the indications and symptoms of urethral infection in males.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 30.3

questions.text: A patient arrives with the lesion in the picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Borderline leprosy:

  • The number of skin lesions is in between those of the two polar types. 
  • They could appear as macules, plaques, annular lesions, or odd-looking bands. - characterised by plaques that appear "punched-out." 
  • Lesions are sparser, drier, more insensitive, and contain fewer bacilli in smears and biopsies towards the tuberculoid end of the spectrum than they do towards the lepromatous pole.
Classification Symptoms Disease response
Tuberculoid leprosy A few flat lesions, some large and numb; some nerve involvement Can heal on its own, persist, or may progress to a more severe form
Borderline tuberculoid leprosy Lesions similar to tuberculoid but more numerous; more nerve involvement May persist, revert to tuberculoid, or advance to another form
Mid-borderline leprosy Reddish plaques; moderate numbness; swollen lymph nodes; more nerve involvement May persist, revert to tuberculoid, or advance to another form
Borderline lepromatous leprosy Many lesions, including flat lesions, raised bumps, plaques, and nodules; more numbness May persist, regress, or progress
Lepromatous leprosy Many lesions with bacteria; hair loss; more severe nerve involvement with peripheral nerve thickening; limb weakness; disfigurement Doesn't regress


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.10, 28.7, 28.5

questions.text: A young patient has patchy hair loss, itching, and scaling on the scalp. Which of the following investigations will help in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. Tinea capitis, which results from an infection with dermatophytes species, is a common cause of hair loss in youngsters.
  2. Investigations - When examined under a wood light, a yellow-green fluorescence is visible. 
  3. Diagnosis: Fungal Culture after pretreatment with potassium hydroxide.








Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.38, 32.24

questions.text: The following itching lesion has been present on a young man for one month. Except for ____  all of the following genera can result in this form of lesion:
questions.solution:
• The lesions shown in the image are suggestive of Tinea cruris, commonly known as Jack itch, is a dermatophytosis of the groin area typically caused by Trichophyton rubrum. 
  • A class of fungus known as dermatophytes includes ringworms which, under moist conditions, can infect and thrive solely on dead keratin, the outermost layer of skin, hair, and nails.
  • It belongs to three genera Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 31.26, 32.3

questions.text: Warts on the penis of a sexually active male were discovered, as seen below. Which of these HPV strains is mostly involved in these lesions?
questions.solution:
The picture suggests it to be a case of Anogenital warts on penis, which are caused by low-risk HPV viruses
i.e. HPV- 6 and 11.




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.56, 25.58

questions.text: A 5 years old girl presented with lesion on the face for the last 3 months. A skin biopsy was performed and the findings are shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The biopsy is showing Molluscum Bodies seen typically in Molluscum contagiosum.
  • This disease is usually seen in young children (like in this case) and causes lesions on the face which are pearly white papules.
  • There may be a history of transmission from mother as well.
  • Also called as HP Bodies( Henderson-Paterson bodies ), these are intracytoplasmic, eosinophilic, granular inclusions within the keratinocytes of the basal, spinous, and granular layers of the epidermis.



Reference : Rook’s tex ok no Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume 2 Chapter 25 fig25.12

questions.text:
STD visit by young male with this painful lesion present in genital area.
What will not be seen in the corresponding microscopy:
questions.solution:
• Cytology of herpes group of viruses include the following features:
  1. Multinucleated cells
  2. Tzanck cell : Enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei present in large, round keratinocytes with peripheral halo.
  3. Greenblatt and Pund cells : A large mononuclear cell whose nucleus is eccentrically placed.
  4. HP bodies : Intracytoplasmic viral inclusion bodies, eosinophilic in nature and seen in Molluscum contagiosum.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.14, 3.26

questions.text:
A patient with painful lesions that were grouped together came to the STD clinic.
Which of the subsequent tests ought to be carried out to make the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tzanck smear for multinucleate giant cells

 
  • Genital herpes is more commonly caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV) 2. The patients present with painful vesicular-ulcerative lesions. In men, it occurs mainly on the penis or urethra. In women, the cervix, vagina, vulva, and perineum can be involved. 
  • Herpes infection can be caused by HSV-1 and HSV-2 viruses. HSV-1 causes orofacial lesions, i.e. herpes labialis, while HSV-2 mainly causes genital herpes.
  • The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers. 
  • The Tzanck smear technique is a rapid and inexpensive diagnostic method. Scrapings (preferably from the base of vesicles) are obtained from the lesions and stained with a  1% aqueous solution of O-toluidine blue for 15 seconds. 
  • Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground-glass chromatin, known as Tzanck cells, are seen. Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles in Giemsa-stained smears.




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 31.22, 31.23

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with the following lesion.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Basal cell carcinoma is strongly suggested by a lesion  with raised, pearly borders, a central crust, and telangiectasia on the lesion's surface.
  • Typically, basal cell carcinomas appear as pearly papules with dilated, noticeable subepidermal blood vessels (telangiectasias). Some cancers have melanin and resemble melanocytic nevi or melanomas on the surface.
  • After years of neglect or in extremely aggressive tumours, advanced lesions may ulcerate and cause considerable local invasion of the bone or face sinuses, which explains the outdated name "rodent ulcers."


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 141.9, 141.10

questions.text: The picture depicts a 25-year-old woman who has erythematous papules on her face. Excessive perspiration, exposure to the sun, and emotional distress all made the lesions worse. Description fits with:
questions.solution:
The above clinical description with worsening of lesions on excessive perspiration/sun exposure/emotional distress fits with Rosacea. 

Rosacea
1.  It's a centro-facial disease, especially seen on the convexities of the face (cheeks, chin, forehead, and nose).
2. The exact cause of rosacea is not known but may be associated with an abnormal vascular reactivity (exaggerated flushing response to heat, spicy food, alcohol, and stress) without any pharmacological defect.


Reference :Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 91.6

questions.text: A young girl who had experienced spotty hair loss for two weeks presented to the OPD as depicted below. Both erythema and scarring were absent. What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Trichotillomania
  • The given image shows patchy hair loss with hair of various lengths pointing towards a diagnosis of trichotillomania. Trichotillomania is non scarring alopecia characterised by perifollicular haemorrhage.
  • Trichotillomania is a disorder characterized by the compulsive pulling of hair.
  • It is predominantly seen in females and is almost always associated with psychological or behavioral stress disorders like OCD (obsessive-compulsive disorder), Body dysmorphic disorder, intellectual disability, etc. 
  • It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern.
  • The hairs are often twisted and broken at varying lengths or may be present as uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal.
  • Sites other than the scalp can also be affected, for example - eyelashes, eyebrows, beard, mons pubis, and perianal region.
  • Patients sometimes may swallow/eat the hair and present in intestinal obstruction. (Bezoar)

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 86.17, 86.18

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of the following condition?
questions.solution:
• Fluocinolone is a steroid and is not used in the treatment of acne as steroids can exacerbate acne.
  • Treatment includes topical retinoids and anti-bacterial depending on the grade/severity of disease.


Reference:Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 90.37, 90.38, 90.40

questions.text: Below is an image of Hair shaft. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Image given is the paintbrush appearance seen in Trichorrhexis nodosa.
  • Trichorrhexis nodosa is a defect in the hair shaft characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily.
  • It is associated with underlying disorders in some cases such as argininosuccinic aciduria, Menkes' kinky hair syndrome, Netherton's syndrome, and hypothyroidism.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 89.54

questions.text:
A girl child was seen with the following lesion associated with dry eyes, and night blindness .
What does the dermatological finding in the picture represent?
questions.solution:
• This is a Phrynoderma case.
  • A type of follicular hyperkeratosis called phrynoderma is connected to nutritional deficits.
  • Although uncommon in developed nations, it is endemic among poor populations.
Nicholls first used the term "phrynoderma" to describe the "toad-like" appearance of the skin of malnourished labourers in 1933.
Isolated vitamin A, B complex, C, and E deficiency can result in this type of dermatosis

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 87.14

questions.text: What is the best line of treatment for the X ray shown below?
questions.solution:
• The fracture displayed in the image is a transverse fracture of the patella .
  • Tension band wiring is the correct treatment option for this type of fracture.
  • Tension band wiring involves placing two Kirschner wires (K-wires) across the fracture site, with one wire placed above the fracture and the other below it.
  • A stainless steel wire is then wrapped around the K-wires and tightened to create a tension band.
  • This tension band converts the tensile forces that would otherwise be applied to the fracture site during knee extension into compression forces, which promote healing.
  •         

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 148

questions.text: What kind of fracture is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
• In the given X-ray of proximal humerus fracture, there is a three-part fracture, which fits it into Neer's type III.
  • It is based on the location and number of fracture fragments
  • Neer Classification for Proximal humerus fractures is as follows
Type I • Minimally Displaced, one-part fracture, fracture lines involve 1-4 parts
Account for ~70-80% of all proximal humeral fractures

Type II • Two-part fracture, fracture lines involve 2-4 parts, one part is displaced (Anatomical neck)

Type III • Three-part fracture, fracture lines involve 3-4 parts, two parts are displaced (Surgical neck)

Type IV • Four-part fracture, fracture lines involve more than 4 parts & three parts are displaced (Greater tuberosity)

Type V • Lesser tuberosity fractures

Type VI • Fracture dislocations






Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 92

questions.text:
A 40 years old male fell on the outstretched hand with radial side pain and
tenderness in anatomical snuffbox and restriction of wrist movement.
Following is the X-ray image. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
•  X-ray that shows a transverse line in the scaphoid bone and a history of falling on an outstretched hard with radial side discomfort, soreness, and restriction of wrist movement is suggestive of a scaphoid fracture.
  • The scaphoid bone is located in the anatomical snuffbox and is commonly fractured when a person falls on an outstretched hand with radial deviation.
  • Clinical features- Tenderness at the anatomical snuff box.
  • Treatment- Cast in glass holding position

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 115

questions.text: As may be seen in the Knee X-ray below, an athlete has a fracture. How will you treat this fracture?
questions.solution:
• The given radiograph shows displaced patellar fracture which is managed by tension wire banding.
  • It works on the principle of converting distraction force from pull of quadriceps muscle into tension force. 
  • Tension wire banding is also performed for displaced olecranon fractures against distraction pull of triceps muscle. 
  • Undisplaced fractures of patella are managed conservatively by cylindrical cast. 
     
Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 148

choices.text: Extra-articular fracture at the wrist with dorsal displacement
Extra-articular fracture at the wrist with volar displacement

questions.text: A woman stumbled in the restroom. She was treated with caution. The following clinical image of the patient demonstrates the following causes of the deformity:
questions.solution:
The deformity is due to extra articular fracture at wrist with dorsal displacement-Option B. 

The picture shown is dinner fork deformity due to Colle’s fracture.
It is characterized by the fracture of the distal radius in forearm with dorsal (posterior) and radial displacement of the wrist and hand.

questions.text: How will you manage the fracture shown below?
questions.solution:
• The given lateral knee radiograph shows displaced patellar fracture.
  • The management of displaced patellar fracture is to perform tension wire banding which will convert distraction force of quadriceps tendon into tension force and align the fracture fragments together.

questions.text: Which of the following deformities in the image is more likely a complication of the other?

questions.text: What is the most likely vascular injury in the fracture shown in the X-ray below?
questions.solution:

  • Most common nerve injured in Supracondylar fracture of humerus is anterior interosseus nerve>median nerve. 
Structures Damaged in Supracondylar Fracture- AMRU

M- Median nerve
R- Radial nerve 
U- Ulnar nerve

Immediately after a trauma, a child complained of forearm ache. The results of an AP and lateral X-ray of the forearm are displayed in the picture below.

questions.text: As seen in the figure below, a 24-year-old male is suffering with a humerus fracture. What nerve is most likely to be affected by the fracture?
questions.solution:
• The given X-ray demonstrates diaphyseal fracture across the radial groove of right humerus. 
  • Here, the most likely injured nerve will be radial as it runs in the radial groove. 
  • Fractures in this area can cause compression or stretching of the radial nerve, which can result in symptoms such as weakness or paralysis of the triceps muscle, wrist drop, and loss of sensation in the back of the hand and fingers supplied by the radial nerve

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 94

questions.text: Which of the numbered bones in the X-ray given below gets fractured most frequently when an elderly person falls on their outstretched hands?
questions.solution:
1-Radius, is most commonly fractured in elderly following fall on an outstretched hand.
2- Ulna
3- 2nd metacarpal
4- 3rd metacarpal
  • The distal radius is  closest to the wrist joint, and it is particularly vulnerable to fractures in this type of fall because it is responsible for transmitting much of the force from the hand to the forearm resulting in Colle's fracture. 

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 36

questions.text: Name the fracture.
questions.solution:
Galeazzi Fracture: A direct impact to the radius causes a diaphyseal fracture and dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint.
XRay:
Lateral view: Radius is dorsally angulated.
APview: Transverse or short oblique fracture radius. The distal radioulnar joint dislocation.
 
  • The Monteggia fracture is a dislocated fracture of the upper portion of the ulna and head of radius is dislocated.  Late childhood is the most typical time. It happens when you fall with your hands outstretched, either in hyperpronation or hyperextension.
  • Distal radius is involved in a colles fracture. frequently happens as a result of a fall onto a hand that is outstretched, resulting in a dorsally displaced, dorsally angulated fracture. frequently observed in kids and the elderly (osteoporosis).
  • A T- or Y-shaped intraarticular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal is known as a Rolando's fracture.


 

Reference-:Ebnezar's Textbook of Orthopedics 5th Edition Page 165

questions.text: Pain at the base of the thumb is evident in the patient (De Quervain tenosynovitis). What are the image's marks?
questions.solution:
• De Quervain tenosynovitis is an inflammation of the tendon sheaths located on the radial side of the wrist. These sheaths surround two muscles of the thumb: the abductor pollicis longs and extensor pollicis brevis.
  • When the outer part of the wrist, at the base of the thumb, is tender to the touch and causes pain with repetitive movements, it is generally a sign of De Quervain tenosynovitis.
  • Treatment may include anti-inflammatory medications, corticosteroid injections, rest, splinting or physical therapy.
  • In severe cases, surgery may be recommended.
  • .
  • De Quervain tenosynovitis is also called De Quervain tendinitis.


   


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 303

choices.text: Inverted champagne bottle sign; bicep tendon rupture

questions.text: What is the following sign known as and what is the cause?
questions.solution:
• Popeye deformity is a condition that occurs when a tendon in the biceps muscle of the arm tears.
  • The biceps muscle then bunches up and forms a large, painful ball-like bulge above the elbow in the upper arm, giving it the appearance of Popeye's cartoon muscular arms.
  • This condition can be very painful and can limit the arm's normal range of motion.
  • Treatment typically involves rest, physical therapy, medications, and in some cases surgery.
Other options: -
Inverted Champagne bottle appearance is seen in lipodermatosclerosis 
Olive sign is seen in infants with pyloric stenosis 

 

Reference:Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma 10th Edition Page no 364

questions.text: Identify the given image.
questions.solution:
• The image shows a dynamic cock-up finger splint.
  • It is used to treat wrist drop from radial nerve palsy

questions.text: You receive greetings from a diabetic sufferer who came to see you. You, the doctor, see that his hand has this malformation when he does namaste. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis is diabetic cheiroarthropathy.
  • The prayer sign is seen in case of diabetic cheiroarthropathy and it is characterized by inability to completely close gaps between opposed palms and fingers on pressing them together.
Other causes that may lead to prayer sign are:
  • Dupuytren’s contracture
  • Eosinophilic fasciitis

Reference-: Online Resources https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9767792/

questions.text: Which of the following provocative tests cannot be performed for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:

  • Finkelstein test is used to diagnose De Quervain’s tenosynovitis.   
  • Rest all tests help in diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome and durkan's test is the most specific one.

questions.text: Following a fall in the bathroom, a 75-year-old person developed hip fracture, as shown in the pelvic X-ray below. What will be the position of the left lower limb?
questions.solution:
• The classically described presentation in a neck of femur fracture is a shortened, and externally rotated limb due to the unopposed pull of the iliopsoas muscle that attaches to the lesser trochanter.
  • MC mechanism- Due to lateral rotation.
  • Classification- Garden and Pauwel
  • Clinical features - Tenderness over anterior joint line, Shortening+ External rotated limb.
  • X ray sign- Breakage in Shenton's line

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 134

questions.text: In the diagram below, which hip action is demonstrated by the examiner
questions.solution:
The above image demonstrates the FADIR(Flexion, adduction, and internal rotation) test. Hence, the internal rotation of the hips is demonstrated in the above image. 

FADIR Test
Hips are Flexed up to an angle of 90 degrees, then ADducted and Internally Rotated. 


Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no 257,412

questions.text: Which deformity is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• A hallux valgus  is a fixed abduction of the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe as shown in the given image. 
  • It is also known as a bunion
  • It is a common deformity of the big toe joint where the big toe deviates laterally towards the second toe, causing a bony bump to form on the inside edge of the foot

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 327

questions.text: A patient is sent to the trauma centre after suffering a roadside injury. His left hip is quite painful, and upon inspection, it is incredibly tender and has a limited range of motion. In the position shown below, the patient is lying down. What kind of malformation is there in the patient?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows flexion, abduction and external rotation of left lower limb with limb lengthening seen in anterior dislocation of hip. 
  • Posterior dislocation- flexion, adduction and internal rotation with knee resting on  opposite limb and limb shortening. 
  • Remember- Most common type of hip dislocation is posterior.  
Memorizing Trick- 
Anterior Dislocation- FABER- Flexion ABduction External Rotation 
Posterior Dislocation- FADIR- Flexion ADduction Internal Rotation 



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 131

questions.text: A patient complained of chronic low back ache as well as hyperpigmented nose and ears. Schober's test result is positive. The following appearance can be detected on a spinal X-ray. What is the most obvious cause?
questions.solution:
The X ray shows multilevel intervertebral disc calcfication, syndesmophyte formation and disc space narrowing - which along with the history of hyperpigmented nose and ears points towards OCHRONOSIS.
The term ochronosis usually refers to the bluish-black discolouration of certain tissues, such as the ear cartilage and the ocular tissue seen with Alkaptonuria. The musculoskeletal manifestations of alkaptonuria are also referred to as ochronosis.    
 

Reference:Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics, 13th edition Page no 1708

questions.text: Which of the subsequent tests is represented in the given image?

questions.text: Given below is the pelvic X-ray of a patient in Ortho OPD. Which of the signs given below will not exist in the patient?
questions.solution:
• The x ray image given is of Developmental Dysplasia of Hip.
  • Narath, Ortolani, and Barlow are all clinical tests used to diagnose DDH.

questions.text: Match with the image
questions.solution:
• Cobb's angle is the angle measured from the uppermost vertebra to the lowermost vertebra in a patient who has scoliosis.
  • It is measured on a radiograph and is used as a reliable clinical assessment of scoliosis.
  • The Ferguson angle is similar, but it is measured at the lumbosacral area of the spine. It is used to determine how deviated the spine is from a normal, straight position. The measurement of both angles can help doctor's diagnose and classify the severity of the patient's scoliosis.
  • The Böhler angle is the angle on a lateral foot radiograph between a line joining the highest point of the anterior process of the calcaneus and the highest point of the posterior articular facet, and a line joining the highest point of the posterior articular facet with the highest point of the calcaneal tuberosity
  •  A reduced Böhler angle can be seen in displaced intra-articular calcaneal fractures.
  • Baumann's angle, which is the angle formed in the AP view by the diaphyseal axis of the humerus and the physeal line of the capitellum, is used to assess varus or valgus alignment of the distal humerus.
 



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 281,282

questions.text: A 42-year-old man finds it difficult to bend forward and experiences back stiffness. His CT scan picture is shown. What exactly is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history along with the X-Ray suggests the diagnosis of Ankylosing spondylitis.

Clinical features:

Lower back discomfort and stiffness gradually start to appear.

The patient is usually awakened by pain in the early morning or late at night, and becomes better after going for a walk or after exercising.

On X-ray:

i. Squaring of vertebrae
ii. Loss of Lumbar lordosis
iii. Bridging osteophytes
Iv. Bamboo spine appearance


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 292,293

questions.text: In the given image, which of the following braces is shown?
questions.solution:
• The given brace is Milwaukee brace which is the best brace for treatment of Scoliosis.
  • Boston brace is the one which is most commonly used for the treatment of scoliosis.
  • Taylor’s brace is used for kyphosis.
  • Charlston’s brace is only used at night for scoliosis.
Below is the image of  Boston Brace


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 283

questions.text: A patient has reported having neck and back pain for the past month. The indicated beam is visible in:
questions.solution:
• The given X-Ray can be seen in DISH (diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis)
  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a condition characterised by calcification and ossification of ligaments and entheses.
  • The condition usually affects the axial skeleton, in particular, at the thoracic segment, though also other portions of the spine are often involved.




Reference- https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2045/dish-diffuse-idiopathic-skeletal-hyperostosis

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is seen with a fever and a 4 month-old wound on his right leg that has been draining pus.
The given X-ray of this patient has a labelled structure; identify it:
questions.solution:
• In the question, Arrow points to the sequestrum.
  • A bony sequestrum is a piece of devascularised bone that becomes separated from the remainder of the bone in chronic osteomyelitis and acts as a nidus for ongoing infection.
  • It appears hyperdense as compared to surrounding bones to due absence of demineralization from the incoming blood. 

   



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 172

questions.text: The patient in the X-ray below is 16 years old. What pathology is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
In this X-ray of the humerus head, we can see a faint patch loss of density and a sequestrum within the bone. This along with the young age, is suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis.



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 172

questions.text:
The patient experienced discomfort and edoema at the same location where he had an RTA two years prior.
The features of an X-ray are as follows. What is the expected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given history along with radiographic appearance of button sequestrum in proximal tibia is diagnostic of chronic osteomyelitis. 
  • The patient had a previous road traffic accident (RTA) two years prior, which could have introduced bacteria into the bone. The X-ray shows a lytic lesion with sclerotic borders, which is a characteristic feature of chronic osteomyelitis.



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 172

questions.text: Where is ring sequestrum seen?
questions.solution:
Ring sequestration is seen in case of infection at pinhole of external fixation.

Ring sequestration occurs when a certain dead portion of bone due to loss of vascularity gets surrounded by granulation tissue.
And it is the characteristic feature of chronic osteomyelitis.
 
Different types of SEQUESTRA
TYPE DISEASE
TUBULAR PYOGENIC
RING EXTERNAL FIXATORS
BLACK ACTINOMYCOSIS
CORALLIFORM PERTHE'S DISEASE
COKE TUBERCULOSIS
SANDY TUBERCULOSIS
FEATHERY SYPHILIS
  

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 172

questions.text: Identify the lytic lesion near the radius's end:
questions.solution:
• The lesion shown in the question is a giant cell tumour or osteoclastoma.
  • Giant cell tumour can be seen in the given image as an epiphyseal lytic lesion in the radius with a "soap bubble" appearance. An osteoclastoma tumour always touches the edge of a joint.
  • In a Giant-cell Tumour, Radiolucent region bordered by a subchondral bone plate is seen which is located eccentrically at the end of a long bone in X-rays. The centre of the lesion occasionally resembles a soap bubble as a result of ridging of the surrounding bones.
  • A cystic lesion in mature bone that extends all the way to the subchondral plate is so distinctive that the diagnosis is rarely in question.
  • Osteochondroma is an extension or outgrowth of the growth plate which is usually pedunculated.

Important d/d is Aneurysmal Bone Cysts, it has similar appearance but occurs before growth plate fusion.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 238

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male patient complains of movement-related pain. On an X-ray of the knee joint, a lytic lesion on the top of the tibia can be seen.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer- 4.Osteoclastoma
Explanation- Eccentric epiphysis soap bubble lytic lesion extending till the cortex  in matured bone, most likely Osteoclatoma. 

Think of aneurysmal bone cyst with similar radiographic features but in an immature bone where joint fusion would not have ocurred. 


Summary of bone tumours




Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 237,238

questions.text: A 30 years old male presented with knew pain for the last 6 months.X-ray is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Xrays shows a circumscribed osteolytic bone tumour involving the epiphysis - the most likely diagnosis is Giant cell tumor.
  • Giant cell tumor is a benign bone tumor that typically affects young adults between the ages of 20 and 40 years old.
  • It is more common in women than in men and frequently occurs in the long bones, such as the femur or tibia.
  • The X-ray image shows a well-defined osteolytic lesion with a thin rim of sclerotic bone, which is a characteristic feature of giant cell tumors
Other options
  • Multiple myeloma- commonly seen in older age group atleast around 60 years of age.
  • Simple bone cyst will be a well defined radiolucent lesion commonly seen in bones of upper limb and in an age group of 10-20. It is characterized by a fluid-filled cavity within the bone
  • An adamantinoma is a rare low-grade malignant bone tumor typically found in the diaphyses of long bones in 20-40 year olds.
Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 237,238

questions.text: A biopsy of the sternum reveals a red, soft-to-firm swelling with the following histology. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given slide shows blood filled dilated blood vessels s/o hemangioma.
  • Hemangiomas are common growths of blood vessels found on skin. These growths can appear anywhere on your body, especially on your face, chest and back, as red or purple lumps.
  • Hemangiomas are usually harmless and tend to resolve on their own.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 236

questions.text: A male boy, age 10, complains of pain in his lower limb. Below is the X ray. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Osteosarcoma is the diagnosis based on the clinical picture given which shows codmann's triangle due to lifting up of periosteum by  a heterogenous radiolucent lesion. 
  • Giant cell tumor only occurs after growth plate fusion, i.e. after 20-40 years.
  • Osteoblastoma is seen in the diaphyseal region.
  • Chondroblastoma is most commonly seen in elderly population. Also it is greyish/bluish in color.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 240

questions.solution:
• The given X-ray shows lamellar/onion peel periosteal reaction involving diaphysis of humerus- typical of Ewing's sarcoma. 
  • The onion skin or layered periosteal reaction is caused by the tumor's aggressive growth, which causes the periosteum  to lift off the bone and create multiple layers. This characteristic is not typically seen in other bone tumors,

questions.text: A 9-year-old child arrives with the malformation described below. Which fracture is most likely to cause such a defect?
questions.solution:
The given image shows cubitus varus of right upper limb and it is most commonly seen as a complication of supracondylar fracture of humerus.  
Cubitus Varus ('Gun-Stock' Deformity)
(Varus refers to a limb malformation in which a portion of the limb deviates from the body's midline.)
When the arms are raised and the elbow is extended, the deformity is most noticeable. Supracondylar fracture malunion is the most frequent cause of this condition.
Wedge osteotomy of the lower humerus can be used to repair the deformity, however it is recommended to wait until skeletal maturity.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 102

questions.text: Identify the well-circumscribed osteolytic lesion in the calcaneum of an 8-year-old child with pigmented deposits using histological images:
questions.solution:
Haemophilic pseudotumors are rare complications of hemophilia consisting of a progressive cystic swelling of muscle and/or bone due to repeated bleeding, occurring in <2% of hemophiliacs as seen in this image. In histology it shows a dense capsule which contains clots, bony debri.

questions.text: An X-ray of a 7-year-old is shown here. Which deformity is it?
questions.solution:
• The given pelvic radiograph shows decrease in the neck-shaft angle of bilateral femur-s/o coxa vara. 
  • The angle of inclination is normally between 120-135 degrees, but in Coxa vara, it is reduced to less than 120 degrees.
  • This can be caused by a variety of factors, including congenital deformities, trauma, or infection.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 323

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy complains of right shoulder and neck ache with limited range of motion. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
• Klippel Feil Syndrome is characterized by congenital fusion of at least two cervical vertebrae with an absence of the intervertebral discs.
  • The classical triad consists of a short neck, limitation of head and neck movements and a low posterior hairline.
  • This triad is present in 50% of patients Klippel-Feil can be associated with multiple anomalies such as congenital heart defects, deafness as well as other skeletal deformities such as scoliosis, malformed ribs and sprengel deformity. 
  • The given image shows Sprengel deformity of left side as the scapula is located at a higher level due to a persistent omovertebral bar. This causes limitation of scapular movement and glenohumeral joint. 


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 224

questions.text: What is the likely cause of the deformity observed in the picture below?
questions.solution:
• Anterolateral bending of the tibia, a common symptom of congenital pseudoarthrosis of the tibia, is depicted in the image.
  • Congenital pseudoarthrosis of tibia is a rare congenital disorder that affects the tibia bone in the leg.
  • It is characterized by a non-union of the bones, causing a bowing of the leg and a visible deformity.
   


Reference- https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4056/anterolateral-bowing-and-congenital-pseudoarthrosis-of-tibia

questions.text: Select the most likely cause of the abnormality seen in the wrist X-ray from a 12 years old boy as shown below.
questions.solution:
• The radiological image above shows cupping and fraying of the metaphyses, typically seen in rickets.
  • In active rickets there is thickening and widening of the growth plate, cupping of the metaphysis and, sometimes, bowing of the diaphysis.
  • The metaphysis may remain abnormally wide even after healing has occurred

questions.text: A 12-year-old child complained of right hip pain. Below is a pelvic X-ray that was obtained. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
• The given pelvic radiograph shows a fracture of right femoral neck in a 12 year old boy, which will most likely be seen in option C- Osteogenesis Imperfecta. 
  • The X-ray shows  fractures in the femur and pelvis, which is a common feature of Osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • The fractures can occur spontaneously or with minimal trauma.


Other options:-
Osteoporosis unlikely to occur in 12 year old child and can't be determined on x ray

questions.text: A young person arrives with a history of right hip pain and walking issues. Hip X-rays were taken as shown in the image. Which of the subsequent diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Osteopetrosis, also known as Albers-Schönberg disease or marble bone disease, is an uncommon hereditary disorder that results from defective osteoclasts.
  • Bones become sclerotic and thick, but their abnormal structure actually causes them to be weak and brittle.
  • The given pelvic radiograph demonstrates bone within bone sign of osteopetrosis. 


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 317

questions.text: Which of the following nerve injuries can affect a girl with the left elbow deformity depicted in the figure?
questions.solution:
• The girl in the figure has a left elbow deformity, which is likely cubitus valgus (also known as "gunstock deformity").
  • This deformity can cause stretching or compression of the ulnar nerve, which runs along the inside of the elbow. Late onset ulnar nerve injury can occur due to chronic compression or stretching of the nerve, known as Tardy Ulnar nerve palsy. 
  • Symptoms may include numbness or tingling in the ring and little fingers, weakness in the hand, and difficulty with fine motor tasks.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 104

questions.text: Identify the following circuit:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Mapleson A.
 
  • The circuit shown in the illustration is Mapleson A, also known as the Magill circuit.
  • The Mapleson A circuit is a rebreathing circuit used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.
  • It allows the patient to breathe spontaneously during the procedure, providing better control over ventilation and maintaining adequate oxygenation.
  •  It has a spring-loaded pop-off valve near the facemask. Gas enters the circuit opposite the side of the patient. It is best for allowing spontaneous breathing but worst for controlled ventilation. 
The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is A > DFE > CB.
The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A.






Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 611-613.

questions.text: The image of a pro-seal-type LMA is given below. Above what site is the A-marked area of the airway positioned?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Above esophagus
 
  • The internal gastric tube (drainage tube), which is kept immediately above the esophageal aperture to aspirate GI fluids, is indicated by the arrow.
  • A reusable supraglottic airway device called the LMA ProSealTM includes a gastric drainage tube that is positioned lateral to the main airway tube and terminates at the tip of the mask.
  • By separating the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts, the gastric drainage tube allows regurgitated fluid to flow up the drain tube and bypass the glottis, shielding the airway from contamination in the event of passive regurgitation.



Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1389-1392.

questions.text: A resident was operating on a patient when she abruptly observed the following plot on the capnograph monitor. What treatment course should be given to the patient immediately?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Increase muscle relaxant
 
  • The capnograph shown here shows " Curare clefts”. It is seen during spontaneous ventilation & cleft is seen in last third of plateau.
  • Clefts during phase III indicating spontaneous breathing efforts during controlled mechanical ventilation.
  • The cleft is caused by lack of synchronous action between the intercostal muscles and diaphragm - most commonly caused by inadequate muscle relaxant  and sedation causing patient to take spontaneous breaths.
  • As the muscle relaxant is given the curve become normal in shape and plateau is normal.


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1311.

questions.text: An accident occurred to a construction worker, who then went to the trauma centre after a large concrete block fell on his face. He had significant laryngeal and maxillofacial injuries, it was discovered. He was unable to open his mouth, and upon investigation, it was discovered that both his oropharynx and nasopharynx had obstructions and many fractures. The following action was taken for him in order to keep a patent airway. Which of the following choices accurately defines the procedure?
questions.solution:
• In the given image Cricothyroidotomy is being performed.
  • A cricothyrotomy (also known as a cricothyroidotomy) is an incision made through the skin and cricothyroid membrane to create a patent airway in certain life-threatening circumstances, such as when a foreign body is blocking the airway, when angioedema is present, or when there has been significant facial trauma.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1406-1408.

questions.text: A cholecystectomy under general anaesthesia was arranged for a 40-year-old habitual smoker. He had anaesthetic induction with propofol and vecuronium, and isoflurane was administered to maintain the anaesthesia. The following capnograph plot was seen during the surgery. What might be the reason?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2: Entry into the right-sided bronchus
 
  • The capnograph plot shows a sudden drop in the end-tidal carbon dioxide (ETCO2) level, indicating a change in the ventilation pattern.
  • Entry into the right-sided bronchus during intubation can lead to selective intubation of the right lung, resulting in ventilation of only one lung.
  • This causes a decrease in the exhaled CO2 levels and a characteristic capnograph pattern.
  • The correct placement of the endotracheal tube should be confirmed by auscultation, chest rise, and bilateral breath sounds to ensure proper ventilation.



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1397, 1398.
Gandhi, S K et al. “Capnography for detection of endobronchial migration of an endotracheal tube.” Journal of clinical monitoring vol. 7,1 (1991): 35-8. doi:10.1007/BF01617896

questions.text: What does the following ETCO2 curve depicts?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Spontaneous efforts
 
  • In an end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) graph, spontaneous effort typically appears as irregularities or "dips" in the waveform during mechanical ventilation. This is commonly known as "Curare clefts".
  • These dips occur when the patient attempts to breathe independently, causing a disruption in the smooth pattern of the ventilator's delivered breaths.
  • Spontaneous effort might be reflected on an ETCO2 graph:

    1. Dip in the Plateau Phase: Normally, the ETCO2 waveform has a plateau phase after the peak, which represents the alveolar plateau. Spontaneous effort may cause a sudden dip during this phase, indicating the patient’s attempt to inhale against the ventilator.

    2. Inconsistent Waveform: The otherwise regular and consistent waveform might show variability in amplitude or frequency due to the patient's spontaneous breathing efforts.

    3. Increased Frequency: If the patient is making multiple spontaneous efforts, you may see a more frequent waveform pattern, potentially with smaller breaths between the regular ventilator-delivered breaths




Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no: 1311.

questions.text: Name the equipment in the image provided.
questions.solution:
The given equipment is a High flow nasal cannula.

High Flow Nasal Canula :
 
  • Can humidify and warm air (to a temperature of 37 C), which helps lessen airway inflammation, preserve mucociliary function, facilitate mucus clearance, and lower caloric consumption in cases of acute respiratory failure.
  • Able to deliver 60 to 70 L/min of 95-100% FiO2. 
  • Can produce PEEP between 4 and 6 mm Hg if the patient keeps the mouth close.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2595, 2752.
Nishimura, M. High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy in adults. j intensive care 3, 15 (2015). https://doi.org/10.1186/s40560-015-0084-5

questions.text: The illustration for airway management shown below contains:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Chin lift.
 
  • The illustration shows the technique of Head tilt and chin lift, which is a maneuver used to open the airway and improve ventilation.
  • During airway management, lifting the chin upwards helps to extend the neck, move the tongue away from the posterior pharyngeal wall, and open the oropharynx.
  • The chin lift is a simple and effective method to relieve airway obstruction in patients who do not have a suspected cervical spine injury




Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology, 5th edition, Page no 1232, 1235.
Austin, Naola et al. “Airway management in cervical spine injury.” International journal of critical illness and injury science vol. 4,1 (2014): 50-6. doi:10.4103/2229-5151.128013

questions.text: Which of the following is represented by the number marked in the monitor's given image?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. End Tidal Carbon dioxide concentration

  • The number and the graph beside it in the image depicts End tidal carbon dioxide concentration (ETCO2) measurement by Capnography.
  • The term "capnography" describes both the process of measuring CO2 and its visual representation as a function of time or volume.

choices.text: IV fluids and antibiotics followed by laparotomy

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient is experiencing respiratory distress, nausea, vomiting, fever, and abdominal pain. His pulse rate was 115/min and his blood pressure was 90/60 mm Hg. The ER took the chest X-ray that is shown below. Which is the next best course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. IV fluids and antibiotics followed by laparotomy

The given chest X-Ray shows gas under diaphragm suggestive of Hollow viscus perforation.
  • The immediate management in place should be IV fluids and antibiotics followed by laparotomy.
 
  • The immediate management should focus on stabilizing the patient's vital signs and treating the underlying infection. IV fluids and antibiotics can help to stabilize the patient's blood pressure and address the infection, till then the patient can be prepared for Laparotomy.
 
  • Emergency Laparotomy is necessary to identify and repair the site of perforation to prevent further complications and is the definite line of management.



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 413, 414.

questions.text: A given set of instruments is utilised in:

  • Millers blade

 All of these instruments are used for airway management of patients.
