questions.text: Which nerve is blocked in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Nasociliary nerve
 
  1. Nasociliary nerve block- Close to the ethmoidal foramen, the nasociliary nerve is blocked before it splits into nasal branches of the anterior ethmoidal nerve and the infratrochlear nerve. 
  2. The nasociliary nerve is blocked before its division into nasal branches of the anterior ethmoidal nerve and the infratrochlear nerve, and near the ethmoidal foramen. A 25- or 27-gauge needle is inserted 1 cm above the medial canthus, halfway between the posterior palpebral fold and the eyebrow. It is then directed medially and backward in contact with the bony roof of the orbit. At a depth of 1.5 cm the needle should be at the anterior ethmoidal foramen, and a maximum of 2 mL of local anesthetic solution is then slowly injected after a negative aspiration test.
  3. The external nasal branch of the anterior ethmoidal nerve can be blocked by infiltration at the junction of nasal bone with cartilage.
  4. Blocking this nerve can be useful in treating conditions such as cluster headaches, migraines, and trigeminal neuralgia

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2412-2414.

questions.text: Determine the investigation from the illustration below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: USG.

The given image shows the ultrasonogram view of neck region



The salient features of neck ultrasound is as follows:
•    Non-invasive, lacks radiation exposure and is readily available at a low cost. 
•    Best imaging modality to study the thyroid gland in neck for both diffuse and nodular disease. 
•    USG guided fine needle aspiration in the most effective method of diagnosing malignancy of thyroid. 
•    After partial/near total thyroidectomy for carcinoma, ultrasound is the preferred method for follow-up, by detecting residual, recurrent or metastatic disease. 
•    TIRADS can be used to stratify the risk of malignancy of thyroid nodule according to its ultrasonographic characteristics. 
•    USG guided ablation with chemical agents/thermal energy can be used to treat thyroid adenoma and benign cold nodules. 


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 882.

questions.text: Which investigation is shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: CT.

The given investigation modality is non-contrast CT scan of abdomen. It is identified by hyperdense (white) appearance of bones. 

The appearance of important structures on CT scan are as follows:
a.    Hypodense- black/dark. 
•    Air- Lungs, paranasal sinuses, middle ear cavity
•    Water- CSF in ventricles, bile in gallbladder and biliary tree, urine in urinary bladder
•    Fat- Subcutaneous tissue, mesentery and omentum. 

b.    Isodense-Gray. 
•    Soft tissues in the body such as brain, liver, spleen, kidneys appear isodense. 

c.    Hyperdense-White/bright. 
•    Bones- Skull, ribs, middle ear ossicles
•    Calcification- Basal ganglia, calcified fibroid, calculus 
•    Acute hemorrhage and foreign body such as glass, bullet, shrapnel. 

Option B-MRI 
•    MRI detects signal intensity arising from nuclei/protons 
•    Appearance is described as hypointense- dark, isointense- intermediate and hyperintense- white.
•     Simple trick to identify MRI is to look for bones which appear black/hypointense as compared to CT scan where they appear white/hyperdense. 

Option C- Contrast Study
•    Involves injection of contrast material to evaluate structures not identified by conventional imaging. 
•    Examples of contrast study include:
  • Digital subtraction angiography
  • Barium studies
  • Intravenous pyelogram 
  • Micturating cystourethrogram
  • Retrograde urethrogram 
  • Hysterosalpingography
Option D- Angiography
•    In angiography, contrast material is injected in the blood vessels and images are acquired using X-Rays, CT or MRI. 

The image seen is from a CT scan. A series of x-rays, a type of radiation on the electromagnetic spectrum, are used to make CT scans. The detectors in the scanner measure the difference between the x-rays that are absorbed by the body and the x-rays that are transmitted through the body. The scanner emits x-rays at the patient from a range of angles. Attenuation is the term used for this.

 
Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 469, 472.

questions.text: The X-ray of the chest shown below exhibits all of the traits except:
questions.solution:
The X-ray suggests cardiomegaly, right atrial enlargement, and decreased blood flow, possibly
due to some right-sided valvular obstruction like Ebstein anomaly. There are no signs of
pulmonary hypertension in the X ray. 
The appearance known is Box shaped heart.




Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th edition, Page no 420, 421.

questions.text: Determine the diagnosis in provided X-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Penumoperitoneum.

The given X-Ray shows gas under right and left hemidiaphragm as well as beneath central tendon of diaphragm suggestive of pneumoperitoneum. 

Most common cause of pneumoperitoneum in adults- Hollow viscus perforation
Most common cause in neonates- Necrotizing enterocolitis
Best X-Ray projection- Erect chest X-Ray PA view
Investigation of choice- CT Abdomen 

The various named signs in pneumoperitoneum are as follows:



The given chest X-ray is clearly showing gas under the right dome of the diaphragm, which is  suggestive of pneumoperitoneum.
 
The term Pneumoperitoneum refers to gas within the peritoneal cavity. The most common cause of pneumoperitoneum is laparoscopic surgery.

The most sensitive radiograph to demonstrate pneumoperitoneum is an erect chest X-ray.
 
Causes of pneumoperitoneum include:

Perforation of the GI tract (caused due to Peptic Ulcers, Inflammation, infarction etc).
Penetrating abdominal injury.
Iatrogenic
Peritonitis with gas formation
Pneumothorax with pleuroperitoneal fistula.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 137.

questions.text: Identify the type of investigation done on the given X-ray image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Myelography
 
  • Imaging procedure performed to evaluate the subarachnoid spaces within the spinal canal. 
  • Fluoroscopic, CT or MR imaging is performed after intrathecal injection of contrast media, usually under fluoroscopic or CT guidance.
  • Only contrast agent approved by FDA for intrathecal injection in order to perform myelography-Iohexol. 
  • Although conventional (i.e. fluoroscopic) myelography has been largely supplanted by modern CT and (especially) MRI of the spine, it remains a useful tool in the evaluation of spondylosis.
  • CT myelography is useful in patients who cannot undergo MRI and CSF leaks/fistulas are suspected.
  • MR Myelography may also provide evaluation without the need for intrathecal gadolinium by utilizing specific fluid-sensitive acquisition techniques.
The investigation shown in the image is myelography.
 
Myelography is a radiographic investigation of the spinal canal which is used for the diagnosis of space occupying and obstructive lesions. A contrast agent is injected into subarachnoid space via lumbar puncture for the imaging.

Nowadays, MRI has replaced myelography, because myelography is invasive and provides less information.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1232, 1233.

questions.text: Identify the pathology on the given X-ray image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Cervical rib.

The given chest X-Ray shows bilateral cervical ribs arising from transverse process of seventh cervical vertebra. 

Cervical ribs:
  • Supernumerary or accessory ribs arising from seventh cervical vertebra.
  • Bilateral in ~ 80% of cases, asymmetric and more common in females. 
  • Anterior end may attach to the first rib, the sternum or the cartilage of the first rib
  • Anterior end can be in the form of a fibrous band or it may have no anterior attachment.
  • Majority are asymptomatic.
  • Clinical importance- Can cause thoracic outlet syndrome. 
The given image is showing a condition known as Cervical rib.
 
Cervical ribs arise from the 7th cervical vertebrae and are more commonly seen on the right side. The patient may present with a lump and tenderness in the supraclavicular fossa and the diagnosis is made using a chest X-ray.
 
Treatment modalities include, Sling exercise for mild cases while In severe cases, Scalenotomy (resection of scalenus anterior muscles) is done. In troublesome cases, the cervical rib is removed.



Reference: Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar, 5th edition, Page no 365.

questions.text: A patient who was presented to the emergency room had the following chest X-ray taken. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Hydropneumothorax.

The given chest X-Ray shows presence of gas-fluid level in right hemothorax-suggestive of hydropneumothorax. 
The air fluid level is indicative of a hydropneumothorax diagnosis.
The presence of both air and fluid in the pleural region surrounding the lung is known as a hydropneumothorax.
Air fluid levels can be seen on an upright chest X-ray. Typically, the horizontal fluid level is clearly defined and runs the entire length of the hemithorax.

Other options: -

Emphysema- Narrow mediastinum, hyperlucent lungs and broadened costophrenic angle
Pneumothorax- Hyperlucency with collapsed lungs and trachea deviation to opposite side
Cardiac tamponade- Water bottle heart



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 50, 123.
Weerakkody Y, Bickle I, Elfeky M, et al. Hydropneumothorax. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-17362

questions.text:
A patient complained of lower back ache, which was improved by hot water baths and exercise. Below is a X-ray image.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Spyondylolisthesis.
 
  • The given lateral pelvic radiograph shows fracture of pars-interarticularis of L3 and L4 lumbar vertebra with anterior migration of body of L3 vertebral body over L4- suggestive of spondylolisthesis ( Beheaded scotty dog sign ).
  • The lower vertebra with the arrow on it has moved forward on the X-ray, suggesting spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis, which most frequently happens after a fracture, is the forward displacement of a vertebra, particularly the fifth lumbar vertebra.
  • Spondylosis (a defect or fracture of the pars interarticularis of the vertebral arch) is the most common cause of spondylolisthesis, which should not be confused with a slipped disc, in which one of the spinal discs in between the vertebra has ruptured.
                          
Spondylosis is degenerative osteoarthritis of the joints between the center of the spinal vertebra or neural foramina. If this condition occurs in the zygoapophysial joints, it can be considered facet syndrome. If severe, it may cause pressure on nerve roots with subsequent sensory or motor disturbances, such as pain, paresthesia, and muscle weakness in the limbs.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1262.
Gaillard F, Hacking C, Bell D, et al. Scottie dog sign (spine). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-9954

questions.text: What does a chest X-ray reveal?
questions.solution:
A right-sided pneumothorax is suggested by the chest X- ray enhanced lucency on the right side, collapse of the right lung, and mediastinal shift to the left.

Most common cause of pneumothorax is spontaneous pneumothorax due to rupture of congenital pleural bleb. 

An expiratory chest X-Ray is the initial investigation modality to be ordered. The radiographic findings are summarized below- 


CT is considered as the gold standard in the diagnosis of pneumothorax. Best diagnosed on lung window images in non-dependent parts. 

Role of Ultrasound- 
The normal lung interface with pleura shows lung sliding with vertical comet tails running down from the pleural surface.



The various USG findings in pneumothorax are enlisted below-




Visceral pleural line sign is positive. 



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 50-52.

questions.text: What does the patient with a history of headaches' digital subtraction angiography reveal?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Aneurysm

The given digital subtraction angiogram shows contrast filled outpouching arising from internal carotid artery which is diagnostic of an aneurysm. 
 
  • Saccular cerebral/berry aneurysms account for most intracranial aneurysms and are the most common cause of non-traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage.
  • Usually arise at arterial bifurcations.
  • Composed of thickened hyalinized intima and muscular wall with internal elastic lamina being absent as the normal muscularis and elastic lamina terminate at the neck of an aneurysm.
  • Tendency to rupture at the dome. 
  • Around 90% of aneurysms arise from the anterior circulation 
    • ACA/Anterior Communicating Artery complex
    • Supraclinoid ICA and ICA/Posterior Communicating Artery junction
    • MCA (M1/M2 junction) bi/trifurcation 
  • Remaining ~ 10% aneurysms arise from the posterior circulation
    • Basilar tip
    • Superior Cerebellar Artery 
    • Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery 
  • Digital subtraction angiography is the gold standard investigation as it is diagnostic as well as therapeutic in case of aneurysms. 
  • Endovascular coiling of the aneurysm is one of the therapeutic options performed under DSA guidance. 
The right internal carotid artery's digital subtraction angiography image displays a balloon-like outpouching that may be an aneurysm.

An aneurysm is a focal enlargement of the vessel wall that most frequently manifests as a balloon-like outpouching but can also be fusiform.
Aneurysms typically develop at the origin of smaller vessels or at the sites where big vessels branch off, such as the internal carotid artery bifurcation.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1382.
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1890.

choices.text: Bilateral intercostal chest tubes are present in correct place

questions.text: A 16 years old male presents with rapidly developing bilateral pleural effusion. The following chest radiograph was taken in the emergency. All are correct interpretations about this radiograph except:
questions.solution:
Option 4 is correct- there is no pleural effusion- it appears to be consolidation at left lower zone.
Right sided Hyper lucency present -Suggestive of pneumothorax.
Bilateral ICD tubes in situ
Mediastinal shift seen.


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 50-52.

questions.text: Spot radiograph from a double contrast esophagram. Image depicts:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Feline oesophagus.

Feline esophagus/esophageal shiver:
  • Refers to the Transient transverse bands visualized in mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow.
  • Pathology-
    • Associated with active gastro-esophageal reflux which causes contraction of muscularis mucosae 
    • As a result, there is shortening of the esophagus along with 'bunching up' of the mucosa in the lumen. 


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 493, 494.

questions.text: An MRI of the skull shows:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Vein of Galen malformation.
 



Vein of Galen malformation:
  • Congenital malformation of the intracranial circulation characterized by an enlarged midline venous structure (persistent embryological remnant of median prosencephalic vein) with multiple arteriovenous communications leading to aneurysmal dilatation. 
  • It constitutes one of the causes of pediatric stroke. 
  • Clinical presentation: 
    • Neonates- Severe cardiac failure
    • Infants- Due to smaller degree of shunting, cardiac failure is uncommon. Present with hydrocephalus and cerebral atrophy.
    • Older children-Headache, seizures, intracerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhage. 
Radiological features: 
  • CT- Parenchymal calcification secondary to chronic venous hypertension
  • MRI- Investigation of choice. It demonstrates
    • Dilated venous sac
    • Location of fistulous connections
    • Feeding arteries 
    • Draining veins 
    • Extent of parenchymal damage in the form of infarction/atrophy. 
  • Angiography- Gold standard. Diagnostic as well as therapeutic 

Other options: -



Pneumocephalus 

Crouzon syndrome is a type of cranial synostosis 


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 288.
D'Souza D, Campos A, Neto A, et al. Vein of Galen aneurysmal malformation. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-2263

questions.text: An X-ray of the skull reveals which lesions are present in the brain:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Paget’s disease. 
 
  • The given skull radiograph shows cotton wool skull seen in Paget’s disease.
  • Results from thickened, disorganized trabeculae leading to areas of sclerosis in a previously lucent area of bone.
  • Sclerotic patches tend to be poorly defined and fluffy.
The radiographic signs seen in Paget’s disease are enlisted below:



Other options: -
Multiple Myeloma has multiple punched out lesions in the skull
Osteomyelitis and osteosarcoma are not seen in skull hence ruled out.


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1114.
Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 151, 152.

questions.text: CT of the thorax indicates:
questions.solution:
CT anatomy involving the arteries of CT thorax
The descending aorta commences at the level of the fourth thoracic vertebra body, on its left, in the plane of Ludwig as the continuation of the aortic arch. It descends in the posterior mediastinum initially on the left of the thoracic vertebral bodies, but then in the midline

A
 

Contrast-enhanced CT (preferably CTA) gives excellent detail. Findings include: 

  • intimal flap

  • double-lumen representing the true and false lumens

  • dilatation of the aorta due to aortic insufficiency 

  • an atypical variant that may be seen is an aortic intramural hematoma

  • Mercedes-Benz sign in the case of a "triple-barreled" dissection

  • Windsock sign




    Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 424-428.

questions.text: 50y old male comes with history of RTA in hypotension. The resident ER doctor orders a FAST scan . What does FAST stand for ?
questions.solution:
• Focused Assessment With Sonography in Trauma (FAST) is an ultrasound protocol developed to assess for hemoperitoneum and hemopericardium. The sensitivity of FAST has been measured between 85 and 96%, and specificity greater than 98%.

In eFAST or Extended FAST right and left thorax is also visualized. 

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 356.

questions.text: Find artery "X" in the anatomical angiography image provided:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Superior mesenteric artery

The X marked structure in the angiography given above shows the origin of Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) along with its branches.





Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 2081, 2088.
D'Souza D, Superior mesenteric artery. Case study, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024), https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-36188. URL: https://radiopaedia.org/cases/superior-mesenteric-artery

questions.text: According to the following X-ray, what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Bladder stones.


 
  • Bladder calculi/bladder stones.
  • Comprise ~ 5% of all urinary tract stones. 
  • Divided into primary, secondary, and migratory stones:
    • Primary: bladder stones seen in absence of other urinary tract abnormality
    • Secondary: Stones formed in an abnormal bladder or from concretions on foreign material (e.g. urinary catheters)
    • Migratory: Renal calculi which have migrated down into the bladder
Radiographic features:
 
  • Plain radiograph
    • Densely radiopaque, calculi may be
    • Single or multiple and tend to be large. 
    • Lamination seen internally, like the skin of an onion.
  • Ultrasound
    • Mobile, echogenic, and shadow posteriorly. 
    • Can be associated with bladder wall thickening due to inflammation.
  • CT remains the investigation of choice. 
  • Above image is showing a Calcified Uterine fibroid.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1509, 1510.

questions.text: Which condition is depicted in the MRI T1 WI image below?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Dandy Walker malformation.

MRI is the modality of choice in evaluation of Dandy-Walker malformation.

Dandy-Walker malformation consists of:
  • Hypoplasia of vermis with cephalad rotation of the hypoplastic remnant.
  • Cystic dilatation of the fourth ventricle extending posteriorly causing anterolateral displacement of cerebellar hemispheres. However, the cerebellar hemispheres retain their normal morphology and size. 
  • Posterior fossa enlargement
  • Torcular-lambdoid inversion wherein torcula lies above the level of lambdoid due to abnormally high tentorium 




Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 2038.

questions.text: The image reflects which sign
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2: Sea shore sign.
  • The given M mode ultrasound image shows sea-shore sign which represents normal sliding between pleural and lung.
  • In pneumothorax, absent sliding on M mode results in barcode/stratosphere sign.
  • The seashore sign can be detected in M-mode imaging of a normal lung in the given image. The time-motion display of the ultrasound wave along a selected ultrasound line is referred to as M-mode. Even rapid motions can be seen, quantified, and recorded when using the -mode. The motionless area of the chest above the pleural line produced horizontal "waves" in the USG's M-mode, and the sliding area below the pleural line produced a granular pattern, or "sand," pattern.


Reference: Bhoil, Rohit et al. “Signs and lines in lung ultrasound.” Journal of ultrasonography vol. 21,86 (2021): e225-e233. doi:10.15557/JoU.2021.0036

questions.text: Mention Cystic lesion in suprasellar region with calcification.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Craniopharyngioma.

The classical history of a cystic suprasellar mass with calcification points towards diagnosis of craniopharyngioma. 

  • Craniopharyngioma is divided into two morphological types- adamantinomatous craniopharyngiomas and papillary craniopharyngiomas.
  • Both are relatively benign WHO grade 1 tumors that typically arise in sellar/suprasellar region.
  • Adamantinomatous craniopharyngiomas- Characterized as cystic masses with peripheral calcifications in children.
  • Papillary craniopharyngiomas- Present as mostly solid masses in adults. 

Craniopharyngiomas are diagnosed through contrast-enhanced MRI scans and CT scans, which help to identify the presence of solid and cystic components, as well as calcification which is present in 80% of these tumors. Physical symptoms such as compression of the optic chiasm or raised intracranial pressure (ICP) are often seen in those with craniopharyngiomas. Treatment approaches for craniopharyngiomas may involve surgery, radiation, drug treatment or a combination of these treatments.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1418, 1430, 1435, 1437, 1438.

questions.text: A patient comes to your OPD with history of Fever and Productive Cough for one week with progressive worsening of Dyspnoea. As the consultant physician you order a CXR. What is the most likely finding in the CXR given below?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Consolidation.

The given X-Ray shows opacity in the region of right middle lobe with obscuration of right border of heart which is suggestive of consolidation likely secondary to pneumonia due to clinical history of fever with productive cough. 

The right middle lobe of the X-ray shows opacities suggesting consolidation.


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 6th edition, Page no 247.

questions.text: A 35 year old man presets with recurrent episodes of fever with chills and fatigue, an MRCP image is given. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Primary sclerosing cholangitis.

The given MCRP image shows multiple short segment strictures with intervening biliary tree appearing normal/mildly dilated (beading). This along with clinical history of recurrent episodes of fever with chills points towards diagnosis of primary sclerosing cholangitis. 

Thick-slab oblique coronal MRCP is a type of imaging that shows multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic segments of stricturing. This type of imaging is useful in diagnosing primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), an inflammatory disease that affects the bile ducts inside and outside the liver. PSC is characterized by the narrowing and scarring of the bile ducts that can lead to cirrhosis, liver cancer, and other serious complications. The thick-slab oblique coronal MRCP shows evidence of multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic segments of stricturing which is typical for a PSC diagnosis.

Atypical p- ANCA is positive. Onion skin appearance on HPE. Ulcerative colitis is sometimes associated.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1241, 1254, 1255.
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1503, 1504.

questions.text: What is the finding of the X ray given below?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Congenital scoliosis.

In the given chest and abdomen radiograph, the dorsal spine shows lateral curvature with convexity towards left in upper part and towards right in lower part which is suggestive of scoliosis. This along with presence of hemivertebra in dorsal spine makes the diagnosis in favor of congenital scoliosis. 




Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 499-501.

questions.text: Which of the following  procedure would be contraindicated in patient whose CXR is shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: ICD insertion.

  • The given image shows elevation of left hemidiaphragm with presence of bowel and stomach beneath it.
  • In such a scenario, insertion of chest tube is contraindicated as the X-Ray findings could be due to diaphragmatic injury following blunt trauma in road traffic accident. 
  • Blunt trauma to the diaphragm results in linear diaphragmatic rupture, which if large, can lead to herniation of abdominal contents into chest. 
  • Management- Primary repair via abdominal approach to manage associated visceral injuries.

ICD insertion could injure viscera therefore it is contraindicated.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 377.

questions.text: After being struck by a bull, a 30-year-old patient later complained of abdominal pain for the past three days, obstipation, and nausea, and vomiting for the last two days. After being initially stabilized, he now complains of worsening abdominal pain, and an examination revealed rigidity in his abdomen. The results of a CT scan are shown below. What is the most probable reason for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Hollow viscus perforation.

  • The given axial CT scan of the abdomen shows presence of air in the peritoneal cavity beneath the anterior abdominal wall. 
  • The given radiographic findings along with clinical features of obstipation, worsening abdominal pain and rigidity in the abdomen points towards diagnosis of pneumoperitoneum secondary to hollow viscus perforation. 
  • Most common cause of pneumoperitoneum in adults- Hollow viscus perforation
  • Most common cause in neonates- Necrotizing enterocolitis
  • Best X-Ray projection- Erect chest X-Ray PA view
  • Investigation of choice- CT Abdomen 

The various named signs in pneumoperitoneum are as follows:




Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 205, 1048, 1049, 1052.
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1236, 1455.

questions.text:
30y old with history of repeated middle ear infections in the past now developed Fever with Altered sensorium since three days. CT scan was taken which is shown below
The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Temporal lobe abscess.

  • The given axial CECT brain section shows presence of ring enhancing lesion in left temporal lobe. The given radiographic finding along with history of chronic ear infection points towards diagnosis of temporal lobe abscess. 
  • The CT brain scan reveals a tumour that resembles a ring and is indicative of a temporal abscess.
  • CSOM is the most typical cause of brain abscess. The infection causes a temporal lobe abscess when it enters the ear and travels to the tegmen tympani. It can also cause a posterior fossa abscess by entering through a sinodural abscess.



Reference: Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology and Head and Neck Surgery Volume 2: Paediatrics, The Ear, and Skull Base Surgery, 8th edition, Page no 1012.

questions.text: The following is the X ray of a patient who presented with abdominal pain and multiple episodes of vomiting. The abdominal X ray is given below. These loops correspond to which part of the intestines?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Jejunum.
 
  • This abdominal radiograph shows dilated bowel loops located centrally in the abdomen with multiple complete transverse lines with-Volvulae conniventes-s/o small bowel loops. 
  • Large bowel loops are always peripheral in location and show incomplete transverse wall folds- haustrations.
  • Among small bowel loops, jejunal loops are located in the upper abdomen- as in this image- with prominent mucosal folds. 
  • Ileal loops are located in the lower central abdomen and do not show prominent wall folds. 
Hence these loops are jejunal loops. 


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 597-599, 672.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1288.

questions.text: What is the name of the examination indicated below in a female who presented with recurrent miscarriage?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Hysterosalpingography.
 
  • Hysterosalpingography is a fluoroscopic procedure wherein a cannula (Leech Wilkinson cannula) in inserted in the cervix and iodinated contrast material is injected through it.  
  • The contrast outlines the uterine cavity, bilateral fallopian tubes and shows free spill into the peritoneal cavity.
  • It is primarily done for evaluation of infertility to look for causes such as 
    • Tubal patency/tubal pathology such as cornual block, hydrosalpinx. 
    • Mullerian duct anomalies
    • Uterine adhesions 
  • The best time to perform hysterosalpingography is between day 6 and day 10 of menstrual cycle.  

A radiologic method called hysterosalpingography, also called uterosalpingography, examines the fallopian tubes' size, shape, and patency in addition to the uterine cavity's contour. This denotes a unique x-ray that uses dye to examine the Fallopian tubes and womb.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 216, 218, 507.

questions.text: The antenatal USG of a female who is 20 weeks pregnant is provided below. Which congenital anomaly is most likely to exist?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Anencephaly.
 
Anencephaly:
  • Most severe form of cranial neural tube defect (NTD)
  • Occurs due to failure of closure of rostral neuropore leading to failed crania vault development and unprotected exposed brain tissue (exencephaly).
  • Subsequent destruction/autolysis leaves a flattened, amorphous vascular-neural mass characteristic of anencephaly. 
Antenatal ultrasound:
 
  • Sonographically detectable as early as 11 weeks. 
  • Sonographic features of anencephaly include:
  • Absence of parenchymal tissue above the orbits along with calvarium 
  • Small amount of neural tissue may be present which is termed as exencephaly
  • Less than expected value for crown-rump length (CRL)
  • "Frog eye" or "Mickey Mouse" appearance- Seen in coronal plane due to absent cranial bone along with brain and bulging orbits
  • Polyhydramnios due to impaired swallowing





Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 231, 1805, 1986.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 202, 471, 472, 736.

questions.text: An HIV-positive 45-year-old woman who was administered ergotamine for migraines experienced searing and non-palpable dorsalis pedalis discomfort in the middle of her leg. What's the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Correct option is 1: Ergotism.
  • The given imaging modality is CT angiography of lower limb vessels which is showing non-opacification of lower limb vessels distal to bilateral superficial femoral artery. 
  • The given radiographic findings along with history of consumption of ergotamine for migraine points towards diagnosis of ergotism which is characterized by dry gangrene due to vasoconstriction  
  • Ergotism affects the more poorly vascularized distal structures, such as the fingers and toes. 
  • Clinical features include:
    • Desquamation or peeling
    • Weak peripheral pulses
    • Loss of peripheral sensation 
    • Edema
    • Gangrene
  • Ergotism is the result of chronic ergot poisoning, which is traditionally brought on by consuming the alkaloids made by the fungus Claviceps purpurea. The fungus's ergotamine-ergocristine alkaloids cause vasoconstriction, which leads to dry gangrene.
  • It affects the distal structures that have less blood flow, like the fingers and toes. Desquamation or peeling, weak peripheral pulses, loss of peripheral feeling, edema, and eventually the death and loss of affected tissues are some of the symptoms. Vasodilators are used to treat vasoconstriction.

In atherosclerosis there would be focal luminal narrowing of the artery.


Reference: KD Tripathi Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page no 191.
Jeong, Seok-Young et al. “Ergotism with ischemia in all four extremities: a case report.” Journal of clinical neurology (Seoul, Korea) vol. 2,4 (2006): 279-82. doi:10.3988/jcn.2006.2.4.279

questions.text: Recognize the MRI sequence.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: SWI.
 
The image shown is susceptibility weighted image (SWI) and it shows microhemorrhages as hypointense foci. 

Susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI) 
  • MRI sequence sensitive to compounds which distort the local magnetic field.
  • Useful in detecting blood products, calcium, etc.
  • The most common use of SWI is for identification of small amounts of hemorrhage/blood products or calcium, both of which are difficult to appreciate on other MRI sequences. 





Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1406, 1407.
Gaillard F, Foster T, Alhusseiny K, et al. Susceptibility weighted imaging. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-13858

questions.text: The following CXR is performed on a patient  who presented with sporadic abdomen pain and minor upper abdominal discomfort. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1- 

The given chest X-Ray shows a raised Hemi-diaphragm on one side , which is consistent with Eventration of the diaphragm. Eventration is charecterized by an abnormal elevation of the diaphragm due to a congenital or acquired weakness of the diaphragmatic muscle, resulting in an abnormally high but intact diaphragm. 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernias: If the elevation was due to CDH there would be evidence of abdominal organs such as bowel loops or abdominal organs within the thoracic cavity


Option D- Gastric volvulus is a relatively uncommon condition presenting with Borchardt’s triad which includes:
  • Sudden onset severe abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with production of little vomitus 
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric tube. 
  • Gastric volvulus is broadly divided into 2 types- organoaxial and mesentroaxial. 
  • Chest X-Ray shows upside down stomach which is intra-thoracic in location along with retrosternal or mediastinal air-fluid level. 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 377.

Radswiki T, Campos A, Silverstone L, et al. Diaphragmatic eventration. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-13370

questions.text: The results of a CECT performed for examination on a 35-year-old female with a Bosnian Type 3 Cyst are displayed below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1: Angiomyolipoma.
 
  • Renal angiomyolipomas- Benign renal neoplasms composed of vascular, smooth muscle and fat elements. 
  • Considered a type of PEComas due to presence of perivascular epithelioid differentiation. 
  • They can be encountered sporadically as well as a part of tuberous sclerosis. 
  • Clinically, they can either be asymptomatic or can present with retroperitoneal hemorrhage (Wunderlich syndrome). 
  • The risk of bleeding is proportional to the size of lesion. 

Radiographic features-
  • USG- Hyperechoic lesion in the cortex due to the presence of macroscopic fat. ( Remember, fat appears hyperechoic- bright on USG )
  • CT scan, cornerstone feature is to demonstrate the presence of macroscopic fat seen as hypoattenuating lesion which is black in color. 
  • MRI- Used to differentiate fat containing AMLs from an entity known as fat poor AML.

Treatment- 

Indication for intervention with either embolization or resection with partial nephrectomy are-
  • Asymptomatic lesions > 4 cm in dimension. 
  • Symptomatic AML
Lesions presenting with retroperitoneal hemorrhage as in the given clinical scenario require emergency embolization as a life saving measure. 

Option B- Oncocytoma. Predominantly benign lesion characterized by presence of a sharp central stellate scar easily seen on CT scan. 



Option C- RCC. 
CT is the investigation of choice for both diagnosis as well as staging where it appears as a heterogeneously enhancing mass lesion.
 


Option D- Renal cyst. It is a broader term which includes cystic lesions of kidney. They can either be simple or complicated. Bosniak system of classification is used for characterization of renal cysts. It is based on their appearance on contrast-enhanced CT scan. 
 




Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 796-799.

questions.text: A USG abdomen of a 20-week-pregnant female is shown below. What is the most likely anomaly?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Anencephaly.
 
  • The sagittal plane of the provided USG scan reveals anencephaly.
  • The loss of cortical tissue and the absence of the cranial vault describe anencephaly, the most severe type of cranial neural tube defect (NTD). However, the brainstem and cerebellum may occasionally be present.
Anencephaly:
  • Most severe form of cranial neural tube defect (NTD)
  • Occurs due to failure of closure of rostral neuropore leading to failed crania vault development and unprotected exposed brain tissue (exencephaly).
  • Subsequent destruction/autolysis leaves a flattened, amorphous vascular-neural mass characteristic of anencephaly. 
Antenatal ultrasound:
 
  • Sonographically detectable as early as 11 weeks. 
  • Sonographic features of anencephaly include:
  • Absence of parenchymal tissue above the orbits along with calvarium 
  • Small amount of neural tissue may be present which is termed as exencephaly
  • Less than expected value for crown-rump length (CRL)
  • "Frog eye" or "Mickey Mouse" appearance- Seen in coronal plane due to absent cranial bone along with brain and bulging orbits
  • Polyhydramnios due to impaired swallowing



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 231, 1805, 1986.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 202, 471, 472, 736.

questions.text: A 16-year-old child with refractory seizures has several ring enhancing lesions on an MRI of the brain, and MRS results show high lactate, choline, and alanine levels. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Neurocysticercosis.
Causative agent- Pork tapeworm- Taenia solium. 
Most common site-Subarachnoid space along cerebral convexity whereas 

Most common intraventricular site-Fourth ventricle. 

Four different stages have been described using Escobar’s staging:
  • Vesicular stage-
    • Indicates acute infection with live quiescent parasite.
    • Seen as an eccentric dot within the cyst which is called target sign/cyst with a dot sign/dot in a hole sign. 
    • Absence of surrounding edema, inflammation, or post contrast enhancement. 
  • Colloidal vesicular stage- 
    • Early subacute stage. 
    • Due to parasitic degeneration, there is diffusion of parasitic antigens into the adjacent brain which leads to severe inflammation with edema and contrast enhancement- ring enhancing lesion as shown in the given image.  
  • Granular nodular stage-  
    • Late subacute stage 
    • Characterized by body’s attempt to curb the infection. 
    • Decreasing trend of edema, inflammation and contrast enhancement with retraction of cyst wall. 
  • Nodular calcified stage- 
    • Chronic stage of infection with dead, densely calcified parasite.
    • Absence of edema, inflammation and post contrast enhancement. 

The given clinical case along with MRI and MRS findings are suggestive of Neurocysticercosis.
 
Neurocysticercosis is caused due to infection by pork tapeworm, Taenia solium, in the central nervous system.
 
The condition clinically presents as seizures in young adults along with headache, altered mental status. Seizures are the most common presenting symptom.
 
  • It shows multiple ring enhancing lesions on MRI which can also be seen in other conditions such as tuberculomas, metastasis, abscesses. Along with the MRI findings, elevated levels of choline, alanine, succinate and lactate and decreased levels of N- acetylaspartate and creatine are seen on Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy in case of Neurocysticercosis. Thus, the diagnosis of Neurocysticercosis can be made.


Tuberculoma- ring enhancing lesion 

Toxoplasmosis- Multiple ring enhancing lesion with surrounding vasogenic edema 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1791, 1792.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with high blood pressure (160/100 mmHg) and a 120-beats-per-minute heart rate arrived at the emergency room. The results of a CECT are provided below. How is the condition being described being managed?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Surgical repair.

The given axial CECT scan of chest shows presence of an acute aortic dissection involving ascending aorta with intimal flap separating true and false lumen. 
Debakey and Stanford classification systems are used for aortic dissection. 



As a thumb rule, Stanford type A dissections which involve ascending aorta require surgical repair whereas Stanford type B dissections which involve descending aorta can be managed conservatively by beta-blockers. 
 
  • Type A ( ascending aorta ) dissections:
    • Lead to aortic rupture into the pericardial space and hemopericardium thereby rapidly progressing to cardiac tamponade and cardiogenic shock. 
    • Critical to confirm or exclude diagnosis of type A aortic dissections as they are surgical emergencies with high mortality rate. 
  • CT angiography- Initial study of choice in hemodynamically stable patients with no e/o renal dysfunction. Shows flap separation of true and false lumen.  
  • MR angiography- More time consuming and requires administration of gadolinium contrast. Therefore, it is avoided in patients with chronic kidney disease.
  • Transesophageal (and not transthoracic echocardiography) has excellent sensitivity and specificity. It is the preferred diagnostic study in hemodynamically unstable patients. 


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 970, 971.
Braunwald's Heart Disease, 12th edition, Page no 827.

questions.text: Based on the results of the CT scan shown below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Extradural hemorrhage.

The given NCCT head shows hyperdense lentiform shaped bleed along left frontal convexity. This along with typical history of unconsciousness-brief period of alertness-again unconsciousness which is suggestive of lucid interval is diagnostic of extradural hemorrhage. 

Epidural hemorrhage:
  • Collection of blood between inner surface of the skull and outer layer of the dura
  • Associated with a history of head trauma and skull fracture. 
  • Resultant bone fragments cause laceration of middle meningeal artery. 
  • Investigation of choice is NCCT. 
  • Swirl Sign- Non-contrast appearance of acute extravasated blood into hematoma. Unclotted fresh blood is of lower attenuation that clotted blood surrounding it. 

Option B- Subdural hemorrhage is characterized by accumulation of blood between dura and arachnoid matter which appears as concavo-convex hyperdensity on NCCT scan. 
 


Option C- Hemorrhagic contusion- Intraparenchymal in location. Seen in areas of brain in close proximity to rough bony surfaces such as orbitofrontal and temporal region of brain. CT shows ill-defined hyperdensities (blood) with surrounding hypodensities (peri-bleed edema)


 
Option D- Subarachnoid haemorrhage appears as collected hyperdensity in sulcal spaces or basal cisterns, usually secondary to traumatic brain injury or rupture aneurysm. 





Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 365-367.

questions.text: A four-year-old boy was diagnosed with painless genu varum. The results of a bilateral knee X-ray are displayed below. Which of the following diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Rickets.

The given radiograph of bilateral knee joint shows presence of metaphyseal widening, cupping, splaying and fraying of ends of visualized femur, tibia and fibula which is diagnostic of rickets. 
  • Rickets is a disorder of growing skeleton. 
  • Deficiency of normal mineralization seen in rickets is most evident at metaphyseal zones of provisional calcification.
  • There is an excess of non-mineralized osteoid resulting in growth plate widening and abnormal configuration of the metaphysis-
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Splaying: widening of metaphyseal ends
  • Cupping: concavity of metaphysis 
  • Findings of rickets are most prominent at the bones where growth is greatest:
  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: ulna 
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary
Other findings: 
  • Outward bowing of legs with variable deformity of the hips (both coxa vara and coxa valga seen)
  • Genu valga and vara
  • Protrusio acetabuli
  • Inward drawing of lower ribs due to inferior attachment of the diaphragm-Harrison's sulcus
  • Codfish vertebra 



Scurvy x ray findings


Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 143.

questions.text:
After falling from the roof, a 50-year-old man arrives with acute chest discomfort, breathing problems, and crepitus.
Shown is the X-ray image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Flail chest.
 
  • Flail chest occurs when two or more contiguous ribs are fractured at two or more sites as shown in the given X-Ray. 
  • Results in paradoxical movement of the flail segment.
  • Can be either clinically occult or can lead to severe ventilation difficulties.
  • Investigation of choice is CT scan. 
  • Management- Proper oxygenation, pain management, if required surgical management


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 375.
Stanislavsky A, Hacking C, Silverstone L, et al. Flail chest. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-10820

questions.text: A 76-year-old man arrives with a history of headaches following a fall. A CT scan was conducted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Acute subdural hemorrhage.

The given NCCT scan demonstrates concavo-convex hyperdensity along left fronto-parietal convexity. This along with typical history of trivial fall and gradually worsening sensorium is diagnostic of subdural hemorrhage. 

Subdural hemorrhage:
  • Bleeding between dura and arachnoid mater secondary to rupture of bridging cortical veins. 
  • Associated with underlying brain damage. 
  • Not limited by cranial sutures. 
  • Limited by dural folds of falx cerebri, falx cerebella and tentorium. 
  • Pseudo-empty Delta sign- Acute SDH lining the wall of superior sagittal sinus making the wall of the sinus appear hyperdense while the contents look relatively hypodense resembling empty delta sign of venous sinus thrombosis. 
  • SDH in neonates and infants should raise suspicion of non-accidental injury/battered baby syndrome. 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 366, 367.

questions.text: In the given figure, which of the following are correctly labeled?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Conus medullaris.

A - Conus medullaris 
B - Subarachnoid space around cauda equina 
C - Posterior longitudinal ligament 
D - Body of first lumbar vertebra 


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1225-1229.
